In and around the capital, Thang Long, all the talk was of the hundred shows, water puppets, lantern processions and other marvels that the Emperor, Son of Heaven, would delight his subjects with on the fifteenth day of the eighth month. Tam was eager to go too.
But when the day came, the stepmother handed her a heavy basket of mixed rice and paddy:
- Separate the rice from the paddy," she quipped, "and you can join us at the party. Then, decked out in their finest tunics and silk pants, mother and daughter set off for the Capital to enjoy themselves, while Tam, faced with this insurmountable task, had only her eyes for tears.
Once again, the Buddha appeared to him.
- O Venerable Elder, my heart craves to go to the King's feast! Even if I manage to sort the rice and paddy from this basket, the feast, alas, will be long over!
At these words, the Buddha summoned a flock of birds from the clouds to help her. Poor grieving Tam trembled lest they eat the grain. So when her stepmother returned, she'd get the rattan!
The Buddha reassured her.
- Don't worry. I've forbidden them to take your rice and paddy.
In less time than it takes to chew a betel quid, the job was done. However, Tem
continued to cry: how could she bring her face to the King's party in these rags?
- Go and get the four pots containing the bones of the goby fish buried in the four corners of your bat-flanc, they contain what you need.
Then he disappeared.
Tam ran to dig out the pots. With exclamations and endless invocations to Buddha's holy name, she emerged in regalia worthy of an Immortal.
Who, seeing her so adorned in silk embroidered with cranes fluttering among impalpable mists, so coiffed in a jewelled tiara and so sweetly shod in little sandals of gold and pearls, wouldn't have exclaimed: "There's a beauty to make fish dive and wild geese fall.
The fourth pot contained a Lilliputian horse which, as soon as she had put it down, became a superb steed, richly caparisoned and topped with a golden-fringed parasol. Like a radiant lotus, she made her way to the party.
As she passed, the admiring people of Thang Long wondered where she had come from, some taking her for one of those "pink-clouded beauties" exiled on earth, others for a distant Princess with a fairy-like face. Seeing her from afar, Câm exclaimed:
- Mommy! Mommy! Mommy! Mommy! I can't believe my flesh eyes! Over there, isn't that my sister Tam?
- Your sister Täm so magnificently adorned? That would be quite extraordinary! She's at home sorting the rice and paddy I've mixed.
Shuttles on the job, the hours at the party flew by! Suddenly realizing that he had to be home by
back from her stepmother, Tâm turned around. She had just crossed the wooden bridge over the Tô Lich River not far from the Royal City, when suddenly there was a great din of gongs and exclamations:
- Prostrate yourselves! Prostrate yourselves!" shouted His Majesty's tattooed guards. Make way! Make way! The Emperor, Son of Heaven, pass!
In her haste, Tam lost one of her sandals, which fell into the river near the bank. Without bothering to look for it, she galloped off. Moments later, as the royal procession passed by, the King's elephant, with a barking sound that would wake heaven and earth, stopped dead in its tracks, refusing to go any further. This was most unusual. From the great dignitaries who made up the imperial retinue to the little servants who carried parasols and betel services, everyone was stunned. Intrigued, the Emperor ordered his guards to search the river and the bank below the bridge to see if there was indeed something extraordinary going on. Shortly afterwards, the guards emerged from the water and brought back a pretty golden woman's sandal, set with pearls. At the sight of it, the Emperor's heart was moved in a strange way, for it could only belong to a very beautiful woman, in every way worthy of being his wife. The following night, tossing and turning on his bed during the night watches, this idea was to haunt him.
So much so that, in the early hours of the morning, a eunuch was expressly commissioned to go and try the sandal on all the girls present at the party. Tired and exhausted, he had visited all the houses in and around the capital to no avail when he arrived at the stepmother's house.
Despite his best efforts, Cam's foot wasn't small enough to fit comfortably either!
- Monsieur l'Eunuque, may I try it?" asked Tam timidly. - When brass bells and bronze tom-toms can't triumph, how can a broken jar?" laughed her stepmother. However, the gynecological eunuch had a keen eye for beauty:
- Please try, Miss!
O obvious surprise from some! Oh, the fury of others! The little sandal of gold and pearls was a perfect fit for her cute arched foot! Then, obeying orders, Her Majesty's tattooed guards solemnly carried Tam in a palanquin to the Palace, where she became Queen. A gentle, beautiful and generous wife, tenderly loved by the Emperor, as the days went by, their union was such that it could be said:
"Predestined fate, by binding them together, has united the apricot tree with the bamboo and harmonized the chords of the lute with those of the lyre."
Some time later, having to sacrifice to the anniversary rites of her father's death, Tam obtained permission from the Emperor to return to her native village. The couple reluctantly parted, and Tam, laden with offerings, arrived at her stepmother's for the ceremony.
Although her daughter-in-law's perfect success had infuriated her black liver and purple entrails, it was with sweet words, sweet smiles and the most vivid signs of affection that she, imitated by her daughter Cam, welcomed Tam as he stepped off the palanquin.
"Faced with the height of mountains and the depth of oceans, only the heart of man is unfathomable." "
- Wouldn't it be the utmost filial piety," she said to Tam, "to go to the top of the arequite?
to gather with your own hands, as you once did, the nuts destined for your father's altar? Tam, unsuspecting, stripped off her beautiful clothes and climbed the arequite. When she reached the top, the stepmother, aided by her daughter, attacked the trunk with an axe.
- What are you doing, Mother-in-law?" cried Tam, shaking east and west, clinging to the tree with all her might. - I'm chasing the ants away so they don't bite you," she shouted, continuing to do so. With a sinister crack, the tree collapsed, throwing Tam into the nearby pond, where she struggled for a long time before sinking and disappearing. When the last air bubble had burst on the surface of the water :
- Now it's your turn to be Queen," said the stepmother to her daughter.
And she dressed her in Tam's magnificent finery before sending her back to the Palace to take her elder sister's place. - If anyone questions you, all you have to say is that the Queen ran away from home in the middle of the night, that we searched in vain until morning, and that fearing the wrath of Her Majesty, you've come to replace her.
The Emperor was deeply saddened by the disappearance of his beloved wife. He dispatched soldiers and officers with drums and tom-toms to find her. But to no avail. His heart was broken with sadness and overwhelmed with grief. Then, one day, as the eunuchs were laying out His Majesty's freshly laundered clothes in the imperial garden, an oriole sang to them in a very distinct voice:
"If you dry my husband's clothes Hang them on bamboo poles
Never lay them on hedges
For fear of tearing them!"
These words having been reported to the Emperor, he hurried off to listen to the bird, which was reportedly filling his precious garden with its human song. Disturbed, he whispered: "Loriot! Sweet oriole!
If you're my wife reincarnated
If you're his metamorphosis into a talking bird
Come in quickly, quickly, please
In the sleeve of my dress
Immediately the bird came to nestle in the silk against his arm, and its warm, gentle presence seemed the sweetest of caresses. From then on, day and night, the Emperor spent every spare moment by the golden and vermilion cage of his favorite oriole. Not for a moment did he think about Câm, the younger sister, who continued to live at the Palace and, out of jealousy, gritted her teeth.
Informed of the affair, his mother advised him to kill the oriole, eat its flesh and throw its feathers into the garden. - How come I can't find my talking bird?" asked the dismayed Emperor, but no one could answer.
From the oriole feathers scattered behind the Palace, two flamboyant trees were to emerge, the like of which the imperial garden had never possessed. The Emperor, fascinated by their beauty, had a pink hammock hung between their trunks to relax in the cool of the sun.
When Cam told her about this new development, her mother urged her to have the trees cut down and the trunks used to make a loom for her personal use. But whenever Cam wanted to use it, the loom would say: "Keo cà, keo ket!
You've supplanted me, your elder sister!
To you who took my husband from me
I'll gouge out the eyes!"
- Get rid of this cursed profession! Burn it and throw its ashes far away from here! And so it was.
Shortly afterwards, from the ashes scattered by the roadside, a splendid persimmon tree sprang up, intriguing passers-by: why didn't it bear any fruit? - It's truly a marvel. Why don't we see any fruit on it?" asked an old merchant one day, as she sat down to rest at the foot of the tree.
She was scanning the foliage when she spotted a solitary fruit at the top of the tree, superbly round, ravishing in color and finished in beauty, seemingly straight out of the Jade Emperor's garden.
- Oh," she said to herself, "I'd be so happy if this fruit would come off! She made this wish:
"Kaki! Kaki!
Falls gently into my basket
I want so much to look at you, to breathe you in
Not eat you"
Thus solicited, the plaquemine fell. Delighted, the old woman took it to the straw hut where she ran her modest business selling soup, tea and roadside sweets.
The next day, like every other day, the old merchant set off early to the market to stock up on supplies. On her return, a surprise awaited her: who had tidied up her house, swept her yard in such a pleasant way and prepared on a platter the whole meal of rice, meats and broths, and those graceful betel quid? And so it was every day.
And every day she would say to herself, "How is it that when I return I find my yard in order and my meal served?"
One morning, she pretended to leave for the market, then, as silent as a leaf, returned to press her eye against the bamboo rack. Carp's mouth dropped open in surprise! Here was a young girl of extraordinary beauty standing in the middle of her poor straw hut! Where had this person come from, whom she hadn't seen enter her house? Suspecting that the plaquemine was hiding a metamorphosis, the old merchant ran to fetch the fruit in the rice jar. But all she found was an empty peel, which she tore into many pieces and hid elsewhere, before rushing back into the house, coughing to attract attention. Torn from her enchantment, the young girl wanted to flee and return to the plaquemine, but it had disappeared. Realizing she was a fairy, the old merchant, filled with joy, took her affectionately by the waist. From then on, the fairy lived in her home as if she were her own daughter, helping her with her business, which soon flourished thanks to her unrivalled beauty and friendliness. Nights of light breezes and moonlight followed one another. One day, the Emperor's palanquin passed by, escorted by a few servants, traveling incognito. The venerable, prosperous appearance of the store immediately appealed to His Majesty and made him want to quench his thirst.
Respectfully, the old merchant immediately served him fragrant tea in a warm, well-covered bowl, and offered him betel quid artfully rolled into phoenix wings. At the sight of them, His Majesty felt his vital spirits evaporate.
- Who made these betel quid?" he asked, shocked because they were so similar to the ones his late wife used to prepare for him. The old merchant didn't know what to answer, so the Emperor ordered vehemently: "Old woman, tell me clearly and immediately who she is?
Then the old merchant confessed that it was her daughter and called her.
The moment the fairy appeared on the threshold, the Emperor thought he was living in a dream, his eyes wide open: it was the former Queen Tam, his beloved wife. Interrupting his prostrations, with tears of joy, he took her hands and lifted her up. She looked just as she had before, and even more beautiful. Having generously rewarded the old merchant, he took his precious wife back to the Palace.
Cam, on seeing her again, exclaimed:
-You were dead, now you've been resurrected! And she began to praise her beauty, her skin so white and velvety. How do you manage to possess this marvelous beauty, which is perfection itself?
- Would you like to have your turn, my Cadette?
- Yes, Elder Sister," Cam replied.
- So be it," says Tam.
While water was being heated in a huge chaurdron, a deep ditch was dug. All dreaming of being beautiful, Cam climbed down into it. Then Tam had the boiling water poured over her in great abundance.
When Cam died, Tam ordered his servants to chop up her corpse into small pieces, marinate it in brine and place it in a jar to be offered to the stepmother.
- It's a supply of brine," said the servants your daughter sent you.
And the stepmother rejoiced at her daughter's gift and said to herself: "Tam, my adopted daughter, when she was Queen, did not have to be the only one.
never sent me anything. Now that she's dead, I couldn't be happier!"
Since she found the food delicious, she tasted it at every meal. And at every meal, a raven perched on the roof would call out to her:
"Not so good
You eat the flesh of your child
And you find it delicious
Give me a piece
If you have any left!"
- Cursed animal!" cried the old woman, chasing it away with a stone, but it always came back.
The jar of salted meat was running out. The old woman was about to finish it, when at the bottom of the jar she spotted a long lock of black hair, which she grabbed with disgust. At the end of it hung the head of
Cam, his daughter.
In horror, in shock, in pain, her lower and higher souls flew apart, and she fell dead.
"Terrible is the way of Heaven, which plans to reciprocate for good and for evil!"
Contes et légendes d'Asie. Contes d'une grand-mère vietnamienne, collected and presented by Yveline Féray, Arles,
Philippe Picquier, 1998, P. 13-32.

Content:
Il était une fois un homme et une femme qui avaient seulement une fille. Il arriva un jour que l’un de leurs moutons s’égara ; ils se mirent à sa recherche, chacun d’un côté du bois. Alors la brave femme rencontra une sorcière qui lui dit: «Si tu craches, misérable créature, si tu craches dans le fourreau de mon couteau, ou si tu passes entre mes jambes, je te changerais en mouton noir.» La femme ne cracha pas, ne passa pas entre ses jambes, et cependant la sorcière la changea en mouton. Et celle-ci se métamorphosa de manière à ressembler exactement à la femme, puis elle appela le brave homme : «Holà, mon homme, j'ai retrouvé le mouton.» L'homme pensa que la sorcière était sa vraie femme, il ne savait pas que son épouse était devenue le mouton. Aussi revint-il à la maison, heureux d’avoir retrouvé l’animal. Une fois arrivés à la maison, la sorcière dit à l’homme : « Tu vois, mon homme, il faudrait tuer ce mouton, de peur qu’il ne s’enfuie de nouveau dans les bois. » L'homme qui était d’un naturel pacifique ne fit aucune objection, il dit simplement : « Bien, faisons-le. » La fille, cependant, avait entendu leur conversation; elle courut vers le troupeau et se lamenta à haute voix: «Oh! chère petite mère, ils veulent te tuer! — Alors, s'ils m'abattent, répondit le mouton noir, tu ne mangeras pas la chair et tu ne boiras pas le bouillon qui en provient, mais tu rassembleras tous mes os et tu les emporteras à la bordure du champ où tu les enterreras.» Peu après, ils
sortirent le mouton noir du troupeau et ils l’abattirent. La sorcière en fit une soupe et l'offrit à la fille. Celle-ci se souvint de l'avertissement de sa mère. Elle ne toucha pas à la soupe, elle rassembla les os, les porta à la bordure du champ où elle les enterra; et à cet endroit, poussa un bouleau, un très beau bouleau./
Quelque temps s’écoula - qui pourrait dire combien ? La sorcière, qui avait eu un enfant, commença à prendre en grippe la fille de l’homme : elle la tourmentait de toutes les façons possible. Il arriva qu’une grande fête devait être donnée au palais; le roi avait ordonné que tout le peuple fut invité et il fit proclamer :
« Venez, tout le monde!
Que vous soyez pauvres ou misérables! Que vous soyez aveugles ou infirmes, Montez vos coursiers, ou venez par voie maritime. »
Alors se dirigèrent vers la fête du roi tous les bannis, les estropiés, les invalides, les aveugles. Dans la maison du brave homme, on faisait aussi des préparatifs pour aller au palais. La sorcière dit à l’homme : «Pars en avant, mon homme, avec ta plus jeune fille ; je vais donner du travail à l’aînée pour qu’elle ne s’ennuie pas durant notre absence. Alors l’homme partit avec l’enfant. La sorcière fit du feu dans l’âtre, jeta un pot plein de grains d'orge dans les cendres, puis dit à la jeune fille : «Si, avant la nuit, tu n'as pas trié et replacé dans le pot les grains, je t'avalerai!»
Alors elle rejoignit les autres : la pauvre fille en pleurs resta seule à la maison. Elle essaya de ramasser les grains d'orge, mais constata vite que ses efforts étaient vains; terriblement tourmentée, elle se rendit auprès du bouleau sur la tombe de sa mère, et elle pleura, elle pleura, parce que sa mère était morte et enterrée et qu’elle ne pouvait plus l'aider. Dans son chagrin, elle entendit soudain la voix de sa mère s'élever de la tombe, qui lui disait : «Pourquoi pleures-tu, ma petite fille ? - La sorcière
a éparpillé des grains d'orge dans l'âtre et elle m'ordonne de les trier des cendres, dit la petite, c’est pourquoi je pleure, chère petite mère. - Ne pleure pas, dit la mère d'une voix consolante, casse l’une de mes branches et frappe l'âtre en croix, tout s’arrangera. » La jeune fille fit ainsi et, voyez!, les grains volèrent dans le pot, et l’âtre était tout propre. Elle retourna près du bouleau, et mit la branche sur la tombe. Alors, sa mère lui fit prendre un bain d’un côté de la branche, elle la sécha d’un autre côté, elle l’habilla sur le troisième. Quand ce fut fini, elle avait tellement embelli que personne sur terre n’aurait pu rivaliser avec elle. Elle por- tait une robe splendide, elle avait un cheval dont la crinière était partie en or partie en argent, et en partie de quelque chose d’encore plus précieux. La jeune fille monta en selle et fila comme une flèche vers le palais. Comme elle arrivait dans la cour du château, le fils du roi vint à sa rencontre, attacha son coursier à un poteau et la fit entrer. Il se tenait près d’elle en parcourant les pièces de la demeure; tout le monde la contemplait, admirait sa beauté et se demandait de quel château elle venait ; mais personne ne savait rien d'elle. Au banquet le prince l’invita à s’asseoir à ses côtés, à la place d'honneur, mais la fille de la sorcière rongeait des os sous la table. Le prince ne l’avait pas vue ; pensant que c'était un chien, il lui donna un tel coup avec son pied qu'il lui cassa un bras. N'est-ce pas triste pour la fille de la sorcière ? Ce n'était pas de sa faute si sa mêre était une méchante femme.
Le soir venant, la fille du brave homme pensa qu'il était temps de rentrer à la maison ; mais quand elle partit, sa bague se prit au loquet de la porte, car le fils du roi l'avait enduit de goudron. Elle n'eut pas le temps de la reprendre, en hâte, elle détacha son cheval, s’éloigna du château comme une flèche. Arrivée à la maison, elle enleva ses vêtements près du bouleau, y laissa son cheval et se dépêcha d'occuper sa place derrière le poêle. Peu
après, l’homme et la femme revinrent aussi à la maison et la sorcière dit à la jeune fille : « Ah ! ma pauvre, tu es là! Tu ne sais pas les bons moments que nous avons passés au palais! Le fils du roi n’a pas quitté ma fille, mais la pauvre malheureuse est tombée et s’est cassé le bras ! » La jeune fille savait bien comment les choses s’étaient réellement passées, mais elle prétendit n’en rien connaître et elle s’assit en silence derrière le poêle Le lendemain, ils furent de nouveau invités au banquet du roi.« Holà, mon homme, dit la sorcière, habille-toi aussi vite que tu peux; nous sommes priés à la fête. Emmène ton enfant, je vais donner du travail à l’autre, sinon elle va se morfondre.» Elle fit du feu, jeta un plein pot de graines de chanvre dans les cendres, et dit à la jeune fille : «Si tu ne tries pas toutes les graines dans le pot, je te tuerai!» La jeune fille se mit à pleurer amèrement ; puis elle se rendit auprès du bouleau, se lava d’un côté de l’arbre, se sécha de l’autre; cette fois encore, de magnifiques vêtements lui furent offerts, ainsi qu’un beau coursier. Elle cassa une branche du bouleau, en frappa l’âtre, si bien que les graines s’envolèrent dans le pot. Elle se hâta alors vers le château.
Le fils du roi vint de nouveau à sa rencontre, attacha son cheval, et la conduisit dans la salle du banquet. À la fête, la jeune fille s’assit près de lui à la place d’honneur, comme la veille. Mais la fille de la sorcière rongeait des os sous la table, et le prince lui donna sans le savoir un coup qui lui cassa la jambe - il ne l’avait pas vue qui se traînait au milieu des pieds des invités. Elle était vraiment très malchanceuse ! La fille du brave homme se hâta de rentrer à la maison à temps, mais le fils du roi avait enduit les montants de la porte avec du goudron, et son diadème en or y resta collé. Elle n'avait pas le temps de s’en occuper, elle sauta en selle et chevaucha comme une flèche jusqu’au bouleau. Elle y laissa son cheval et ses beaux vêtements et dit à sa mère: «J'ai perdu mon diadème ; les montants ges porte étaient pleins de goudron et il s'y est collé. - Et tu en
aurais perdu deux, répondit la mère, je t’en redonnerais de plus beaux encore.»
Alors la jeune fille se hâta vers la maison, et quand son père y revint avec la sorcière, elle était à sa place habituelle derrière le poêle. La sorcière lui dit: «Pauvre malheureuse! Y a t-il ici quelque chose de comparable à ce que nous, nous avons vu au palais ? Le fils du roi a porté ma fille de salle en salle; il l'a laissée tomber, c’est vrai, et ma fille s’est cassé le pied ». La fille du brave homme resta impassible pendant ce temps; elle s’occupa du foyer. Le lendemain matin, à l’aube, la sorcière éveilla son mari, en criant : « Ho! debout, mon homme! Nous sommes invités au banquet royal». Il se leva. La sorcière lui confia l’enfant : « Prends la petite ; je vais donner du travail à l’autre fille, sinon elle se lasserait de rester seule ». Elle fit comme d'habitude. Cette fois, ce fut un pot de lait qu’elle versa dans les cendres : «Si tu ne remets pas le lait dans le pot avant mon retour, tu en pâtiras ».
Quelle fut la peur de la jeune fille cette fois-ci! Elle courut au bouleau et, grâce au pouvoir magique de l'arbre, la tâche fut accomplie ; ensuite, elle alla à cheval au palais comme les jours précédents. Quand elle arriva dans la cour, le prince l’attendait. Il la conduisit dans le hall, où elle reçut les honneurs ; mais la fille de la sorcière suçait des os sous la table, et, accroupie aux pieds des gens, elle reçut un coup dans l’œil, pauvre petite! Personne ne connaissait rien à propos de la fille du brave homme, personne ne savait d’où elle venait. Mais le prince avait enduit le seuil de goudron, et, lorsqu’elle s'enfuit, ses pantoufles y restèrent collées. Arrivée près du bouleau, elle enleva ses parures : « Hélas, chère petite mère, j'ai perdu mes pantoufles en or! - Ne t’en fais pas, fut la réponse de la mère, si tu en as besoin, je t'en donnerai de plus belles. » À peine était-elle installée à sa place habituelle que son père rentra avec la sorcière. Immédiatement, celle-ci commença à se moquer : « Ah! pauvre malheureuse, il
n'y a rien ici à voir, et nous, ah! quelles belles choses nous avons vues au palais ! Ma petite fille a été portée de nouveau, mais elle a eu la malchance de tomber et de recevoir un coup à l'œil. Toi, stupide créature, que peux-tu savoir de ces choses ? - Oui, vraiment, qu’en puis-je savoir ?, répondit la jeune fille, j’ai assez à faire à nettoyer l’âtre. »
Le prince avait gardé tout ce que la jeune fille avait perdu, et il se mit en quête de la propriétaire. À cette fin, il donna un grand banquet le quatrième jour, tout le monde y était invité. La sorcière se tint prête. Elle attacha une traverse de bois à la place du pied de sa fille, un autre morceau en guise de bras, et un peu de boue dans l'orbite de l’œil. Elle l’emmena au palais. Quand tout le monde fut rassemblé, le fils du roi s’avança dans la foule pour annoncer : « La jeune fille à qui cet anneau ira au doigt, ce diadème au front et ces pantoufles aux pieds, deviendra mon épouse». Combien de tentatives! Aucune ne réussit. « La jeune fille des cendres n’est pas là, dit à la fin le prince, allez la chercher et faites-la essayer».
On fit chercher la jeune fille. Le prince était sur le point de faire l’essai lorsque la sorcière surgit : «Ne faites pas cela, elle souille tout avec la cendre ; tentez plutôt avec ma fille». Le prince donna l’anneau à la fille de la sorcière ; celle-ci rogna le doigt de sa fille jusqu’à ce que l’anneau entre. La sorcière interdit qu’on essaie avec'la fille des cendres ; elle tailla la tête et les pieds de sa fille jusqu’à ce que le diadème et les pantoufles lui aillent. Que pouvait-on faire ? Le prince devait prendre la fille de la sorcière comme épouse, qu'il le veuille ou non. Il s’esquiva avec elle à la maison de son père, car il avait honte de célébrer au palais son mariage avec une épousée si étrange. Quelques jours après, il était sur le point d'amener la mariée au palais, lorsque la fille de cuisine surgit de sa place près du poêle, feignant d’avoir quelque chose à prendre dans l’étable. En passant près de lui dans la cour, elle lui murmura à l’oreille : «Hélas! cher prince, ne me
dérobez pas mon or et mon argent». Le fils du roi reconnut la fille des cendres; alors il emmena les deux avec lui. Ils arrivèrent au bord d'une rivière; le prince jeta en travers la fille de la sorcière en guise de pont et continua avec la fille des cendres, laissant là la malheureuse, au-dessus de l’eau, incapable de bouger car son cœur était consumé de chagrin. Aucune aide en vue; elle cria, pleine d'angoisse : « Qu'il pousse de mon corps une ciguë dorée! Peut-être ma mère me reconnaîtra grâce à ce signe». À peine avait-elle parlé qu’une ciguë dorée, surgie de son corps, surplombait le pont.
Aussitôt débarrassé de la fille de la sorcière, le prince élut la fille des cendres comme épouse; ils se rendirent ensemble près du bouleau qui poussait sur la tombe de la mère. Ils reçurent là toutes sortes de trésors et de richesses, trois sacs pleins d’or, autant d'argent, et un splendide coursier, qui les ramena au palais. Ils y vécurent longtemps ensemble, la jeune femme donna un fils au prince. Immédiatement le mot fut passé à la sorcière : sa fille avait accouché d’un garçon; tous croyaient que l'épouse du prince était la fille de la sorcière. « Bien, bien, se dit la sorcière, je vais donner un cadeau au nouveau-né. » Elle se mit en route aussitôt. Elle arriva au bord de la rivière ; elle y vit la magnifique ciguë dorée qui poussait au milieu du pont et, lorsqu'elle essaya de la couper pour la donner à son petit-fils, elle entendit une voix qui gémissait : « Hélas ! chère mère, ne me coupe pas! - Es-tu ici ?, demanda la sorcière. - Oui, je suis ici, chère petite mère, répondit la fille. Ils m'ont jetée en travers de la rivière pour faire de moi un pont.» En un instant la sorcière avait fracassé le pont en morceaux ; elle se hâta alors vers le palais. S'approchant du lit de la jeune Reine, elle commença à essayer sa magie sur elle. Elle dit :««Crache, toi, misérable, sur la lame de mon couteau ; ensorcelle la lame de mon couteau pour moi, et je te changerai en renne de la forêt. - Allez-vous me causer de nouveaux ennuis ?», dit la jeune femme. Elle ne cracha ni ne fit rien
d'autre, mais la sorcière la métamorphosa en renne. Elle substitua sa propre fille en tant qu'épouse du prince. Mais, à partir de ce moment, le nouveau-né ne connut plus de repos, pleurant sans cesse parce que sa mère lui manquait. On l’amena à la cour, on essaya de le calmer de toutes les manières possibles, mais il ne cessait jamais de pleurer.
« Qu'est-ce qui trouble ainsi cet enfant ? » demanda le prince. Il alla trouver une veuve d’une grande sagesse pour lui demander conseil. « Non, non, votre épouse n'est pas à la maison, dit la veuve; elle vit dans les bois comme un renne ; vous avez maintenant pour femme la fille de la sorcière, et la sorcière elle-même pour belle-mère. - Y at-il aucun moyen de faire revenir des bois mon épouse ? demanda le prince. - Donnez-moi l'enfant, répondit la veuve. Je l'emmènerai demain quand je conduis mes vaches vers les bois. Je provoquerai un bruissement de feuilles de bouleau et un frémissement de feuilles de tremble : il se peut que l’enfant se calme en entendant ces bruits. - Oui, prenez l'enfant, emmenez-le avec vous pour l’apaiser, dit le prince et il la conduisit au château. - Comment cela ? vous emmenez l'enfant dans les bois ? » dit la sorcière d’un ton suspicieux, essayant de l’en empêcher. Mais le fils du roi tint bon : «Allez avec l'enfant dans les bois, peut-être cela le calmera. » Alors la veuve l'emmena: Elle alla jusqu’au bord d’un marais, voyant qu'il s’y trouvait un troupeau de rennes. Elle commença aussitôt à chanter :
Petite Yeux-brillants, petite Peau-vermeille, Viens prendre soin de l'enfant que tu as mis au monde ! Ce monstre assoiffé de sang Cette sinistre ogresse ne s'en occupera plus Ils peuvent menacer et gronder autant qu'ils veulent il se détourne d'elle, il s'en écarte.
Et aussitôt, le renne s’approcha et allaita l'enfant et prit soin de lui toute la journée ; mais, à la tombée de la nuit, devant suivre le troupeau, elle dit à la veuve : « Amenez-moi l'enfant demain, et le jour suivant; ensuite je dois partir au loin avec le troupeau vers d’autres contrées. » Le lendemain, le veuve revint au château pour prendre l’enfant. Naturellement la sorcière s’interposa, mais le prince déclara : « Emmenez-le au grand air ; le garçon a été plus calme cette nuit, certainement parce qu’il a été dans les bois toute la journée ». Alors la veuve prit l'enfant dans les bras et l'amena au marais de la forêt. Là elle chanta comme la veille.
Petite Yeux-brillants, petite Peau-vermeille, Viens prendre soin de l'enfant que tu as mis au monde! Ce monstre assoïffé de sang Cette sinistre ogresse ne s'en occupera plus Îls peuvent menacer et gronder autant qu'ils veulent il se détourne d'elle, il s'en écarte.
Et immédiatement, le renne quitta le troupeau, s’approcha de l'enfant et en prit soin comme la veille. Et l’enfant était florissant, il n’y avait pas de plus beau garçon au monde. Le fils du roi réfléchissait à tout cela, il dit alors à la veuve : «N’y a-t-il aucun moyen de retransformer le renne en être humain ? — Je ne le sais pas avec certitude, fut sa réponse. Mais venez avec moi dans les bois ; quand la femme enlèvera son pelage de renne, je peignerai ses cheveux ; pendant ce temps, vous brûlerez la peau. » Sur ce, ils allèrent tous deux dans les bois avec l'enfant ; à peine étaient-ils arrivés que le renne apparut et se mit à allaiter l'enfant. Alors la veuve lui dit: « Puisque vous serez demain au loin, que je ne vous reverrai pas, laissez-moi peigner vos cheveux pour la dernière fois, en sou- venir de vous». La jeune femme se dépouilla de son pelage, laissant faire la veuve comme elle l’entendait. Aussitôt, sans se faire voir, le fils du roi jeta la peau de renne dans le feu.
« Qu'est-ce qui sent le roussi ? », demanda la jeune femme et, regardant tout autour d'elle, elle aperçut son époux. « Malheur à moi! Vous avez brûlé ma peau: pourquoi ? — Pour vous rendre votre forme humaine. — Jour de malheur! Je n'ai rien maintenant pour me couvrir, pauvre créature !», cria la jeune femme qui se transforma d’abord en quenouille, puis en morceau de bois, puis en fuseau, et en toutes sortes de formes imaginables. Mais le fils du roi détruisait l'une après l’autre toutes ces formes, jusqu’à ce qu'elle ait retrouvé son apparence humaine. « Hélas! je dois donc rentrer à la maison avec vous, où la sorcière va me manger, pleura la jeune femme. — Elle ne vous mangera pas, répondit son mari, et ils se dirigèrent tous vers la maison. Mais quand la sorcière les vit, elle s'enfuit avec sa fille, et si elle ne s’est pas arrêtée, elle court encore, malgré son âge. Et le prince, et son épouse, et le bébé vécurent heureux pour toujours.
Andrew Lang, The Red Fairy Book, London, Longmans, Green and Co, 1890, p. 123-132.
English:
Once upon a time there was a man and a woman who had only one daughter. One day one of their sheep went astray; they went looking for it, each on one side of the wood. Then the good woman met a witch who said to her: "If you spit, miserable creature, if you spit in the sheath of my knife, or if you pass between my legs, I will change you into a black sheep." The woman did not spit, did not pass between her legs, and yet the witch changed her into a sheep. And she transformed herself so that she looked exactly like the woman, and then she called to the good man: "Hello, my man, I have found the sheep." The man thought that the witch was his real wife; he did not know that his wife had become the sheep. So he returned home, happy to have found the animal. When they arrived at the house, the witch said to the man, "You see, my man, we must kill this sheep, lest it run away into the woods again." The man, who was of a peaceful nature, made no objection; he simply said, "Very well, let us do it." The girl, however, had overheard their conversation; she ran to the flock and lamented aloud, "Oh, dear little mother, they want to kill you!" "Then if they slaughter me," replied the black sheep, "you shall not eat the flesh or drink the broth that comes from it, but you shall gather all my bones and carry them to the edge of the field where you shall bury them." Soon after, they took the black sheep out of the flock and slaughtered it. The witch made soup from it and offered it to the girl. The girl remembered her mother's warning. She didn't touch the soup, she gathered the bones, carried them to the edge of the field where she buried them; and there grew a birch tree, a very beautiful birch tree.
Some time passed—who could say how much? The witch, who had a child, began to take a dislike to the man's daughter: she tormented her in every possible way. It happened that a great feast was to be given at the palace; the king had ordered that all the people be invited and he had it proclaimed:
"Come, all of you!
Whether you are poor or wretched! Whether you are blind or crippled, mount your steeds, or come by sea."
Then all the banished, the crippled, the disabled, the blind, and the blind set out for the king's feast. In the good man's house, preparations were also being made to go to the palace. The witch said to the man: "Go ahead, my man, with your youngest daughter; I'll give the eldest some work so she won't get bored while we're away. So the man left with the child. The witch made a fire in the hearth, threw a pot full of barley grains into the ashes, and then said to the young girl: "If, before nightfall, you haven't sorted the grains and put them back in the pot, I'll swallow you!" So she joined the others: the poor girl, weeping, remained alone at home. She tried to gather the barley grains, but soon realized that her efforts were in vain; terribly tormented, she went to the birch tree on her mother's grave and wept and wept, because her mother was dead and buried and she could no longer help her. In her grief, she suddenly heard her mother's voice rising from the grave, saying to her: "Why are you crying, my little girl? “The witch scattered barley grains in the hearth and she orders me to sort them from the ashes,” said the little girl, “that’s why I’m crying, dear little mother.” “Don’t cry,” said the mother in a consoling voice, “break off one of my branches and strike the hearth crosswise, everything will be all right.” The girl did so and, look! the grains flew into the pot, and the hearth was all clean. She went back to the birch tree and placed the branch on the grave. Then her mother bathed her on one side of the branch, dried her on another, and dressed her on the third. When it was finished, she had become so beautiful that no one on earth could have rivaled her. She wore a splendid dress, she had a horse whose mane was partly gold, partly silver, and partly something even more precious. The girl mounted her and rode like an arrow to the palace. As she arrived in the castle courtyard, the king's son came to meet her, tied his steed to a post, and brought her in. He stood beside her as he rode through the rooms of the house; everyone gazed at her, admired her beauty, and wondered which castle she came from; but no one knew anything about her. At the banquet the prince invited her to sit beside him in the place of honor, but the witch's daughter was gnawing bones under the table. The prince had not seen her; thinking she was a dog, he kicked her so hard that he broke her arm. Isn't that sad for the witch's daughter? It wasn't her fault that her mother was a Wicked woman.
When evening came, the good man's daughter thought it was time to go home; but as she left, her ring got caught on the door latch, for the king's son had tarred it. She didn't have time to retrieve it; in haste, she untied her horse and rode away from the castle like an arrow. Arriving at the house, she took off her clothes by the birch tree, left her horse there, and hurried to take her place behind the stove. Soon after, the man and woman also returned home, and the witch said to the young girl, "Ah! My poor thing, you're here! You don't know what a wonderful time we had at the palace! The king's son didn't leave my daughter, but the poor wretch fell and broke her arm!" » The girl knew very well how things had really happened, but she pretended to know nothing about it and sat silently behind the stove. The next day they were again invited to the king's banquet. "Hey, my man," said the witch, "get dressed as quickly as you can; we are invited to the feast. Take your child with you, I will give the other one some work, otherwise she will mope." She made a fire, threw a full pot of hemp seeds into the ashes, and said to the girl: "If you don't sort all the seeds into the pot, I will kill you!" The girl began to weep bitterly; then she went to the birch tree, washed on one side of the tree, and dried herself on the other. This time again, beautiful clothes were presented to her, as well as a handsome steed. She broke off a branch of the birch tree and struck the hearth with it, so that the seeds flew into the pot. She then hurried to the castle.
The king's son came to meet her again, tethered his horse, and led her into the banquet hall. At the feast, the girl sat next to him in the place of honor, just as she had the day before. But the witch's daughter was gnawing bones under the table, and the prince unknowingly struck her with a blow that broke her leg—he hadn't seen her dragging herself amidst the guests' feet. She was truly very unlucky! The good man's daughter hurried home in time, but the king's son had coated the doorposts with tar, and her gold diadem stuck to them. She had no time to worry about it; she jumped into the saddle and rode like an arrow to the birch tree. There she left her horse and her beautiful clothes and said to her mother, "I have lost my diadem; The doorposts were full of tar, and it stuck to them. "And if you had lost two," replied the mother, "I would have given you even more beautiful ones." So the young girl hurried back to the house, and when her father returned with the witch, she was in her usual place behind the stove. The witch said to her, "Poor wretch! Is there anything here comparable to what we saw at the palace? The king's son carried my daughter from room to room; he dropped her, it's true, and my daughter broke her foot." The good man's daughter remained impassive during this time; she took care of the hearth. The next morning, at dawn, the witch woke her husband, shouting, "Oh! Get up, my man! We are invited to the royal banquet." He stood up. The witch entrusted the child to him: "Take the little one; I'll give the other girl some work, otherwise she'd get tired of being alone." She did as usual. This time, she poured a jug of milk into the ashes: "If you don't put the milk back in the jug before I return, you'll suffer."
How frightened the girl was this time! She ran to the birch tree and, thanks to the tree's magic power, the task was accomplished; then she rode to the palace as on previous days. When she arrived in the courtyard, the prince was waiting for her. He led her into the hall, where she received the honors; but the witch's daughter was sucking bones under the table, and, crouching at people's feet, she received a poke in the eye, poor little thing! No one knew anything about the good man's daughter, no one knew where she came from. But the prince had smeared the threshold with tar, and when she ran away, her slippers stuck to it. Arriving near the birch tree, she took off her finery: "Alas, dear little mother, I have lost my golden slippers!" "Don't worry," was the mother's reply, "if you need them, I will give you more beautiful ones." Hardly had she settled into her usual place when her father returned with the witch. Immediately, the latter began to mock her: "Ah! poor wretch, there is nothing here to see, and we, ah! what beautiful things we saw at the palace! My little girl was carried out again, but she had the misfortune to fall and receive a blow to the eye. You, stupid creature, what can you know about these things?" "Yes, really, what can I know?" replied the young girl, "I have enough to do at clean the hearth."
The prince had kept everything the girl had lost, and he set out to find the owner. To this end, he gave a grand banquet on the fourth day, to which everyone was invited. The witch was ready. She attached a wooden crosspiece to her daughter's foot, another piece for an arm, and a little mud in the eye socket. She took her to the palace. When everyone was gathered, the king's son stepped forward into the crowd to announce: "The girl on whom this ring fits, this diadem on her forehead, and these slippers on her feet, will become my wife." How many attempts! None succeeded. "The girl of the ashes is not here," the prince said at last, "go and find her and have her tried on."
The girl was sent for. The prince was about to try it when the witch appeared: "Don't do that, she contaminates everything with ashes; try it with my daughter instead." The prince gave the ring to the witch's daughter; she clipped her daughter's finger until the ring fit. The witch forbade anyone to try it with the daughter of ashes; she clipped her daughter's head and feet until the diadem and slippers fit her. What could be done? The prince had to take the witch's daughter as his wife, whether he liked it or not. He slipped away with her to his father's house, for he was ashamed to celebrate his marriage to such a strange bride in the palace. A few days later, he was about to bring the bride to the palace when the kitchen maid appeared from her place by the stove, pretending to have something to take from the stable. As she passed by him in the courtyard, she whispered in his ear: "Alas! dear prince, do not steal my gold and silver." The king's son recognized the daughter of ashes; So he took the two with him. They arrived at a riverbank; the prince threw the witch's daughter across as a bridge and continued with the Ashen Girl, leaving the unfortunate woman there, above the water, unable to move for her heart was consumed with grief. No help was in sight; she cried out in anguish: "Let a golden hemlock grow from my body! Perhaps my mother will recognize me by this sign." Hardly had she spoken than a golden hemlock, sprouting from her body, overhung the bridge.
As soon as he was rid of the witch's daughter, the prince chose the Ashen Girl as his wife; they went together to the birch tree that grew over the mother's grave. There they received all sorts of treasures and riches, three sacks full of gold, as much silver, and a splendid steed, which brought them back to the palace. They lived there together for a long time, and the young woman bore the prince a son. Immediately the word was passed to the witch: her daughter had given birth to a boy; everyone believed that the prince's wife was the witch's daughter. "Well, well," said the witch to herself, "I will give the newborn a present." She set out at once. She came to the riverbank; there she saw the beautiful golden hemlock growing in the middle of the bridge, and when she tried to cut it down to give to her grandson, she heard a voice moaning: "Alas! dear mother, do not cut me!" "Are you here?" asked the witch. "Yes, I am here, dear little mother," replied the girl. "They threw me across the river to make a bridge." In an instant the witch had smashed the bridge to pieces; she then hurried to the palace. Approaching the young Queen's bed, she began to try her magic on her. She said: "Spit, you wretch, on the blade of my knife; Bewitch the blade of my knife for me, and I will change you into a forest reindeer. “Are you going to cause me more trouble?” said the young woman. She didn’t spit or do anything else, but the witch transformed her into a reindeer. She substituted her own daughter as the prince’s wife. But from that moment on, the newborn knew no rest, crying constantly because he missed his mother. He was brought to court and tried to calm him in every way possible, but he never stopped crying. “What is troubling this child?” asked the prince. He went to a widow of great wisdom to ask her advice. “No, no, your wife is not at home,” said the widow. “She lives in the woods like a reindeer; now you have the witch’s daughter for a wife, and the witch herself for a stepmother.” “Is there no way to bring my wife back from the woods?” asked the prince. "Give me the child," replied the widow. "I will take him tomorrow when I drive my cows to the woods. I will make the birch leaves rustle and the aspen leaves rustle; perhaps the child will calm down when it hears these sounds." "Yes, take the child, take him with you to calm him down," said the prince, and he led her to the castle. "What do you mean? You're taking the child into the woods?" said the witch suspiciously, trying to stop her. But the king's son stood firm: "Go with the child into the woods, perhaps that will calm him down." So the widow took him: She went to the edge of a marsh, seeing that there was a herd of reindeer there. She immediately began to sing:
Little Bright-Eyes, little Red-Skin, Come and take care of the child you brought into the world! This bloodthirsty monster This sinister ogress Will no longer take care of it They can threaten and scold as much as they want, it turns away from it, it moves away.
And immediately, the reindeer approached and suckled the child and took care of it all day; But, at nightfall, having to follow the herd, she said to the widow: "Bring me the child tomorrow, and the day after; then I must go far away with the herd to other lands." The next day, the widow returned to the castle to take the child. Naturally, the witch intervened, but the prince declared: "Take him out into the open air; the boy was calmer last night, certainly because he was in the woods all day." Then the widow took the child in her arms and brought him to the forest marsh. There she sang as she had the day before.
Little Bright-Eyes, little Red-Skin, Come and take care of the child you brought into the world! This bloodthirsty monster This sinister ogress will no longer take care of him They can threaten and scold him as much as they want, he turns away from her, he moves away from her. And immediately the reindeer left the herd, approached the child, and took care of him as he had the day before. And the child was flourishing; there was no more beautiful boy in the world. The king's son was thinking about all this, and then he said to the widow, "Is there no way to turn the reindeer back into a human being?" "I don't know for sure," was his reply. "But come with me into the woods; when the woman takes off her reindeer coat, I will comb her hair; meanwhile, you will burn the skin." With that, they both went into the woods with the child; no sooner had they arrived than the reindeer appeared and began to suckle the child. Then the widow said to her, "Since you will be far away tomorrow, and I will not see you again, let me comb your hair for the last time, in memory of you." The young woman took off her coat, leaving the widow to do as she saw fit. Immediately, unnoticed, the king's son threw the reindeer skin into the fire.
"What smells of burning?" asked the young woman, and looking all around, she saw her husband. "Woe is me! You have burned my skin: why?" "To restore your human form." "Unfortunate day! I have nothing now to cover myself with, poor creature!" cried the young woman, transforming herself first into a distaff, then into a piece of wood, then into a spindle, and into every imaginable shape. But the king's son destroyed all these shapes one after the other, until she regained her human appearance. "Alas! I must then return home with you, or the witch will eat me," wept the young woman. "She will not eat you," replied her husband, and they all headed for the house. But when the witch saw them, she ran away with her daughter, and though she hasn't stopped, she's still running, despite her age. And the prince, his wife, and the baby lived happily ever after.
Andrew Lang, The Red Fairy Book, London, Longmans, Green and Co, 1890, pp. 123-132.

Content:
Un homme bon et pauvre avait une femme qui lui avait donné deux petites filles. Mais avant que ces deux enfants, dont la cadette s'appelait Marguerite et l’aînée Annette, n'aient eu le temps de grandir, sa femme mourut, et l’homme en épousa une autre. Voilà que cette femme fut prise de jalousie envers la petite Marguerite et aurait bien voulu qu’elle fût morte. Cependant, comme elle éprouvait des réticences à la tuer elle-même, elle usa de ruse pour attirer à elle la sœur aînée, si bien que celle-ci fut bien disposée à son égard et qu'elle devint hostile à sa sœur.
Un jour, la mère et la fille aînée étaient assises ensemble et se concertaient sur la façon dont elles pourraient bien se débarrasser de la sœur cadette. Elles décidèrent enfin d’aller ensemble dans la forêt en emmenant la fillette avec elles et, une fois là-bas, de l’envoyer au loin de façon à ce qu'elle ne puisse plus les retrouver.
Or la fillette se tenait derrière la porte de la pièce et elle avait entendu tout ce que sa mère et sa soeur disaient contre elle, et comment elles cherchaient des raisons de la faire penir. Elle fut alors très affligée de devoir, sans aucune raison, moutir d’une manière aussi misérable et être mise en pièces par les loups. En proie à son chagrin, elle alla trouver sa marraine, qui l’avait portée sur les fonts baptismaux, et lui raconta l‘immense trahison ainsi que la terrible sentence de mort que sa soeur et sa mère avaient prononcée à son égard. « Eh bien, ma chère enfant, lui dit la bonne vieille, puisqu'il en est ainsi, va chercher de la sciure de bois et, quand tu suivras ta mère,
laisse tomber de la sciure par terre devant toi. Ensuite, quand elles t'auront abandonnée, tu n'auras qu’à suivre cette trace pour rentrer chez toi. »
La bonne fille fit ce que la vieille femme lui avait ordonné. Quand elles furent parvenues toutes les trois dans la forêt, la mère s’assit et parla ainsi à la fille aînée : « Viens près de moi Annette, et épouille-moi un peu ! Pendant ce temps,
Marguerite ira ramasser trois fagots de bois. Nous l’attendrons ici, puis nous rentrerons ensemble à la maison. »
La pauvre fillette partit donc, en laissant tomber de la sciure de bois à ses pieds (car elle savait bien ce qui allait lui arriver), et ramassa trois fagots de bois. Lorsqu'elle les eut ramassés, elle les posa sur sa tête et les porta à l’endroit où elle avait laissé sa marâtre et sa sœur. Mais quand elle arriva là-bas, elle ne les y trouva point. Cependant, elle garda ses trois fagots sur sa tête et rentra chez elle en suivant le chemin qu’elle avait tracé, puis elle jeta à terre son fardeau.
Lorsqu'elle aperçut la fillette, la mère dit à la sœur de celleci : « Annette, notre fille est revenue et toute notre ruse a été vaine. Nous irons donc à un autre endroit demain, et nous l’enverrons de nouveau au loin. Ainsi, elle ne pourra plus retrouver le chemin de la maison, et nous serons alors débarrassées d’elle. » Mais la bonne petite Marguerite avait de nouveau entendu ces paroles. Elle courut une nouvelle fois chez sa marraine et lui raconta tout. « Bien, lui dit la vieille femme. Je vois qu elles en veulent à ta vie et qu’elles n’auront point de repos tant qu'elles ne t'auront pas tuée. Va donc chercher de la balle de grain et laisses-en de nouveau tomber par terre devant toi, comme tu l’as fait avec la sciure de bois. Tu pourras ainsi retrouver le chemin de ta maison. »
Quand la fillette rentra chez elle, sa mère parla ainsi : « Venez ici, Marguerite et Annette ! Nous allons sortir dans la forêt. » L'aïnée, qui était au courant de tout et qui avait aidé sa mére de ses conseils, sortit toute joyeuse. Marguerite, quand à elle, était bien chagrinée. Une fois dans la forêt, la mère, cette femme méchante, sournoise et cruelle s’assit et s'adressa
ainsi à Annette : « Viens par ici, Annette, et épouille-moi un peu ! Pendant ce temps, Marguerite ira chercher un fagot de bois pour chacune d’entre nous ; puis nous rentrerons à la maison. »
La pauvre Marguerite partit et ramassa du bois. Mais avant qu’elle ne fût de retour, sa mère et sa sœur repartirent. Chargée de son bois, la bonne Marguerite suivit donc la trace laissée par la balle du grain, jusqu’à ce qu’elle fût arrivée de nouveau chez elle. Et lorsque sa mère l’aperçut, elle dit à Annette : « Voilà notre fille de malheur qui revient. Voyons à présent comment nous débarrasser d’elle, quand bien même il devrait nous en coûter cher. Demain, nous retournerons dans la forêt et ferons en sorte qu’elle s’y égare. »
La fillette avait de nouveau surpris ces paroles et se rendit pour la troisième fois chez sa marraine afin de lui demander conseil sur ce qu’elle pouvait bien faire. « Eh bien, ma chère enfant, lui dit la vieille, va chercher des graines de lin que tu sèmeras par terre devant toi. Puis rentre chez toi en suivant cette trace. »
La bonne fillette sortit une nouvelle fois dans la forêt avec sa mère et sa sœur, tout en semant les graines de lin sur son chemin. La mère dit de nouveau, comme elle l’avait fait les deux fois précédentes : « Annette, épouille-moi un peu Pendant ce temps, Marguerite ira chercher du bois. » La Pauvre Marguerite partit chercher du bois, tout en se disant « J'ai réussi deux fois à retrouver le chemin de la maison, j'y parviendrai bien une troisième fois. » Mais lorsqu'elle eut ramassé le bois et qu’elle revint à l'endroit où elle avait laissé sa mère, celle-ci était partie. Et quand la pauvre fillette voulut suivre son chemin pour rentrer chez elle, les oiseaux avaient mangé toutes les graines de lin. Mon Dieu, y avait-il plus triste que la pauvre fillette ? Elle courut toute la journée dans la forêt, pleurant, criant, prenant Dieu à témoin de sa détresse, mais elle ne parvenait pas à trouver un chemin qui lui permette de sortir de la forêt. En plus, elle s'était enfoncée si loin dans la forêt qu,elle était parvenue à un endroit si reculé qu'aucun homme n'avait jamais dû y mettre les pieds. Et
quand le soir approcha et que la pauvre fillette abandonnée perdit tout espoir de trouver de l'aide, elle grimpa sur un arbre très élevé pour voir si elle pouvait discerner une ville, un village ou une maison, quels qu’ils soient, où elle pourrait trouver refuge pour ne pas être misérablement livrée en pâture aux bêtes sauvages. Et comme elle regardait ainsi autour d’elle, elle aperçut un mince filet de fumée. Elle descendit de l'arbre en toute hâte, marcha en direction de cette fumée et arriva quelques heures plus tard à l’endroit d’où celle-ci provenait. C’était une petite maisonnette où il ne vivait personne hormis une petite-vache-de-la-terre.
La fillette s’approcha de la porte et frappa, demandant qu’on la laisse entrer. La petite-vache-de-la-terre lui répondit : « Pour sûr, je ne te laisserai pas entrer, à moins que tu ne me promettes de rester auprès de moi jusqu’à la fin de tes jours et de ne jamais me trahir ni parler de moi. » La fillette le lui jura et la petite-vache-de-la-terre la laissa entrer sur-le-champ, puis elle lui dit : « Bien ! Tout ce que tu as le droit de faire, c'est me traire le matin et le soir. Ensuite, tu boiras mon lait, et je t’apporterai de la soie et du velours à ta suffisance. Fais-t'en de belles robes selon ton désir. Mais souviens-toi et veille à ne pas parler de moi ! Quand bien même ta propre sœur viendrait te voir, ne la laisse pas entrer pour que je ne sois pas trahie et qu’on ne sache pas que je me trouve en ce lieu ! Sinon, ma vie serait perdue. » Sur ces mots, la petite vache partit pour sa prairie et, le soir, à son retour, elle rapporta à la fillette de la soie et du velours avec lesquels la bonne Marguerite se fit des habits si riches qu’elle eût pu se comparer à une princesse. Quand elles eurent passé ainsi plus d’une année ensemble, il se que la fille aînée, qui était restée chez elle et qui avait contribué à jeter dans la misère Marguerite, sa jeune sœur innocente, devint songeuse et se demanda ce qu'il pouvais bien être advenu de celle-ci. Elle se mit à pleurer à chaudes larmes, et à penser à l'immense trahison qu'elle avait fait subir à sa soeur aucune raison. En somme, elle fut
ter chez elle, et qu’elle voulait tenter de retrouver ne serait-ce qu'un petit os de sa sœur pour le rapporter chez elle et le conserver soigneusement.
Un jour, de bon matin, elle sortit donc dans la forêt et se mit à chercher, et elle chercha de la sorte, en pleurant pitoyablement, pendant si longtemps qu’elle s’égara complètement dans la forêt. À présent, d’un instant à l’autre, il allait faire nuit noire. Qui donc pouvait être plus triste qu’Annette ? Elle se dit alors que ce devait être sa punition pour ce qu’elle avait fait à sa sœur, et se mit à pleurer à chaudes larmes et à suplier Dieu d’avoir pitié d’elle et de lui pardonner. Mais il ne fallait pas perdre de temps en plaintes et en attente. Elle grimpa donc sur un arbre très haut pour tenter d’apercevoir une maison, quelle qu’elle soit, où elle pourrait passer la nuit pour ne pas être misérablement dévorée par les bêtes sauvages. Et comme elle regardait ainsi autour d’elle, elle aperçut une fumée qui s’élevait de la maisonnette où se trouvait sa sœur. Elle se mit alors en route et se dirigea vers cette maison en se disant que ce devait être la hutte d’un berger ou d’un ermite.
Quand elle arriva devant la maison, elle frappa à la porte. Sa sœur lui demanda peu après qui était là. « Oh, répondit Annette, je suis une pauvre jeune fille qui s’est égarée dans la forêt et je vous prie, pour l'amour du Ciel, de bien vouloir me laisser passer la nuit chez vous. » Marguerite jeta un coup d'œil à travers une fente, reconnut sa sœur perfide et dit : « Vraiment, ma chère enfant, je ne puis te laisser entrer car cela m'est interdit. Si mon maître revenait et voyait que jai laissé entrer un étranger, il me battrait. C’est pourquoi tu dois partir ! »
Mais la pauvre fillette ne voulait pas se laisser dissuader et encore moins chasser. Au contraire, elle supplia tant et si bien sa sœur, sans la reconnaître, que celle-ci lui ouvrit la porte et la laissa entrer.
En entrant, Annette reconnut sa soeur, éclata en sanglots et se mit à remercier Dieu de lui avoir permis de retrouver sa
donner tout ce qu’elle avait fait contre elle. Puis elle lui demanda gentiment de bien vouloir lui dire tout de même qui vivait auprès d’elle pour qu'elle soit si joliment et si richement vêtue. La bonne Marguerite, à qui il était interdit de dire chez qui elle vivait, inventa et invoqua diverses excuses. Tantôt elle dit qu’elle habitait chez un loup, tantôt qu'elle habitait chez un ours. Annette ne voulut rien croire de tout cela et se fit tout sucre, tout miel pour faire dire la vérité à Marguerite, sa jeune sœur. La fillette, qui avait la langue bien pendue (car toutes les femmes ont pour coutume de causer plus que ce qui leur est permis), finit par dire à sa sœur : « J'habite chez une petitevache-de-la-terre, mais garde-toi bien de me trahir ! » Quand elle entendit cela, Annette, à qui la trahison dont elle s'était rendue coupable envers sa sœur n'avait pas encore suffi, lui répondit : « Très bien. À présent, ramène-moi sur le bon chemin pour que je rentre à la maison. » Marguerite s'empressa de le faire. Et quand la bonne Annette arriva chez elle, elle raconta à sa mère comment elle avait trouvé Marguerite dans la maison d’une petite-vache-de-la-terre, et comment sa sœur était vêtue de façon somptueuse. « Parfait, répondit la mère. Nous irons donc la semaine prochaine dans la forêt pour ramener Marguerite et la petite-vache-de-la-terre chez nous. Nous tuerons la petite vache et la mangerons. »
La petite vache savait déjà très bien tout cela, et quand elle rentra chez elle, tard le soir, elle dit en pleurant à la fillette : « Ah ! Ah ! Marguerite chérie, qu’as-tu fait en laissant entrer ta sœur perfide et en lui disant chez qui tu habitais ? Et à présent, vois : la semaine prochaine, ta mère cruelle et ta soeur sortiront dans la forêt pour nous ramener chez elles, toi et moi. Moi, elles me tueront pour me manger, mais toi, elles te garderont chez elles et la vie qu’elles te feront mener sera encore plus dure que jamais. » Après avoir parlé ainsi, la petite vache prit un air si pitoyable que la pauvre fillette fondit larmes et crut mourir de chagrin, tant elle regrettait amèrement d’avoir laissé entrer sa sœur. La petite-vache-de-la-terre la consola cependant en disant : « Eh bien, ma chère enfant, ce qui est fait est fait, et on ne peut
revenir en arrière. Voilà donc ce qu’il te faudra faire : quand le boucher m’aura tuée, reste-là et pleure ! Quand il te demandera ce que tu veux, dis-lui : « J'aimerais bien avoir la queue de ma petite vache.” Il te la donnera. Quand tu l'auras, remets-toi à pleurer et demande-lui une de mes cornes. Quand tu auras celle-ci, pleure de nouveau ! Quand on te demandera ce que tu veux, dis ceci : " Je voudrais bien un sabot de ma petite vache.” Une fois que tu l'auras, va plenter ma queue dans la terre, pose la comme corne pas-dessus puis place le sabot sur la corne et ne t'en éloigne pas pendant trois jours ! Le troisième jour, il en poussera un arbre. Cet arbre portera les plus belles pommes qu'on ait jamais vues, été comme hiver, et toi seule pourras les cueillir. Et grâce à cet arbre, tu deviendras une grande et puissante dame. »
Lorsqu'on tua la petite vache, Marguerite se tenait tout près. Elle demanda toutes ces choses, comme le lui avait enseigné la petite vache, et on les lui donne. Elle alla donc les planter dans la terre et, le troisième jour, il en pourra un bel arbre. Il se trouva qu'un puissant seigneur passait par là. Il était accompagné de son fils qui avait la fièvre. Et quand il vit les belles pommes, le fils dit : « Monsieur mon père, faites-moi apporter des pommes de cet arbre. Je crois que si j'en mangeais, je retrouverais la santé. » Le seigneur ordonna aussitôt qu'on lui apporte des pomme, disant qu'il en donnerait un bon prix.
La fille aînée s'approcha la première de l'arbre et s'apprêta à cueillir des pommes. Toutes les branches se dressèrent alors vers le ciel, si bien qu'il lui fut impossile d'en atteindre une seule. Elle appela alors sa mère et lui ordonna de cueillir des pommes et de les porter ensuite au seigneur. Mais quand la méchante femme s'approcha de l'arbre, les branches remontèrent plus haut encore. Le seigneur avait observé tout cela et en était fort étonné. Enfin, Marguerite s'approcha de l'arbre pour cueillir des pommes. Les branches s'abaissèrent alors vers elle de leur plein gré et la laissèrent cueillir des pommes. Cela étonna le seigneur encore plus et, pensant qu'il s'agissait
rogea sur ce miracle. La brave fille lui raconta alors tout ce qui était arrivé à cause de sa mère, de sa sœur et de la petitevache-de-la-terre, du début jusqu’à la fin. Quand il eut entendu la chose, le seigneur demanda à la jeune fille si elle voulait partir avec lui. La brave fille en fut ravie. Elle déterra son arbre et s’installa avec son père dans le carrosse du seigneur. Celui-ci les accueillit chaleureusement et leur fit tous les honneurs, puis ils partirent, abandonnant là la mère maligne et la sœur.
Version écrite en dialecte alsacien, publiée par Martin Montanus, dans La Compagnie au jardin ( Gartengesellschaft), vers 1559. Albert Wesselski, Deustche Märchen  vor Grimm, Brünn, München, Wien, Rudolf W. Wohrer Verlag, 1942, p. 1-10.
English:
A good and poor man had a wife who bore him two little girls. But before these two children, the younger named Margaret and the older named Annette, had time to grow up, his wife died, and the man married another. This woman became jealous of little Margaret and wished she were dead. However, since she was reluctant to kill her herself, she used trickery to lure the older sister to her, so that the latter was well disposed toward her and became hostile to her sister.
One day, the mother and the older daughter were sitting together and consulting on how they could get rid of the younger sister. They finally decided to go into the forest together, taking the girl with them, and once there, to send her far away so that she would never be able to find them again. Now the little girl was standing behind the door of the room and had heard everything her mother and sister were saying against her, and how they were looking for reasons to have her hanged. She was then very distressed to have to die in such a miserable way and be torn to pieces by the wolves for no reason at all. Overwhelmed by her grief, she went to her godmother, who had carried her to the baptismal font, and told her of the immense betrayal and the terrible death sentence her sister and mother had pronounced upon her. "Well then, my dear child," the good old woman said to her, "since that is so, go and get some sawdust and, when you follow your mother, drop some sawdust on the ground in front of you. Then, when they have left you, you will only have to follow this trail to get home." The good girl did as the old woman had ordered. When the three of them had reached the forest, the mother sat down and spoke to the eldest daughter: "Come near me, Annette, and delouse me a little! Meanwhile,
Marguerite will go and gather three bundles of wood. We will wait for her here, then we will return home together."
So the poor girl set off, dropping some sawdust at her feet (for she knew well what would happen to her), and gathered three bundles of wood. When she had gathered them, she placed them on her head and carried them to the place where she had left her stepmother and her sister. But when she arrived there, she did not find them there. However, she kept her three bundles on her head and returned home by following the path she had marked out, then she threw her burden to the ground. When she saw the girl, the mother said to her sister: "Annette, our daughter has returned, and all our trickery has been in vain. So we will go to another place tomorrow and send her away again. This way, she will no longer be able to find her way home, and then we will be rid of her." But good little Margaret had heard these words again. She ran once more to her godmother and told her everything. "Good," the old woman said to her. "I see that they want your life and that they will not rest until they have killed you. Go and get some more chaff and let some fall on the ground in front of you, as you did with the sawdust. Then you will be able to find your way home." When the girl returned home, her mother spoke thus: "Come here, Margaret and Annette! We are going out into the forest." The eldest, who knew everything and had helped her mother with her advice, left full of joy. Marguerite, for her part, was very upset. Once in the forest, the mother, that wicked, sly, and cruel woman, sat down and addressed Annette thus: "Come here, Annette, and delouse me a little! Meanwhile, Marguerite will fetch a bundle of wood for each of us; then we will return home." Poor Marguerite went and gathered some wood. But before she could return, her mother and sister left again. Loaded with her wood, good Marguerite followed the trail left by the chaff of grain until she arrived home again. And when her mother saw her, she said to Annette: "There's our unfortunate daughter back. Now let's see how we can get rid of her, even if it costs us dearly." Tomorrow we will return to the forest and make sure she gets lost there."
The little girl overheard these words again and went for the third time to her godmother to ask her advice on what to do. "Well then, my dear child," the old woman said to her, "go get some flax seeds and scatter them on the ground in front of you. Then return home following this trail."
The good little girl went out into the forest once again with her mother and sister, scattering the flax seeds along the way. The mother said again, As she had done the two previous times: "Annette, delouse me a little. Meanwhile, Marguerite will go and get some wood." Poor Marguerite went to get some wood, saying to herself, "I've managed to find my way home twice; I'll manage it a third time." But when she had gathered the wood and returned to the place where she had left her mother, she was gone. And when the poor girl tried to continue on her way home, the birds had eaten all the flax seeds. My God, was there anyone sadder than the poor girl? She ran all day in the forest, crying, screaming, calling God to witness her distress, but she couldn't find a way out of the forest. Moreover, she had gone so far into the forest that she had reached a place so remote that no man had ever set foot there. And
When evening approached and the poor, abandoned girl lost all hope of finding help, she climbed a very tall tree to see if she could discern a town, a village, or a house, whatever they might be, where she could find refuge from being miserably left as prey to wild beasts. And as she looked around, she saw a thin wisp of smoke. She hurried down the tree, walked in the direction of the smoke, and a few hours later arrived at the place where it was coming from. It was a small cottage where no one lived except a little cow of the earth.
The girl approached the door and knocked, asking to be let in. The little earth-cow replied, "Certainly, I will not let you in unless you promise to stay with me until the end of your days and never betray me or speak of me." The girl swore to her, and the little earth-cow let her in at once, then said, "Very well! All you are allowed to do is milk me morning and evening. Afterward, you will drink my milk, and I will bring you silk and velvet to your sufficiency. Make beautiful dresses from them as you wish. But remember and be careful not to speak of me! Even if your own sister comes to see you, do not let her in so that I will not be betrayed and no one will know that I am in this place! Otherwise, my life will be lost." " With these words, the little cow left for her meadow and, in the evening, when she returned, she brought the little girl some silk and velvet with which good Marguerite made herself clothes so rich that she could have compared herself to a princess. When they had spent more than a year together in this way, it so happened that the eldest daughter, who had stayed at home and who had contributed to throwing Marguerite, her innocent younger sister, into poverty, became thoughtful and wondered what could have become of her. She began to weep bitterly, and to think of the immense betrayal she had made her sister suffer for no reason. In short, she went home, and wanted to try to find even one small bone of her sister to take home and keep carefully. So one day, early in the morning, she went out into the forest and began to search, and she searched like this, weeping piteously, for so long that she got completely lost in the forest. Now, at any moment, it would be pitch black. Who could be sadder than Annette? She then said to herself that this must be her punishment for what she had done to her sister, and began to weep bitterly and beg God to have pity on her and forgive her. But there was no time to waste in complaints and waiting. So she climbed a very high tree to try to see a house, some kind of house, where she could spend the night so as not to be miserably devoured by wild beasts. And as she looked around her, she saw smoke rising from the little house where her sister was. She then set off and headed towards the house, thinking it must be the hut of a shepherd or a hermit.
When she arrived at the house, she knocked on the door. Her sister asked her shortly after who was there. "Oh," replied Annette, "I am a poor young girl who has lost her way in the forest, and I beg you, for heaven's sake, to let me spend the night with you." Margaret peered through a crack, recognized her treacherous sister, and said, "Really, my dear child, I cannot let you in because it is forbidden to me. If my master returned and saw that I had let a stranger in, he would beat me. That is why you must leave!"
But the poor girl would not be dissuaded, much less driven out. On the contrary, she begged her sister so earnestly, without recognizing her, that she opened the door and let her in. Upon entering, Annette recognized her sister, burst into tears, and began to thank God for allowing her to regain her dignity.
Give her everything she had done to her. Then she kindly asked him to please tell her who lived with her, so that she was so beautifully and richly dressed. Good Marguerite, who was forbidden to say who she lived with, invented and invoked various excuses. Sometimes she said she lived with a wolf, sometimes that she lived with a bear. Annette would not believe any of this and made every effort to get Marguerite, her younger sister, to tell the truth. The little girl, who had a sharp tongue (for all women are accustomed to talking more than they are allowed), finally said to her sister: "I live with a little earth-cow, but be careful not to betray me!" When she heard this, Annette, who had not yet had enough of the betrayal she had committed against her sister, replied: "Very well. Now lead me back to the right road so that I can go home." Margaret hastened to do so. And when good Annette arrived home, she told her mother how she had found Margaret in the house of a little earth-cow, and how sumptuously her sister was dressed. "Very well," replied the mother. "So we will go to the forest next week to bring Margaret and the little earth-cow home with us. We will kill the little cow and eat her." »
The little cow already knew all this very well, and when she returned home late that evening, she said to the little girl, weeping: "Ah! Ah! Darling Margaret, what have you done by letting your treacherous sister in and telling her who you were staying with? And now, look: next week, your cruel mother and sister will go out into the forest to take you and me home with them. They will kill me to eat me, but they will keep you at home, and the life they will make you lead will be even harder than ever." After speaking thus, the little cow assumed such a pitiful expression that the poor girl burst into tears and thought she would die of grief, so bitterly did she regret having let her sister in. The little earth cow, however, consoled her by saying: "Well, my dear child, what's done is done, and there's no going back." So this is what you must do: when the butcher has killed me, stay there and cry! When he asks you what you want, tell him: "I would like to have the tail of my little cow." He will give it to you. When you have it, start crying again and ask him for one of my horns. When you have this one, cry again! When they ask you what you want, say this: "I would like a hoof of my little cow." Once you have it, go and plant my tail in the ground, place it like a horn on it, then place your hoof on the horn and do not stray from it for three days! On the third day, a tree will grow from it. This tree will bear the most beautiful apples ever seen, summer and winter, and you alone will be able to pick them. And thanks to this tree, you will become a great and powerful lady."
When the little cow was killed, Margaret was standing nearby. She asked for all these things, as the little cow had taught her, and they were given to her. So she went to plant them in the ground and, on the third day, a beautiful tree will grow from them. It so happened that a powerful lord was passing by. He was accompanied by his son who had a fever. And when he saw the beautiful apples, the son said, "Sir, father, have some apples brought to me from this tree. I believe that if I ate them, I would regain my health." The lord immediately ordered that apples be brought to him. apple, saying he would give a good price for it.
The eldest daughter approached the tree first and prepared to pick some apples. All the branches then reached up to the sky, so that it was impossible for her to reach a single one. She then called her mother and ordered her to pick some apples and then take them to the lord. But when the wicked woman approached the tree, the branches rose even higher. The lord had observed all this and was greatly astonished. Finally, Margaret approached the tree to pick some apples. The branches then lowered themselves towards her of their own accord and let her pick the apples. This astonished the lord even more and, thinking it was a miracle, he rummaged over this miracle. The good girl then told him everything that had happened because of her mother, her sister, and the little earth cow, from beginning to end. When he heard this, the lord asked the girl if she would go with him. The good girl was delighted. She dug up her tree and sat with her father in the lord's carriage. He welcomed them warmly and did them all the honors, then they left, leaving behind their cunning mother and sister.
Version written in Alsatian dialect, published by Martin Montanus, in The Garden Company (Gartengesellschaft), around 1559. Albert Wesselski, Deustche Märchen vor Grimm, Brünn, München, Wien, Rudolf W. Wohrer Verlag, 1942, pp. 1-10.

Content:
La mère Attchich avait une fille adoptive qu’elle appelait Petite Souillon. La mère Attchich se rendit à l’église avec sa propre fille, mais sans emmener Petite Souillon. À la place, elle lui donna un quart de tonneau de grain, mais la jeune fille le donna aux oiseaux. Ces derniers, reconnaissants, l’emmenèrent à l’église.
