She was about to continue in this vein when Zezolla—that was the young girl's name—said to her: "Forgive me if I interrupt you. I know you love me, so, hush, say no more: teach me what to do, I don't have your knowledge; write, I will sign." "All right, let's go," replied the governess, "listen to me carefully, open your ears wide and you will enjoy a loaf of bread as white as the lilies. As soon as your father leaves, tell your stepmother that you want one of those old clothes that are in the big chest in the wardrobe, to save on the ones you are wearing." She, who desires nothing more than to see you in rags and tatters, will open the chest and say, “Hold the lid a little.” You will hold it, but while she rummages inside, you will drop it suddenly, and that will break her neck. You know that your father would not hesitate to become a counterfeiter to please you; do this, then, when he caresses you as he likes to do, ask him to take me as his wife, and you will become the mistress of my life.” When she had listened to these words, it seemed to Zezolla that each minute lasted a year. She carried out her governess’s advice point by point, then began to pluck the strings of her father’s heart to make him marry her. The prince at first thought it was a joke, but the girl pulled so hard with the flat of the sword that she finally touched the point, and, defeated, he yielded to Zezolla's words and took Carmosina, the housekeeper, as his wife, amidst great rejoicing. Now, while the newlyweds were pirouetting on their own, Zezolla leaned over a balcony of the house. A little dove suddenly landed on the wall and said to him: "When you want something, ask the fairy dove on the island of Sardinia, and you will be granted it at once." For five or six days, the new stepmother cajoled Zezolla with caresses, made her sit at the table in the place of honor, gave her the best morsels, and dressed her in the most beautiful clothes. She forced herself to smile for a while, then she sent everything to the devil and buried the favor she had received in the depths of her memory (ah, how villainous is the misgoverned soul!), and she began to elevate the six daughters she had until then kept hidden. She worked her husband so hard that he became fond of his daughters-in-law and alienated his own child from his heart; so that little by little—what one loses today is missed tomorrow—Zezolla moved from the bedroom to the kitchen, from the canopy to the fireplace, from silk and gold to rags, from the scepter to the spit. And she changed not only her station, but also her name: she was no longer called Zezolla, but the Cat of Ashes.
Now it so happened that the prince had to leave for Sardinia on business. He asked each of his daughters-in-law, 'Mperia Calamita Shiorella Diamante Colommina Pascarella, what they wanted him to bring back for them upon his return: one asked for sumptuous clothes to strut around in, another for hair ornaments, another for cosmetics, another for games to pass the time, another for this, another for that. Finally, almost mockingly, he said to his daughter: "And you, what do you want?" She said: "Nothing, except that you tell the fairy dove about me so that she can ask them to send me something; and if you forget, may you not be able to take a step forward or backward. Remember what I told you, your fate is in your own hands." The prince left, packed his bags in Sardinia, bought everything his daughters-in-law had asked for, and forgot about Zezolla. But when he had embarked and wanted to set sail, the ship could not leave the port, it seemed that a remora was hindering it. The captain of the ship, on the verge of despair, gave in to fatigue, fell asleep and saw that she cannot unanchor from the port? Because the prince who sails with you has broken his promise for his daughter; he has remembered all the others, but not the one who is his own blood." The captain awoke, recounted his dream to the prince, who, confused by his forgetfulness, went to the fairies' cave and, after recommending his daughter to them, asked them to send him something. Then, from the cave, a beautiful young girl emerged - imagine, a real gonfalon - who told him that she thanked this girl for having remembered her and wished him with all her heart to be happy. And, saying these words, she gave the prince a date, a hoe, a small golden bucket and a silk cloth, adding that the first gift should be planted and that the others would be used to care for the plant. The prince, greatly astonished by these gifts, took leave of the fairy and returned to his own country, where, after distributing to his daughters-in-law everything they had asked for, he gave his daughter the young fairy's gift. Zezolla, sweating joy from every pore, planted the date in a pretty pot, and she hoed it and watered it and wiped it morning and evening with the silk cloth, so that in four days the date produced a date palm the size of a woman, and from it came a fairy who said to her: "What do you want?" Zezolla replied that sometimes she wanted to leave the house, but she did not want her sisters to know. The fairy replied: "Whenever you wish, approach the pot and say:
'O my golden date palm,
With the golden hoe I have hoeed you,
With the little golden bucket I have watered you,
With the silken linen I have dried you,
Undress yourself, and dress me!'
When you wish to undress, change the last verse and say: 'Undress me and dress yourself.'"
Now, the day of the feast arrived, and the governess's daughters came out all adorned, dolled up, and pampered: they were nothing but little bows, trinkets, charms and trinkets, trinkets, the perfume of flowers, the scent of roses. Zezolla ran immediately to her pot and, as soon as she spoke the words the fairy had taught her, she saw herself dressed like a queen; Then, perched on a hackney escorted by twelve dapper, gleaming pages, she went where her sisters were going, who drooled with envy before the beauty of this luminous dove. Fate would have it that the king arrived in these places and that, upon discovering the incredible beauty of Zezolla, he remained under the spell and ordered his most faithful servant to inquire who this marvel of marvels was and where she lived. Without losing a moment, the servant followed her; but she saw his plot and threw him a handful of gold coins that she had obtained for this purpose from the date palm. Noticing the pennies, the servant forgot to follow the hackneyed girl to fill his pockets, and Zezolla bounded straight back to her house, where she undressed as the fairy had taught her, before her ugly sisters arrived and told her, at length and in detail, to make her boil with envy, all the beautiful things they had seen. Meanwhile, the servant returned to the king and told him the story of the golden crowns. The king, suddenly inflamed by all the thunderbolts of hell, told him that for four miserable crowns, he had sacrificed his own pleasure, and that he must at all costs, at the next festival, try to find out who this beautiful darling was and where this beautiful bird nested.
Another festival came; and the sisters went there, all dressed up and elegant, abandoning poor Zezolla in her ashes. She immediately ran to her date palm, recited the magic words, and there came out a whole troop of young ladies: some carrying a mirror, some a flask of pumpkin water, some a curling iron, some brandishing the powder puff, some brooches, some dresses, some the diadem, some necklaces; after having made her as beautiful as a sun, they placed her in a carriage drawn by six horses, escorted by attendants and pages in livery, and she presented herself at the feast, as the first time, so resplendent that she left the minds of her sisters even more astonished and the heart of the king even more inflamed. When she left, the servant resumed his tailing, and, so that he would not join her, she threw him a handful of pearls and jewels. The good man stopped to give them a hug, for it was not necessary to fly home and undress, like the first time. The servant returned, all sheepish, to the king, who said to him: "By the Manes of my dear departed, if you don't find her, you'll see what I'm made of, and you'll receive as many slaps on the ass as you have hairs on your chin." A third feast came, and once her sisters had left, Zezolla went to her date palm, sang the magic song, was dressed superbly, and installed in a golden carriage, with so many servants that she looked like a surprised courtesan at the promenade and surrounded by the men-at-arms. After thumbing her nose at her sisters, she left, and this time the servant tied himself firmly to her carriage. Seeing that he was sticking to her heels, she shouted: "Whip, coachman!" And the carriage began to speed off, and the race was so frantic that Zezolla lost one of her mules, the cutest thing in the world. The servant, who had not managed to reach this impetuous carriage, picked up the mule, carried it to the king and told him what had happened. The king, with the mule in his hands, exclaimed: "If the foundations are so pretty, what will the house be like? O marvelous candlestick where rested the candle that consumes me! Marvelous tripod of the marvelous cauldron where my life boils! Marvelous stopper attached to the line with which Love fished my soul! Let me embrace you and hold you! If I cannot reach the plant, at least I will adore the roots! If I cannot see the capitals, at least I will kiss the bases! You were the cippus of a completely white foot, now you are the laces of a completely black heart; you raised the one span of the one who tyrannizes my life, now raise the sweetness of this life by that much, while I look at you and possess you." Thus he moans, then he calls his secretary, summons his herald, and tara ta ta, he publishes a ban, inviting all the women of the region to a public festival and a banquet that he has decided to give. On the appointed day, by my faith! what a feast, what a feast they do not see! Where did all these poupelins and pretty doughnuts, all these stews and paupiettes, all these macaroni and ravioli come from? Enough to feed an entire squadron! The women arrived, all the women, noble and common, rich and poor, young and old, beautiful and ugly, and when they had cackled, the king raised his glass and had all his guests try on the mule, one after the other, to see who it would fit perfectly on, hoping that it would thus reveal to him the secret he wanted to uncover. But, finding no foot that could fit into this pretty sheath, he began to despair.
However, he silenced his party and called out: "Come back tomorrow and do penance with me again; but if you love me, do not forget any woman at home, whoever she may be." The prince said: "I have a daughter, but she is always in the ashes of the fireplace, she is a poor, worthless beggar, who does not deserve to sit at your table." The king said: "Let her be first on the list, such is my good pleasure." They all took their leave, and the next day, everyone returned, and with the daughters of Carmosina there was also Zezolla. Hardly had the king seen her than he felt that she was the object of all his desires, but he showed nothing of it. When everyone had finished working their jaws, they began the test of the mule; and as soon as Zezolla brought her foot near, the mule sprang of its own accord upon that pretty coconut of Cupid, as iron springs toward the magnet. The king immediately ran to hug Zezolla, then had her sit under the royal canopy, crowned her, and ordered that she be saluted and honored as a queen. At this sight, which tore their hearts and made their stomachs turn, the sisters, suffocating with rage, returned without a word to their mother's house and were forced to admit, willingly or unwillingly, that "it is a fool who wants to joust with the stars."

Content:
Mais le fils du roi ouvrit la porte et la vit si jolie, avec sa robe rouge et son soulier en or, qu'il dit :
- Voici ma fiancée, celle qui doit être mon épouse. On lui fit essayer le soulier, et lui allait parfaitement. Il lui dit qu'il allait la laisser là tandis qu'il allait chercher son cortège pour la ramener au palais.
Dès qu’il fut parti, la mère et la fille dirent:
- Nous allons la tuer.
Elles l'emmenèrent dans un champ, l'allongèrent sur une pierre, la tuèrent et lui arrachèrent la langue et les yeux. Un berger passa par là, qui criait à ses brebis: - Allez, brebis! Allez, brebis!
Il trouva la jeune fille en sang, la releva et l'emmena avec lui dans la grotte dans laquelle il vivait avec sa femme. Ils là soignèrent, nettoyèrent ses blessures, lui donnèrent à boire et elle se ranima. La jeune fille mit alors la main dans sa poche, en sortit beaucoup d'argent et le donna au berger. Elle se mit alors à rire, il tomba des roses et elle lui dit par signes d’aller les vendre, mais qu’il ne les vende que contre une langue.
Il partit vendre les fleurs et passa par la maison de la mauvaise marâtre en vantant ses roses :
- Qui achète mes roses ? Qui achète mes roses ?
Comme ce n'était pas la saison, la fille dit à sa mère: - Mère achète des roses, personne n'en à en ce moment !
Elles allèrent voir les roses et les trouvèrent si belles que la mère décida d'en acheter. Quand elle lui demanda combien il en voulait, l'homme répondit:
- Madam, je ne demande pas d'argent pour ces roses, je ne vends que contre une langue.
- Ah, mon dieu, nous n'allons pas nous arracher la langue pour vous la donner ! Ou prendrions-nous une langue ?
- Pourquoi ne pas lui donner celle de la Souillon, puisque nous l'avons à la maison ? lui demanda sa fille.
— Non ma fille, je ne veux pas qu’elle ressuscite, lui répondit la mère.
— Comment le pourrait-elle, puisqu'elle est morte! lui répondit la fille.
Elles lui donnèrent donc la langue de la Souillon et il l’emporta dans les pâturages.
En arrivant, il la donna à la jeune fille, elle prit la langue et dit à la baguette aux sept vertus:
— Baguette aux sept vertus, par la grâce que tu possèdes et celle que Dieu t’a donnée, remets-moi ma langue comme avant.
Sa langue fut comme avant et elle parla. Puis elle se coiffa et il tomba des perles. Elle les ramassa, les donna au berger pour qu'il aille les vendre, mais uniquement contre des yeux. Le berger sortit et passa devant la maison de la marâtre en vantant ses perles: — Qui m’achète mes perles ? Qui m’achète mes perles ? Elles vinrent voir les perles et les trouvèrent si belles, que la fille dit à sa mère :
— Ah, mère, comme elles sont jolies ! Achète-moi ces perles pour me faire faire un collier.
La femme demanda au berger combien il en voulait et il lui répondit :
— Madame, je ne les vends pas contre de l’argent, mais contre des yeux.
— Mais monsieur, comment pourrions-nous nous arracher les yeux pour vous les donner en échange des perles ? lui demanda la femme.
— Nous pourrions lui donner les yeux de la Souillon, nous lesavons à la maison, lui dit sa fille.
— Attention, cela peut avoir des conséquences, lui dit la mère.
— Quelles conséquences cela aurait-il, puisqu'elle est morte! lui répondit la fille.
Elles donnèrent donc les yeux de la jeune fille et le berger les rapporta à la grotte. La jeune fille prit sa baguette
magique aux sept vertus et lui demanda de lui remettre ses yeux comme avant, ce qu'elle fit.
Une fois qu'Étoile d’Or fut redevenue comme avant, elle écrivit une lettre au roi et la lui fit porter par le berger en lui expliquant son aventure et en lui demandant de venir la chercher. Le roi fut très surpris parce que l’autre lui avait raconté que la jeune fille s’était enfuie toute seule pour courir le monde afin de ne pas l’épouser. Le roi rassembla immédiatement les gens du palais et alla la chercher. Ils la ramenèrent au palais, préparèrent les noces etse marièrent. Quand ils furent mariés, le roi demanda à son épouse, Étoile d'Or, quel châtiment elle voulait faire donner à la marâtre et à sa fille. Elle lui dit qu’elle n’en souhaitait aucun, qu’elle leur pardonnait tout. Le roi ordonna alors de les pendre et de jeter leurs corps dans une marmite d’huile bouillante.
Et le conte s’acheva avec du pain et des piments, et que celui qui n’y croit pas aille se faire voir.
Grenade
English:
But the king's son opened the door and saw her so pretty, in her red dress and gold shoe, that he said, "This is my fiancée, the one who is to be my wife." They had him try on the shoe, and it fitted perfectly. He told her he would leave her there while he went to find his entourage to take her back to the palace.
As soon as he left, the mother and daughter said, "We are going to kill her." They took her to a field, laid her on a rock, killed her, and gouged out her tongue and eyes. A shepherd passed by, shouting to his sheep, "Go, sheep! Go, sheep!" He found the girl bleeding, picked her up, and took her with him to the cave where he lived with his wife. There they nursed her, cleaned her wounds, and gave her something to drink, and she revived. The young girl then reached into her pocket, took out a lot of money, and gave it to the shepherd. She began to laugh, roses fell out, and she signaled to him to go and sell them, but he was only to sell them for a tongue.
He went to sell the flowers and passed by the wicked stepmother's house, boasting about her roses:
"Who's buying my roses? Who's buying my roses?"
Since it wasn't the season, the girl said to her mother: "Mother, buy roses, no one has any at this time!"
They went to see the roses and found them so beautiful that the mother decided to buy some. When she asked him how many he wanted, the man replied:
"Madam, I'm not asking for money for these roses, I'm only selling them for a tongue."
"Oh, my God, we're not going to tear out our tongues to give them to you! Or would we take a tongue?" "Why not give him the Slut's tongue, since we have it at home?" his daughter asked.
"No, my daughter, I don't want her to be resurrected," her mother replied.
"How could she, since she's dead!" the daughter replied.
So they gave him the Slut's tongue, and he took it to the pastures.
When he arrived, he gave it to the girl. She took the tongue and said to the wand of seven virtues:
"Wand of seven virtues, by the grace you possess and that which God has given you, restore my tongue to its former state."
Her tongue remained as it was before, and she spoke. Then she combed her hair, and pearls fell out. She picked them up and gave them to the shepherd to sell, but only for eyeballs. The shepherd went out and passed in front of the stepmother's house, boasting of his pearls: "Who buys my pearls? Who buys my pearls?" They came to see the pearls and found them so beautiful that the daughter said to her mother:
"Ah, mother, how pretty they are! Buy me these pearls to make a necklace for me."
The woman asked the shepherd how many he wanted, and he replied:
"Madam, I'm not selling them for money, but for eyes."
"But sir, how could we tear out our eyes to give them to you in exchange for the pearls?" the woman asked him.
"We could give him the Slut's eyes; we have them at home," her daughter told her.
"Be careful, that could have consequences," the mother told her.
"What consequences would that have, since she's dead?" the daughter replied.
So they gave the girl's eyes, and the shepherd brought them back to the cave. The girl took her magic wand with seven virtues and asked him to restore her eyes to their former state, which she did. Once Goldstar was back to her old self, she wrote a letter to the king and had the shepherd deliver it to him, explaining her adventure and asking him to come and get her. The king was very surprised because the other had told him that the young girl had run away alone to travel the world so as not to marry him. The king immediately gathered the people from the palace and went to get her. They brought her back to the palace, prepared the wedding, and were married. When they were married, the king asked his wife, Goldstar, what punishment she wanted for the stepmother and her daughter. She told him that she wanted none, that she forgave them everything. The king then ordered them to be hanged and their bodies thrown into a pot of boiling oil.
And the story ended with bread and peppers, and anyone who doesn't believe it should go to hell.
Grenade

Content:
Thibaud, prince de Salerne, veut épouser sa fille Doralice. Celles-ci, poursuivie par son père, arrive en Angleterre, où Genese l'épouse : ils ont deux enfants, qui seront mis à mort par Thibaud, ce dont par la suite Genese lire vengeance.
Je pense qu'il n’est aucun d’entre vous qui n’ait éprouvé par expérience la puissance de l'Amour et les aiguillons de notre chair corruptible. L'Amour, tel un puissant seigneur, conduit et gouverne son empire sans épée, mais de son seul vouloir, comme vous pourrez l'entendre par la fable que je me propose maintenant de vous raconter. Vous devez donc savoir, gracieuses dames, que Thibaud, prince de Salerne, comme je l’ai souvent entendu dire par nos aînés, eut pour femme une demoiselle gentille et avisée, de bon lignage, dont il eut une fille qui en beauté et bonnes manières l’emportait sur toutes les autres dames de Salerne. Mais il eût mieux valu à Thibaud de ne l'avoir jamais eue, car il ne lui serait pas advenu ce qu’il lui advint. Lorsque sa femme, jeune mais pleine de sens, fut près de mourir, elle pria son mari, qu’elle aimait très affectueusement, de ne prendre jamais d'autre épouse si l'anneau qu’elle portait n'allait au doigt de celle qu'il prendrait pour sa seconde femme. Le prince, qui n'aimait pas moins sa femme qu’elle ne l’aimait, jura d'observer ses volontés. Après que cette dame fut allée de vie à trépas, et qu'elle fut honorablement ensevelie, Thibaud eut envie de se remarier ; mais, se souvenant de la promesse faite à son épouse, il ne voulut point rompre son serment. Le bruit
était déjà semé partout que Thibaud voulait se remarier, et cette nouvelle vint aux oreilles de beaucoup de pucelles qui en biens et en vertu ne lui étaient point inférieures. Mais lui, qui désirait avant tout respecter la volonté de la morte, voulut d’abord essayer l'anneau de sa femme à toutes celles qui lui étaient offertes en mariage, et comme il n’en trouvait aucune à qui l’anneau allait, car il était ou trop étroit ou trop large, il leur donna finalement congé à toutes, sans dire autre chose. Or, un jour que la fille de Thibaud, nommée Doralice, dînait avec son père, elle vit sur la table l'anneau de sa mère, et se le mit au doigt. Se tournant vers son père, elle lui dit : « Voyez, mon père, comment l’anneau de ma mère me va bien. » À quoi Thibaud acquiesça.
Mais il ne fut guère de temps qu’entra au cœur de Thibaud le projet étrange et diabolique de prendre pour femme sa fille Doralice ; et il demeura longuement entre oui et non. À la fin, succombant à cette pensée diabolique et embrasé par la beauté de sa fille, il l’appela auprès de lui et lui dit : « Doralice, ta mère, juste avant de mourir, me pria instamment de ne prendre pour femme que celle à qui irait l’anneau qu’elle portait au doigt lorsqu’elle vivait. Alors je lui jurai d’agir selon sa volonté. Cependant, après avoir passé l’anneau de ta mère à beaucoup de pucelles, j'ai trouvé qu’il n’allait à aucune autre que toi; aussi ai-je décidé de te prendre pour femme, car j’accomplirai ainsi mon désir et ne violerai point la promesse faite à ta mère. » La fille, qui n’était pas moins honnête que belle, apprenant la malheureuse intention de son mauvais père, se troubla fort. Devant cette abominable proposition, de peur de le mettre en colère, elle ne voulut rien répondre pour l'instant, mais le quitta en affectant un air joyeux. Elle n’avait de meilleure personne à qui se fier que sa nourrice, et recourut à elle sans détour, comme à la fontaine de son salut, pour avoir son conseil. Quand elle eut appris l’exécrable désir d’un père rempli d’iniquité et qu’elle eut reconnu la constante et ferme intention de la jeune fille, prête à endurer le plus grand
rice la réconforta, lui promettant faveur et aide, afin que sa virginité ne fût point souillée avec son déshonneur.
Cependant la nourrice, qui songeait sans cesse à trouver un remède contre un tel péril, faisait projet sur projet et ne trouvait aucun moyen pour assurer la protection de Doralice : car si elle trouvait bon de la faire fuir et de l’éloigner de son père, elle n’en craignait pas moins la perspicacité de Thibaud, pensant bien qu'il la rattraperait et la mettrait à mort. Alors que cette fidèle nourrice retournait ces pensées, il lui vint une nouvelle idée que je vais vous exposer. Il y avait en la chambre de sa défunte mère une belle armoire magnifiquement ouvragée, où la fille tenait ses riches vêtements et ses bijoux, et personne ne pouvait l’ouvrir, sinon cette sage nourrice. Celle-ci ôta en cachette toutes les robes et les bijoux qui étaient dedans, et mit en cette armoire une certaine liqueur douée d’une telle vertu que quiconque en prenait une cuillerée, rien qu'un tout petit peu, pouvait vivre longtemps sans aucune autre nourriture. Ayant appelé Doralice, elle l’enferma dans l’armoire et lui conseilla d’y demeurer jusqu’à ce que Dieu lui envoyât un sort meilleur, et que son père renonçât à son dessein bestial. La fille, obéissant à sa bonne nourrice, fit tout ce qu’elle lui proposa. Le père, qui persévérait dans sa maudite intention sans jamais réfréner l’élan de son désir, demanda par plusieurs fois des nouvelles de sa fille, et, ne la de fureur qu'il menaça de la faire mourir ignominieusement. Peu de jours après, il advint que Thibaud entra, un matin, sur le lever du soleil, dans la chambre où était cette armoire. Posant le regard sur elle et ne pouvant la souffrir, il ordonna de l'ôter de là, de l'emporter ailleurs, et de la vendre afain de délivrer ses yeux de cet objet fâcheux. Les serviteurs, prompts à obéir aux ordres de leur maître, la prirent aussitôt sur leurs épaules, et l'emportèrent au marché. Il advint qu'à ce moment arriva en ce lieu un bon et riche marchand génois. Celui-ci, ayant contemplé cette armoire si magnifiquement ouvragée, en fut ravi, et décida de ne la point laisser passer, quoi qu'elle lui coûtât. Il s'approcha du serviteur qui avait
charge de la vendre, fit affaire avec lui, puis la fit aussitôt charger sur le dos d’un portefaix et mener en son navire. La nourrice, qui avait tout vu, s’en trouva contente, bien qu’elle fût fort marrie d’avoir perdu sa fille; toutefois elle trouva à se consoler dans la pensée que, quand surviennent deux grands maux, il faut toujours éviter le pire.
Le marchand, ayant quitté Salerne avec son armoire et autres riches marchandises, parvint en l'île de Bretagne, aujourd’hui appelée Angleterre, et débarqua en un lieu où s’étendait une vaste plaine. Là il aperçut Genese, qui venait d’être sacré roi d'Angleterre, courant à bride abattue le long de la plage. Il poursuivait une superbe biche qui par crainte se jeta à la mer. Le roi, se trouvant las, et fâché d’avoir si longuement couru, se reposait, et, dès qu’il vit le navire, il demanda à boire au capitaine. Celui-ci, feignant de ne pas le reconnaître, le reçut aimablement, en lui faisant le plus bel accueil qu'il était possible, et parvint à le faire monter sur le navire. À peine le roi eut-il vu la belle armoire richement ouvragée, qu’il eut grand désir de l’avoir, et de fait il demanda au capitaine du navire combien il l’estimait ; on lui répondit qu’elle valait fort cher. Le roi, ravi d’un objet si précieux, ne s'en alla qu'après être convenu d’un prix avec le marchand, puis, s’étant fait remettre assez d’argent pour le satisfaire, il prit congé de lui, fit porter le meuble tout droit au palais, et mettre en sa chambre.
Or, Genese, qui était fort jeune, n’avait point encore pris femme, et prenait son plaisir à aller tous les jours, de grand matin, à la chasse. Cependant Doralice, fille de Thibaud, cachée dans l’armoire qu’on avait dressée dans la chambre de Genese, entendait tout ce qui s’y faisait, et, pensant aux dangers passés, elle commença à espérer quelque bonne fortune. Et, dès que le roi avait quitté sa chambre pour aller chasser selon son habitude, la jeune fille sortait de l’armoire, arrangeait la chambre avec art et subtilité, la nettoyait, dressait le lit, et en ajustait les tentures en les faisant reposer sur une couette piquée de grosses perles avec deux coussins merveilleusement brodés. Outre cela, la belle semait sur le lit des
roses, des violettes et d’autres fleurs odoriférantes mêlées de précieux parfums, qui sentaient fort bon et confortaient le cerveau. Cette jeune dame procéda ainsi maintes fois sans être vue de personne. Cela donnait un merveilleux contentement au roi Genese : car, quand il venait de la chasse et qu’il entrait dans la chambre, il croyait être au milieu de toutes les drogues et épices du Levant. Un jour le roi voulut savoir de sa mère et des demoiselles quelle était celle, si gentille et si gracieuse, qui lui arrangeait si magnifiquement sa chambre. On lui répondit qu’on n’en savait rien, parce que, quand on allait ranger la chambre, on trouvait ordinairement le lit couvert de roses, de violettes et de parfums odoriférants. Le roi, entendant de telles merveilles, résolut de savoir exactement d’où cela venait, et feignit un matin d'aller à un château situé à dix lieues de la ville ; puis il se cacha dans la chambre, regardant par une fente, et attendant ce qui pourrait arriver. Il ne se passa pas longtemps que Doralice, plus claire que le soleil, ne sortît de son armoire ; elle se mit à nettoyer la chambre, dresser les tapis, refaire le lit et s'occuper de tout, comme elle avait fait les jours précédents. Lorsque la gentille pucelle eut rempli ce digne et louable service, elle se voulut retirer en son armoire; mais le roi, qui avait attentivement pris garde à tout, vint la surprendre et la prit par la main, et, la voyant belle et fraîche comme un lys, lui demanda qui elle était. La jeune fille lui répondit qu’elle était fille d’un prince, dont elle ne pouvait se rappeler le nom, parce qu’il y avait déjà trop longtemps qu'elle était cachée dans l’armoire, mais elle ne voulut Pas dire pourquoi. Le roi entendit tout cela, puis, avec le consentement de sa mère, la prit pour femme, et engendra avec elle deux enfants.
Cependant Thibaud persévérait dans son perfide et exécrable désir, et, comme il ne trouvait point sa fille qu'il avait longtemps cherchée et recherchée, il en vint à penser qu'elle pourrait bien être dans cette armoire qu’il avait vendue. Aussi, en proie au dépit et à la colère, résolut-il d’aller chercher par le monde pour voir s’il ne la pourrait point trouver. Il se vêtit en marchand, prit force bijoux et autres ouvrages
d’or, et partit ainsi déguisé de Salerne. Ayant parcouru divers pays, il rencontra un jour celui qui l’avait achetée le premier, et lui demanda s’il l’avait bien revendue et entre les mains de qui elle était tombée. L'autre marchand lui répondit qu'il l'avait vendue au roi d'Angleterre et qu’il y avait doublé son gain. À cette nouvelle, Thibaud se réjouit et prit son chemin vers l’Angleterre. Dès qu'il fut entré dans la ville où se tenait le roi, il disposa contre la muraille du palais bijoux et autres objets, parmi lesquels figuraient des quenouilles et des fuseaux, et se mit à crier : « Allons, mesdames, quenouilles et fuseaux ! » Alors, l’une des demoiselles se mit à la fenêtre, et, voyant le marchand avec ses trésors, courut aussitôt vers la reine, et lui dit qu’il y avait en la rue un marchand qui vendait des quenouilles et des fuseaux d’or, les plus beaux et les plus riches que l'on vît jamais. La reine le fit venir au palais. Il monta les escaliers et entra dans la salle, mais elle ne le reconnut point, car elle ne pensait plus à son père. Or, le marchand, lui, reconnut fort bien sa fille. La reine donc, ayant vu ces quenouilles et ces fuseaux splendides, demanda au marchand combien selon lui ils valaient. « Cher, dit-il; mais, si Votre Altesse veut bien que je couche une nuit en la chambre de vos deux enfants, je vous ferai présent de toute ma marchandise. » La dame, simple et pure, qui ne se serait jamais doutée de la maudite entreprise de ce marchand, persuadée par ses demoiselles, y consentit. Mais, avant que les serviteurs l’eussent mené reposer, les demoiselles décidèrent de lui donner un breuvage pour le faire dormir. Quand la nuit fut venue, le marchand feignit d’être las. L'une des demoiselles le conduisit dans la chambre des enfants du roi, où on avait dressé un lit magnifique, et, avant qu’on l'y fît entrer, la demoiselle lui dit : « Mon père, n’avez-vous point soif ? — Oui, ma fille. » Elle prit le verre, qui semblait d’argent, et le lui présenta; mais lui, qui était malin et rusé, feignit de boire tout le vin, alors qu’il le versait petit à petit sur ses vêtements, puis il s en alla reposer.
Or, il y avait, dans la chambre des enfants, une petite porte par laquelle on pouvait aller dans la chambre de la reine.
Quand vint l’heure de minuit, il y entra secrètement, et, s'approchant du lit, lui prit un petit couteau, qu'elle portait au côté et qu’il avait déjà remarqué la veille. Il s’approcha du berceau où étaient les enfants, les tua tous deux, puis remit le couteau tout sanglant dans son étui. Il ouvrit une fenêtre, descendit à terre à l’aide d’une corde à nœuds, et de grand matin, sur le point du jour, alla chez un barbier faire raser sa longue barbe, de peur d’être reconnu. Il revêtit de nouveaux habits, plus larges et plus longs, et s’en alla par la ville.
Cependant les nourrices, encore endormies, se levèrent à l'heure habituelle pour allaiter les enfants, mais lorsqu'elles regardèrent dans les berceaux, elles trouvèrent les enfants tués. Aussi se mirent-elles à crier et à pleurer en s’arrachant les cheveux, rompant leurs vêtements par devant et découvrant leurs poitrines. La triste nouvelle fut aussitôt transmise au roi et à la reine. Ils se levèrent tout déchaussés, accoururent à ce triste spectacle, et, quand ils virent leurs enfants morts, se mirent à pleurer amèrement.
Déjà dans toute la ville s'était répandu le bruit de ce meurtre, et aussi que venait d’arriver un astrologue fameux, qui savait les choses et prédisait l'avenir d’après le cours des étoiles. Comme sa renommée était parvenue aux oreilles du roi, celui-ci le fit appeler et lui demanda s’il ne pouvait point par son art découvrir qui avait tué les enfants. L'astrologue répondit que oui, et, s’approchant de l'oreille du roi, lui dit tout bas : « Sire, ordonnez à tous ceux qui, en votre cour, portent un couteau à leur côté, de venir se présenter devant vous; celui qui sera trouvé en possession du couteau encore sanglant sera le vrai meurtrier de vos enfants. » Alors tous les courtisans, sur son ordre, comparurent devant lui, et de ses soigneusement si leurs couteaux n'étaient point tachés de sang; et, comme il n'en trouva aucun qui fût souillé, il s'en retourna vers l'astrologue, il lui raconta ce qu'il avait fait et qu'il avait fouillé tout le monde, hormis sa mère et la reine. « Sire, répondit l'astrologue, chercher bien et n'ayez d'égard pour personne, vous trouverez à coup sûr le criminel. » Le roi
fouilla sa mère, mais ne trouva aucun indice; finalement, il appela la reine, lui prit l’étui qu’elle portait au côté et trouva le couteau tout souillé de sang. Alors, pris de rage, le roi, devant cette preuve évidente, se tourna vers son épouse et lui dit : « Ah! femme cruelle et méchante, ennemie de ton propre sang, perfide envers tes propres enfants! Comment as-tu pu jamais avoir le courage de souiller tes mains avec le sang innocent de ces pauvres petits ? Je jure devant Dieu que tu porteras la pénitence d’un si grand forfait. » Et, bien que le roi fût enflammé de courroux et de dépit et désirât se venger surle-champ en la faisant mourir ignominieusement, toutefois, afin qu’elle souffrît plus longtemps, il lui vint une nouvelle idée : il donna l’ordre de déshabiller la reine, de l’ensevelir en terre toute nue jusqu'à la gorge, et de la nourrir de mets exquis, afin que la vermine lui dévorât les chairs, et qu’elle endurât ainsi un plus dur et plus long supplice. La reine, qui par le passé avait supporté bien d’autres misères et se savait imnocente, prit la mort en patience. Quand le bon astrologue, qui n'était autre que son père, apprit que la reine, jugée coupable, avait été condamnée à une mort horrible, il se réjouit fort, et, prenant congé du roi, quitta l’Angleterre en grand contentement; et, dès qu’il fut secrètement arrivé en son palais, il raconta à la nourrice tout ce qu'il lui était arrivé, et comment sa fille avait été condamnée. La nourrice se montra réjouie, mais, en son for intérieur, elle se trouvait très fâchée. Prise de pitié pour sa pauvre fille, et animée par le tendre amour qu'elle lui portait, elle partit un jour, de grand matin, de Salerne, et chevaucha jour et nuit jusqu’au royaume d'Angleterre. Elle monta les marches du palais et trouva le roi qui donnait audience à tous en une vaste salle. S’agenouillant à ses pieds, elle lui demanda une audience secrète pour une affaire concernant l’honneur de sa couronne. Le roi la prit en ses bras et la fit lever, et, lui donnant la main, fit se retirer l’assistance et s’assit tout seul avec elle. La nourrice, fort bien instruite des choses passées, lui dit respectueusement : « Vous devez savoir, Sire, que Doralice, votre femme et ma fille (non pas que je l’aie portée dans ce misérable ventre, mais parce
que je l'ai allaitée et nourrie avec ces mamelles), est innocente du crime qui lui est imputé à tort, et pour lequel elle est condamnée à une mort cruelle. Et quand vous aurez entendu le nom du meurtrier impie, et touché du doigt la raison qui l’a poussé à tuer vos enfants, je suis certaine que vous serez saisi de pitié, et que vous la délivrerez aussitôt de ce si terrible supplice. Mais si vous trouvez que je mens d’un seul mot, je m'offre de subir le même châtiment que la reine. » Et du début à la fin, elle lui raconta point par point tout ce qui était arrivé. Le roi ajouta foi à ces paroles, et ordonna que la reine, qui était plus morte que vive, fût ôtée de la sépulture. Il la fit soigner en grande diligence, si bien qu'elle revint en peu de temps à la santé. Ensuite le roi fit de grands préparatifs par tout son royaume, assembla une grosse armée qu’il envoya à Salerne, et l’on eut tôt fait de conquérir la ville : Thibaud fut pris, et pieds et poings liés fut emmené prisonnier en Angleterre. Le roi, voulant avoir plus grande assurance de sa faute, procéda contre lui avec rigueur, et le fit mettre à la question, où il confessa point par point tout ce qui était arrivé. Le lendemain, il fut mené par toute la ville sur un chariot tiré par quatre chevaux, et fut tenaillé, puis mis en quaire quartiers, comme Ganelon, et ses membres jetés aux chiens. Voilà comment le méchant et abominable Thibaud finit misérablement sa vie, et le roi et la reine Doralice vécurent encore longuement en grande félicité, laissant après leur mort de beaux enfants, qui leur succédèrent sur le trône.
Giovan Francesco Straparola, Les Nuits facétieuses, Paris, José Corti, 1999, p. 48-58 (Première Nuit, Fable IV).
English:
Thibaud, Prince of Salerno, wants to marry his daughter Doralice. Pursued by her father, she arrives in England, where Genesius marries her. They have two children, who will be put to death by Thibaud, for which Genesius will later seek revenge.
I believe there is no one among you who has not experienced firsthand the power of Love and the stings of our corruptible flesh. Love, like a mighty lord, leads and governs his empire without a sword, but by his own will, as you will be able to understand from the fable I now propose to tell you. You must therefore know, gracious ladies, that Thibaud, Prince of Salerno, as I have often heard our elders say, took as his wife a kind and wise young lady of good lineage, from whom he had a daughter who, in beauty and good manners, surpassed all the other ladies of Salerno. But it would have been better for Theobald to have never had her, for what happened to him would not have happened to him. When his wife, young but full of sense, was about to die, she begged her husband, whom she loved very affectionately, never to take another wife unless the ring she wore fitted the finger of the one he would take for his second wife. The prince, who loved his wife no less than she loved him, swore to observe her wishes. After this lady had passed away and was honorably buried, Theobald longed to remarry; but, remembering the promise he had made to his wife, he did not want to break his oath. The rumor
had already spread everywhere that Theobald wanted to remarry, and this news reached the ears of many maidens who were not inferior to him in wealth and virtue. But he, who wished above all to respect the dead woman's wishes, first wanted to try his wife's ring on all those who were offered to him in marriage, and since he found none to whom the ring suited, for it was either too narrow or too wide, he finally gave them all leave, without saying anything else. Now, one day when Thibaud's daughter, named Doralice, was dining with her father, she saw her mother's ring on the table and put it on her finger. Turning to her father, she said, "See, father, how well my mother's ring suits me." To which Thibaud agreed.
But it was not long before the strange and diabolical plan of taking his daughter Doralice as his wife entered Thibaud's heart; and he remained for a long time between yes and no. At last, succumbing to this diabolical thought and inflamed by the beauty of his daughter, he called her to him and said to her: "Doralice, your mother, just before she died, earnestly begged me to take as my wife only the one who would wear the ring that she wore on her finger when she was alive. Then I swore to her that I would do as she wished. However, after having given your mother's ring to many maidens, I found that it suited no one but you; therefore I have decided to take you as my wife, for I will thus fulfill my desire and not violate the promise made to your mother." The daughter, who was no less honest than beautiful, learning of her wicked father's unfortunate intention, was greatly troubled. Before this abominable proposal, for fear of angering him, she would not reply for the moment, but left him with an air of joy. She had no one better to trust than her nurse, and she turned to her without hesitation, as to the fountain of her salvation, for her advice. When she learned of the execrable desire of a father filled with iniquity and recognized the young girl's constant and firm intention, ready to endure the greatest hardship, she comforted her, promising her favor and help, so that her virginity would not be sullied with her dishonor. Meanwhile, the nurse, who was constantly thinking of finding a remedy against such peril, made plan after plan and found no way to ensure Doralice's protection: for if she thought it good to make her flee and separate her from her father, she nonetheless feared the perspicacity of Thibaud, believing that he would catch her and put her to death. While this faithful nurse was pondering these thoughts, a new idea came to her, which I will present to you. There was in her dead mother's room a beautiful wardrobe, magnificently wrought, where the girl kept her rich clothes and jewels, and no one could open it except this wise nurse. She secretly took off all the dresses and jewels that were inside, and put in this wardrobe a certain liquor endowed with such virtue that whoever took a spoonful of it, even a tiny bit, could live a long time without any other food. Having called Doralice, she locked her in the wardrobe and advised her to remain there until God sent her a better fate, and her father renounced his bestial design. The girl, obeying her good nurse, did everything and that she proposed to him. The father, who persisted in his cursed intention without ever restraining the impulse of his desire, asked several times for news of his daughter, and, so furious, he threatened to have her put to death ignominiously. A few days later, it happened that Thibaud entered, one morning, at sunrise, into the room where this wardrobe was. Setting his gaze on it and unable to bear it, he ordered it to be removed from there, taken elsewhere, and sold in order to free his eyes from this unpleasant object. The servants, quick to obey their master's orders, immediately took it on their shoulders, and carried it to the market. It happened that at that moment a good and rich Genoese merchant arrived in this place. The latter, having contemplated this magnificently crafted wardrobe, was delighted and decided not to let it pass him by, whatever it cost him. He approached the servant who was responsible for selling it, made a deal with him, and then immediately had it loaded onto the back of a porter and taken to his ship. The nurse, who had seen everything, was pleased, although she was very sorry to have lost her daughter; however, she found comfort in the thought that when two great evils occur, one must always avoid the worst. The merchant, having left Salerno with his wardrobe and other rich merchandise, arrived at the island of Britain, now called England, and disembarked at a place where a vast plain stretched out. There he saw Genesius, who had just been crowned king of England, running at full speed along the beach. He was chasing a magnificent doe, which, out of fear, threw itself into the sea. The king, feeling tired and angry at having run for so long, was resting, and as soon as he saw the ship, he asked the captain for a drink. The latter, pretending not to recognize him, received him kindly, giving him the most welcoming possible, and managed to get him on board the ship. No sooner had the king seen the beautiful, richly crafted armoire than he greatly desired to have it, and in fact he asked the ship's captain how much he valued it; he was told that it was worth a great deal. The king, delighted with such a precious object, left only after agreeing on a price with the merchant, then, having been given enough money to satisfy him, he took his leave of him, had the piece of furniture taken straight to the palace, and placed in his room. Now, Genese, who was very young, had not yet taken a wife, and took pleasure in going hunting every day early in the morning. Meanwhile, Doralice, daughter of Thibaud, hidden in the wardrobe that had been set up in Genese's room, heard everything that was done there, and, thinking of the past dangers, she began to hope for some good fortune. And, as soon as the king had left his room to go hunting as was his custom, the young girl came out of the wardrobe, arranged the room with art and subtlety, cleaned it, made the bed, and adjusted the hangings by placing them on a quilt studded with large pearls with two marvelously embroidered cushions. In addition, the beauty scattered roses, violets, and other fragrant flowers mixed with precious perfumes on the bed, which smelled very good and comforted the mind. This young lady did this many times without being seen by anyone. This gave King Genese wonderful satisfaction: for, when he came from hunting and entered the room, he believed himself to be in the midst of all the drugs and spices of the Levant. One day the king wanted to know from his mother and the young ladies who it was, so kind and gracious, who arranged his room so magnificently. He was told that they did not know, because, when they went to tidy the room, they usually found the bed covered with roses, violets and sweet-smelling perfumes. The king, hearing such wonders, resolved to find out exactly where this came from, and one morning pretended to go to a castle located ten leagues from the city; then he hid in the room, looking through a crack, and waiting to see what might happen. It was not long before Doralice, brighter than the sun, came out of her wardrobe; She began to clean the room, lay the rugs, remake the bed, and take care of everything, just as she had done the previous days. When the sweet maiden had fulfilled this worthy and praiseworthy service, she wanted to retire to her wardrobe; but the king, who had carefully attended to everything, came to surprise her and took her by the hand, and, seeing her beautiful and fresh as a lily, asked her who she was. The young girl replied that she was the daughter of a prince, whose name she could not remember, because she had already been hidden in the wardrobe for too long, but she would not say why. The king heard all this, then, with her mother's consent, took her as his wife, and fathered two children with her.
However Thibaud persisted in his perfidious and execrable desire, and, as he could not find his daughter whom he had long sought and sought, he came to think that she might well be in that wardrobe he had sold. So, overcome by spite and anger, he resolved to search the world to see if he could not find her. He dressed as a merchant, took many jewels and other gold works, and thus left Salerno in disguise. Having traveled through various countries, he one day met the one who had first bought her, and asked him if he had indeed sold her and into whose hands she had fallen. The other merchant replied that he had sold her to the King of England and had doubled his profit. At this news, Thibaud rejoiced and set off for England. As soon as he entered the city where the king was staying, he arranged against the wall of the palace jewels and other objects, among which were distaffs and spindles, and began to cry: "Come, ladies, distaffs and spindles!" Then one of the damsels went to the window, and seeing the merchant with his treasures, ran at once to the queen, and told her that there was a merchant in the street who sold distaffs and golden spindles, the most beautiful and richest that anyone had ever seen. The queen called him to the palace. He went up the stairs and entered the hall, but she did not recognize him, for she no longer thought of her father. Now the merchant, however, recognized his daughter very well. The queen then, having seen these splendid distaffs and spindles, asked the merchant how much he thought they were worth. "Expensive," he said; But if Your Highness is willing that I sleep one night in the room of your two children, I will give you all my merchandise as a present." The lady, simple and pure, who would never have suspected the cursed enterprise of this merchant, persuaded by her young ladies, consented. But, before the servants had led him to rest, the young ladies decided to give him a drink to make him sleep. When night came, the merchant pretended to be tired. One of the young ladies led him into the room of the king's children, where a magnificent bed had been made, and, before he was let in, the young lady said to him: "Father, are you not thirsty?" "Yes, my daughter." She took the glass, which seemed to be silver, and presented it to him; but he, who was cunning and crafty, pretended to drink all the wine, while he poured it little by little on his clothes, then he went to rest. Now, in the children's room, there was a small door through which one could enter the queen's bedroom.
When midnight came, he entered secretly and, approaching the bed, took a small knife from her, which she carried at her side and which he had already noticed the day before. He approached the cradle where the children were, killed them both, then put the bloody knife back in its sheath. He opened a window, climbed down to the ground with the help of a knotted rope, and early in the morning, at daybreak, went to a barber to have his long beard shaved, for fear of being recognized. He put on new clothes, looser and longer, and went through the city.
Meanwhile, the nurses, still asleep, got up at the usual time to nurse the children, but when they looked into the cradles, they found the children killed. So they began to scream and weep, tearing their hair, tearing their garments in front, and exposing their breasts. The sad news was immediately conveyed to the king and queen. They rose up barefoot, ran to this sad spectacle, and when they saw their children dead, began to weep bitterly.
The rumor of this murder had already spread throughout the city, and also that a famous astrologer had just arrived, who knew things and predicted the future according to the course of the stars. As his fame had reached the king's ears, he sent for him and asked him if he could not by his art discover who had killed the children. The astrologer replied that he could, and, approaching the king's ear, said in a low voice: "Sire, order all those in your court who carry a knife at their side to come and present themselves before you; Whoever is found in possession of the still bloody knife will be the true murderer of your children." Then all the courtiers, on his orders, appeared before him, and carefully checked whether their knives were not stained with blood; and, as he found none that were soiled, he returned to the astrologer, he told him what he had done and that he had searched everyone, except his mother and the queen. "Sire," replied the astrologer, "search well and have no regard for anyone, you will certainly find the criminal." The king searched his mother, but found no clue; finally, he called the queen, took from her the sheath she was carrying at her side and found the knife all stained with blood. Then, seized with rage, the king, faced with this clear proof, turned to his wife and said to her: "Ah! cruel and wicked woman, enemy of your own blood, perfidious towards your own children! How could you ever have the courage to soil your hands with the innocent blood of these poor little ones? I swear before God that you will bear the penance for such a great crime." And, although the king was inflamed with anger and spite and wanted to take revenge immediately by putting her to an ignominious death, nevertheless, so that she would suffer longer, a new idea came to him: he gave orders to strip the queen naked, to bury her in the ground completely naked up to the throat, and to feed her with exquisite food, so that the vermin would devour her flesh, and so that she would endure a harder and longer torture. The queen, who in the past had endured many other miseries and knew herself to be innocent, took death patiently. When the good astrologer, who was none other than her father, learned that the queen, found guilty, had been condemned to a horrible death, he rejoiced greatly, and, taking leave of the king, left England in great contentment; and, as soon as he had secretly arrived at his palace, he told the nurse everything that had happened to him, and how her daughter had been condemned. The nurse appeared to be rejoiced, but, in her heart of hearts, she was very angry. Moved with pity for her poor daughter, and animated by the tender love she bore him, she left one day, early in the morning, from Salerno, and rode day and night to the kingdom of England. She climbed the steps of the palace and found the king who was giving audience to all in a vast hall. Kneeling at his feet, she asked for a secret audience for a matter concerning the honor of her crown. The king took her in his arms and made her stand up, and, giving her his hand, made the audience withdraw and sat down alone with her. The nurse, very well informed of past events, said to him respectfully: "You must know, Sire, that Doralice, your wife and my 
daughter (not because I carried her in this miserable womb, but because I suckled and nourished her with these breasts), is innocent of the crime wrongly imputed to her, and for which she is condemned to a cruel death. And when you have heard the name of the impious murderer, and put your finger on the reason that drove him to kill your children, I am certain that you will be moved with pity, and that you will immediately deliver her from this terrible torture. But if you find that I lie with a single word, I offer to undergo the same punishment as the queen." "And from beginning to end, she told him point by point everything that had happened. The king believed these words, and ordered that the queen, who was more dead than alive, be removed from the tomb. He had her cared for with great diligence, so that she quickly returned to health. Then the king made great preparations throughout his kingdom, assembled a large army which he sent to Salerno, and the city was quickly conquered: Thibaud was captured, and bound hand and foot was taken prisoner to England. The king, wishing to have greater assurance of his fault, proceeded against him with severity, and had him put to the examination, where he confessed point by point everything that had happened. The next day, he was led through the whole city in a chariot drawn by four horses, and was tortured, then quartered, like Ganelon, and his limbs thrown to the dogs. This is how the wicked and abominable Thibaud ended his life miserably, and King and Queen Doralice lived for a long time in great happiness, leaving behind beautiful children who succeeded them on the throne.
Giovan Francesco Straparola, Les Nuits facetieuses, Paris, José Corti, 1999, pp. 48-58 (First Night, Fable IV).

Content:
Il était une fois trois sœurs. Deux d’entre elles étaient issues d’une autre naissance. Comme elles détestaient leur troisième sœur, elles l’appellaient « Marie des Cendres-Roulée-dedans-Peson et Fuseau des Cendres ». Tous les jours les trois sœurs partaient filer la laine au bord d’un précipice; elles disaient que celle qui n’arriverait à filer vite sa botte de laine, verrait se transformer sa mère en vache. Cependant, il faut dire que seule Marie des Cendres avait sa mère, les autres n’en avaient point. La pauvre fille finissait toujours très vite ses bottes de laine et les demi-sœurs ne trouvaient rien à redire. Mais, pour se venger, elles lui remettaient en cachette toutes les laines de son côté. Et, plus elle voyait les bottes de laine s’accumuler, plus se dépêchait-elle de filer au plus vite. Cependant, une fois parmi d’autres, Marie des Cendres ne put finir toutes les bottes de laine et sa mère se transforma en vache.
Le soir en rentrant, elles vont chez elle pour ouvrir la porte, et elles entendent un meuglement. Elles ouvrent et regardent et voient la vache au milieu ; lorsque leur père rentre aussi du travail, et voit ce qui s’était passé, bouleversé il dit : « Que pouvons-nous maintenant, mes fillettes ? Toi, Marie des Cendres, tu dois prendre tous les jours la vache et tu iras la faire païtre et le soir tu rentreras chez nous ». Lorsqu'elle s’en fut plusieurs fois conduire la vache, son père lui dit : « Va, maintenant te reposer, Marie
des Cendres; tes Sœurs pourront, elles aussi, désormais l'emmener aux champs ».
Le matin les sœurs l’emmènent pour la faire paître et celle-ci ne veut pas bouger. Elles essaient à plusieurs reprises et puis le père dit: « Nous allons la tuer, les filles, cette vache, et nous allons la manger ». Dès qu'elle entendit cela, Marie des Cendres se leva brusquement et se mit à pleurer et à crier très fort. Mais son père ne l’écouta point et décida d’égorger la vache.
On la fit bien rôtir au four et l’on se mit à la manger près de l’âtre. Marie des Cendres était assise derrière l’âtre et regardait. « Viens ici, toi aussi, Marie, te réjouir », lui dirent ses demi-sœurs. Mais elle regardait sans cesse, sans dire un mot. Elle ramassait seulement les os qu’elles jetaient. Elle les prit tous ensemble et s’en fut les enterrer dans un endroit qu’elle seule connaissait. Elle avait cependant gardé la queue de la vache et, lorsqu'elle voulait se rendre quelque part, elle brûlait un poil et apparaissait d’un grand saut devant elle un cheval armé et un habit en or. Ses deux autres sœurs sortaient, s’amusaient, sans inviter Marie des Cendres. Mais, une fois, quelqu'un les invita toutes les trois pour un baptême, suivi d’une grande fête. Les deux sœurs, bien parées, dirent enfin à Marie des Cendres, de venir avec elles, faire la fête. Mais la pauvre Marie répondait, comme les autres fois, « puisque je n'ai rien, comment voulez-vous que je vienne ?»
Dès que ses demi-sœurs furent parties, elle court tout de suite à l'endroit où elle avait enterré les os de la vache, allume un poil et voit tout de suite apparaître le cheval armé ainsi que l’habit en or. Elle le monte aussitôt et arrive avant ses méchantes sœurs à la maison où devait se tenir la fête. Quand les gens virent une telle femme, habillée d’or et couverte de pièces d’or ils lui demandèrent sans hésiter d’être la marraine. Elle accepta, et, lorsque le baptême fut terminé, elle se mit à distribuer plein de pièces d’or à tous les invités. Ses sœurs ne l'avaient pas reconnue, et, contentes d’avoir eu beaucoup
de pièces d'or, rentrèrent chez elles. Marie des Cendres, s'arrêta en route devant un puits, pour que son cheval boive. Mais, sans faire attention, elle fit tomber une chaussure dans le puits. Elle essaya, tant bien que mal, de la retirer, mais cela fut impossible. Elle s'en alla. Arrivée à l'endroit où elle cachait son cheval et son habit, elle dit brûler encore un poil de la queue de la vache et tout disparût sous ses yeux. Elle part donc pour rentrer chez elle. Elle rentre et s'assoit dans un coin. Sous peu arrivent ses deux soeurs, contentes, et commencent à lui raconter la Soirée. « Tu n'es pas venue, Marie des Cendres-Roulée-dedans-Peson et Fuseau des Cendres, pour voir quelle soirée nous avons eue ! Est arrivée une femme, très belle, vêtue d’or, sur un cheval avec une selle, et c’est elle qui fut la marraine et enfin, elle nous distribua plein de pièces d’or». - « Eh, bien, montrez-moi vos pièces d’or, que je les voie aussi », dit alors Marie des Cendres. Celles-ci ouvrent tout de suite, joyeuses la boîte, où elles les avaient mises, elle regardent, et, que voient-elles ! Elles voient la boîte remplie de charbon! Elles s’étonnèrent et s’en furent sur-lechamp interroger leurs voisins, qui étaient aussi invités au baptême. Mais les autres avaient leurs pièces d’or. Elles pensèrent qu’une drôle de chose était peut-être en train d'arriver.
Un jour, le prince s’en fut au puits boire de l’eau, et, comme il était en train de regarder à l’intérieur, il vit dans le fond briller une chaussure. Il lance le seau et la retire aussitôt et, sans perdre du temps, il passe par toutes les maisons du village et demande à qui appartient la chaussure. Chaque femme disait que la chaussure lui appartenait. Mais le prince la leur faisait essayer, et, lorsqu'il voyait qu’elle ne leur allait pas parfaitement, il partait on autre maison. Au bout du compte, après avoir tourné dans le village entier sans résultat, il frappe à la porte de Marie des Cendre. Mais, les deux demi-soeurs, qui commencent à soupçonner qu'il s'était passé quelque
chose, lorsqu'elles voient leurs pièces d’or se changer en morceaux de charbon, et, quand elles entendent que le prince tourne dans le village entier, pour trouver la femme à qui appartient cette chaussure d’or, elles attrapent Marie des Cendres et l’enferment dans un grand panier, qu'elles recouvrent d’un tissu.
Lorsque le prince entra dans la pièce, elles lui proposèrent une chaise pou s'asseoir, mais lui alla s'asseoir sur le panier. Lorsqu'elles virent la chaussure, elles commencèrent à crier et à dire qu’elle leur appartenait, et à remercier le prince pour le bien qu’il leur fit en la ramenant. Mais, cela ne servit à rien, car la chaussure était trop petite, lorsqu'elles l’essayèrent. Marie des Cendres, ayant soupçonne ce qui se passait, avait pris avec elle une grosse aiguille, avant qu'on ne la cache dans le panier, et piquait le prince ; « Mais, qu'avez-vous ici, qui me pique ? » demanda le prince aux deux sœurs. « Rien, mon prince, nous n'avons qu'une poule ». Marie des Cendres le piqua encore une fois et de nouveau le prince demanda aux deux sœurs. Elles lui répondirent: « Rien, mon roi, ce n’est qu'une poule ». Mais, la troisième fois, il ne put plus tenir, et il découvrit aussitôt le panier, et vit Marie des Cendres, l’aiguille à la main. Il lui demande à elle aussi d'essayer la chaussure, pour voir si elle fui appartient, et elle essaie. La chaussure lui va parfaitement.
Le prince s’en va alors en courant dans son palais. Il retrouve son père et lui dit: « Mon père, tu sais, j'ai pris la décision d’épouser Marie des Cendres - Mais toi, mon fils, dans tes richesses, épouser Marie des Cendres-Roulée-dedans-Peson et Fuseau des Cendres ? » lui dit son père. Mais, lorsqu'il vit, tant bien que mal, qu'il ne pouvait lui faire changer d’avis, il lui donna sa bénédiction pour qu’il l'amène au palais.
Le lendemain matin, le prince se lève, s habille en or et va versila maison de Marie des Cendres. Elle le savait et n'avait pas perdu de temps. Elle se rendit dès l'aube à l'endroit ou elle avait enterré les os de sa mère, qui s'était
transformée en vache, elle brûla un poil de la queue qu’elle avait gardée, et, aussitôt apparaissent le cheval armé et l’habit d’or. Elle le monte et se rend chez elle. Le prince arrive alors et l'emmène ; il s'en vont au palais. Un an plus tard, Marie des Cendre eut un enfant. Ses sœurs, très jalouses d'elle, voulant sa mort, se lèvent un beau matin, se transforment en sorcières et se rendent au palais. Elles frappent à la porte et une servante apparaît « Nous voulons voir la reine.
— Ce n’est pas possible, ces jours-ci, elles vient d’accoucher. — Mais, c’est pour cela que nous voulons la voir ». Sur ces paroles, la servante ouvre la porte et les conduit à la chambre où se trouve la reine avec son petit enfant; la servante s’en va. Sans perdre de temps, les sorcières sortent une aiguille et lui piquent le crâne. Elle se transforme tout de suite en oiseau. Alors, l'une d’elles se met au lit, et fait semblant d’être la nouvelle accouchée, sans que le roi soit au courant; mais le petit, qui n’avait pas sa mère pour téter, pleurait toute la journée et ne se calmait jamais. Plus tard, le roi entre dans la chambre et demande : « Mais pourquoi cet enfant pleure-t-il toute la journée et ne se calme-t-il jamais ?— Parce que je n’ai pas de lait pour l’allaiter, voilà pourquoi il pleure toute la journée », lui dit sa « femme ». « Et pourquoi n’as-tu point de lait? »
— À cause de mon état de nouvelle accouchée », lui répondit-elle. Et l’enfant pleurait, pleurait, tout le temps et on ne savait que faire. Ils apportèrent du lait de l'extérieur, mais lui ne voulait pas se calmer. Devant le palais il y avait une branche et sur cette branche venait se poser l'oiseau (la vraie mère de l'enfant), tous les matins il gazouillait et aussitôt l’enfant s’arrêtait de pleurer. La reine-nouvelle-accouchée s’en rendit compte alors et ordonna qu'on le tue. Le roi ne voulait pas, mais quand il vit que sa femme insistait, il donna la permission de le tuer. Le
chasseur qui le tua, le prit dans ses mains, et le regarda attentivement. Il voit une épingle la retire et l'enlève de sa tête. Dès qu’il l’eut retirée, trois gouttes de sang tombèrent par terre, et là, poussa un beau pommier devant le palais. Il devint grand et dès que l'enfant s’en approchait, il se baissait pour qu’il l'attrape. Il se penchait seulement devant le roi et le petit garçon, pour qu'ils puissent prendre les pommes ; lorsque sa sœur, la sorcière, s'approchait, le pommier écartait ses branches. Elle comprit aussitôt Ce Qui se passait et ordonna qu’on coupe le pommier; le roi ne voulait pas, mais l’a permis. On convoque un bûcheron et lui demande de le couper ; à l'endroit où il frappait avec sa hache, on entendit une voix, qui disait « Oh, ma taille » Le bûcheron court alors voir le roi, et lui raconte l'incident ; « Il faut au moins l'ouvrir en deux » lui dit le roi. Il lui tombe alors dessus avec sa hache pour le couper en lamelles, mais la voix se cache dans un petit morceau de bois et le bûcheron, sans le savoir, le prend et le pose sur une pierre.
Un jour il arrive qu’une vieille passe par là. Elle voit le bois, le prend et l’emporte chez elle. Le lendemain matin elle se lève et va à la montagne couper du bois. Le soir en rentrant, elle voit qu’on avait porté de l’eau, préparé la cuisine, donné à manger aux chats. Elle demanda « qui vous donna à manger, mes petits chats ? » Mais ils ne répondaient pas ; le lendemain, elle fit semblant de partir travailler et se cacha dans un baril. Elle sort sous peu de sa cachette et voit Marie des Cendres faire le ménage. La vieille lui dit alors : « C’est toi, petite dame, qui prépares tout, lorsque je ne suis pas là ? — Oui, c'est moi, grand-mère, lui dit alors Marie des Cendres - Comment se fait-il que tu ne te sois pas montrée depuis le temps que tu es ici?»
Et elle commença à raconter son histoire : « Je suis Marie des Cendres-Roulée-dedans-Peson et Fuseau des Cendres...»
Entre-temps, le prince, comme il comprit un jour que l’autre n’était pas sa vraie femme, tomba gravement malade à mourir. Et beaucoup de gens se rendaient au palais lui apportant les neuf biens du monde à manger, mais son état s’aggravait toujours. Il ne mangeait rien de ce qu’on lui apportait. La petite vieille, lorsqu’elle apprit tout cela, dit à Marie des Cendres : « Nous allons aussi rendre visite à ton mari. Nous ferons bouillir des choux, nous mettrons ta bague dans les choux et nous irons ». Marie des Cendres fut d'accord et elles y allèrent. Lorsqu’elles arrivèrent au palais, sa demi-sœur sortit demander où est-ce qu’elles emportaient les choux et ce qu’elles voulaient. Elles répondirent qu’elles voulaient les donner au roi malade, pour qu’il soit guéri. La reine répondit alors: «On lui a apporté les neuf biens du monde à manger et il n’en a pas voulu! Il mangera ces choux ? — Au moins laisse-nous lui rendre visite », dirent alors les deux étrangères.
Elle les laissa et elles entrèrent dans la chambre du roi, qu'elles trouvèrent prêt à mourir, l’âme dans la bouche. Elles le prièrent : « Notre roi, si tu manges une cuillerée de choux, tu verras que tu guériras tout de suite. »
Le roi prit les choux pour les manger, et, en les mélaneant, il trouva la bague. Il guérit alors aussitôt, se leva du lit, attrapa la demi-soeur de Marie des Cendre et la brûla dans le four. Il donne à la vieille un carrosse rempli de pièces d'or, et elle s'a va, il reconnaît sa femme et c'est ainsi qu'ensuite il vécurent heureux, mais pas autant que nous.
English:
Once upon a time, there were three sisters. Two of them were from another birth. Since they hated their third sister, they called her "Ash Mary-Rolled-in-Peson and Ash Spindle." Every day, the three sisters went to spin wool at the edge of a precipice; they said that whoever failed to spin her bundle of wool quickly would see her mother transformed into a cow. However, it must be said that only Ash Mary had her mother; the others did not. The poor girl always finished her bundles of wool very quickly, and the stepsisters had nothing to complain about. But, to get revenge, they secretly gave her all the wool on her side. And the more bundles of wool she saw piling up, the faster she hurried to spin. However, on one occasion, among others, Ash Mary was unable to finish all the bundles of wool, and her mother transformed into a cow.
In the evening, when they came home, they went to her house to open the door, and they heard a lowing. They opened it and looked in, and saw the cow in the middle. When their father also came home from work and saw what had happened, he was distraught and said, "What can we do now, my little girls? You, Mary of Ashes, must take the cow every day and go out to graze her, and in the evening you will return to us." When she went several times to lead the cow, her father said to her, "Now go and rest, Mary of Ashes; your sisters can also take her to the fields from now on."
In the morning, the sisters took her out to graze, but she refused to move. They tried several times, and then the father said, "We will kill this cow, girls, and we will eat her." As soon as she heard this, Mary of Ashes suddenly stood up and began to cry and scream very loudly. But her father didn't listen to her and decided to slaughter the cow. They roasted it well in the oven and began to eat it near the hearth. Mary of Ashes sat behind the hearth and watched. "Come here, you too, Mary, and rejoice," her stepsisters told her. But she watched without saying a word. She only picked up the bones they threw away. She took them all together and went to bury them in a place only she knew. She had, however, kept the cow's tail, and when she wanted to go somewhere, she would burn a hair and with a great leap appear before her an armed horse and a golden garment. Her two other sisters would go out and have fun, without inviting Mary of Ashes. But once, someone invited all three of them to a baptism, followed by a big party. The two sisters, well adorned, finally asked Mary of Ashes to come with them to the party. But poor Mary replied, as she had always done, "Since I have nothing, how can I come?" As soon as her stepsisters had left, she immediately ran to the place where she had buried the cow's bones, lit a candle, and immediately saw the armed horse and the gold suit appear. She mounted it immediately and arrived before her wicked sisters at the house where the party was to be held. When the people saw such a woman, dressed in gold and covered in gold coins, they asked her without hesitation to be the godmother. She accepted, and when the baptism was over, she began distributing lots of gold coins to all the guests. Her sisters hadn't recognized her, and, happy to have had so many gold coins, went home. Mary of Ashes stopped on the road in front of a well so that her horse could drink. But, without paying attention, she dropped a shoe into the well. She tried, as best she could, to get it out, but it was impossible. She left. When she reached the place where she hid her horse and her coat, she said she burned another hair from the cow's tail and everything disappeared before her eyes. So she left to go home. She went inside and sat down in a corner. Soon her two sisters arrived, happy, and began to tell her about the evening. "You didn't come, Mary of Ashes-Rolled-in-it-Weighbridge and Spindle of Ashes, to see what an evening we had! A woman arrived, very beautiful, dressed in gold, on a horse with a saddle, and she was the godmother and finally, she gave us lots of gold coins." - "Well, show me your gold coins, so I can see them too," said Mary of Ashes. They immediately, joyfully, opened the box where they had put them, they looked, and what did they see! They saw the box filled with coal! They were astonished and went immediately to question their neighbors, who were also invited to the baptism. But the others had their gold coins. They thought that something strange was perhaps happening.
One day, the prince went to the well to drink some water, and, as he was looking inside, he saw a shoe shining at the bottom. He threw the bucket and immediately pulled it out and, without wasting any time, he went through all the houses in the village and asked who the shoe belonged to. Each woman said that the shoe belonged to her. But the prince made them try it on, and when he saw that it didn't fit perfectly, he would go to another house. Finally, after wandering around the entire village without success, he knocked on the door of Marie des Cendres. But the two stepsisters, who began to suspect that something had happened, when they saw their gold coins turn into lumps of coal, and when they heard that the prince was wandering around the entire village, trying to find the woman to whom this golden shoe belonged, they grabbed Marie des Cendres and put her in a large basket, which they covered with a cloth. When the prince entered the room, they offered him a chair to sit on, but he went to sit on the basket. When they saw the shoe, they began to shout and say that it belonged to them, and to thank the prince for the kindness he had done them in bringing it back. But it was of no use, for the shoe was too small when they tried it on. Mary of Ashes, having suspected what was happening, had taken a large needle with her, before it was hidden in the basket, and pricked the prince; "But, what have you here that pricks me?" the prince asked the two sisters. "Nothing, my prince, we only have a hen." Mary of Ashes pricked him again and again the prince asked the two sisters. They answered him: "Nothing, my king, it is only a hen." But the third time, he could hold it no longer, and he immediately uncovered the basket and saw Mary of Ashes, needle in hand. He asked her to try on the shoe too, to see if it belonged, and she did. The shoe fit perfectly.
The prince then ran off to his palace. He found his father and said to him: "Father, you know, I have decided to marry Mary of Ashes—but you, my son, in your riches, marry Mary of Ashes-Rolled-in-the-Weigh-and-Spindle of Ashes?" his father asked him. But when he saw, somehow, that he could not change her mind, he gave him his blessing to bring her to the palace.
The next morning, the prince got up, dressed in gold, and went to Mary of Ashes's house. She knew this and had wasted no time. At dawn, she went to the place where she had buried the bones of her mother, who had transformed into a cow. She burned a hair from the tail she had kept, and immediately the armed horse and the golden robe appeared. She mounted it and went to her house. The prince then arrived and took her away; they went to the palace. A year later, Mary of Ashes had a child. Her sisters, very jealous of her, wanting her dead, got up one fine morning, transformed themselves into witches, and went to the palace. They knocked at the door and a maid appeared: "We want to see the queen." "It's not possible these days; she has just given birth." "But that is why we want to see her." With these words, the maid opened the door and led them to the room where the queen was with her little child; the maid left. Without wasting any time, the witches took out a needle and pricked her head. She immediately transformed into a bird. Then, one of them went to bed and pretended to be the new mother, without the king knowing; but the little one, who didn't have his mother to suckle, cried all day and never calmed down. Later, the king entered the room and asked, "But why does this child cry all day and never calm down?" "Because I have no milk to nurse him, that's why he cries all day," his "wife" told him. "And why don't you have any milk?" "Because of my condition as a new mother," she replied. And the child cried and cried all the time, and they didn't know what to do. They brought milk from outside, but he wouldn't calm down. In front of the palace there was a branch and on this branch the bird (the child's real mother) would come and sit. Every morning it would chirp and immediately the child would stop crying. The newly-born queen realized this and ordered that it be killed. The king didn't want to, but when he saw that his wife insisted, he gave permission to kill it. The hunter who killed it took it in his hands and looked at it carefully. He saw a pin pull it out and removed it from its head. As soon as he had pulled it out, three drops of blood fell to the ground, and there grew a beautiful apple tree in front of the palace. It grew tall and as soon as the child approached it, it would bend down so that the child could catch it. It only bent down in front of the king and the little boy, so that they could take the apples; when his sister, the witch, approached, the apple tree spread its branches. She immediately understood what was happening and ordered that the apple tree be cut down; the king did not want to, but allowed it.
