OI allait pas. Y avait pas moyen: l’un ol était trop grand, l’autre ol était bayant. L'étiont pour s’en aller, velà que tournont la tête, pis voyont dans l’coin Cendrouzette, assise dans l’coin de la cheminaï. Elle disait rin mais savait ben de quoi il en était — parce que ses sœurs:
« Oh! quelle idée saugrenue ! Elle a des pé d’éléphant! » Et pis, ma foi, quand même:
« Oh! nous sommes venus pour voir tous les pieds des demoiselles. Nous voulons chausser celle-ci. »
Et au même moment qu’ont tourné la tête, la fée l’a transformée en la toilette de bal. Et pis, pardé, en même temps qu'a voulu mett’le pé dedans, de sa p'tite poche a sort la « personnière » de tchielle là et pis les chausse toutes les deux. Ses sœurs étaient confondues, son père et pis sa mère étiont rendus, confondus. Le roi est venu la chercher, pis son gas. Pis sont mariés après. Se sont pas occupés qu’elle avait porté le nom de Cendouzette, et qu'elle avait été tout l'temps dans la cendre.
Pis sa mère lui demandait pardon des peinces qu'elle avait faites. Le roi a demandé : « Qui qu'elle voulait faire, voulait-elle punir ses parents ?» Elle a dit : « Non, mais faut pas qu'ils recommencent à faire des peinces à personne.
Pis ol est fini.
Dit par Madame Ernest Cosset, à la Goujardiere, hameau de la commune de Boupre (Vendée), le 3à avril 1945.
Enquête Ariane de Félice, Poitou (Musée des arts et traditions populaires - Ms 59.2).
English:
There were people who were very rich, who had very beautiful estates. They had a daughter. They wanted to have another, and the second one came along: they loved her as much as the first, and then, to add insult to injury, a third one came along, and they didn't know how to make her disappear. So they asked each other: "Whoever has a third? If he's a boy, he'll walk well. If she's a girl, we'll have to make her disappear," said the father.
When he came along, he was still a girl. Then the mother said the same thing.
"We mustn't compromise ourselves just because we're afraid. At that moment," the mother said, "they just thought about what we'll have to do." When she gets up, well, I'll go lose her in the woods, I'll say that a little wolf came to eat her and then I'll say that it was me who saved me to get out of trouble. So, because, you understand, I'll take her in a little carriage and then the wolf will take her away" and then, you understand, that's when it got compromised: she abandoned her in the woods then the fairy came, then she carried the little girl without anyone seeing her to the castle gate, and then in a moment, they thought they were saved: they thought it was permission from heaven, that it would bring them luck: "We have to raise her anyway. Maybe she'll bring us a whole treasure one day." Well, they took to raising her without loving her like her two sisters. Well, for a little while, they'd given up hope on that fortune. After that, when she was older, seeing no wealth coming, they put her to work as a servant. They had a big chimney, and to hide from the beatings, because they were always beating her, they hid in the chimney.
When they came to hit her, they'd bang themselves against the firebox so they wouldn't tap her, they'd take the blade of the firebox and put it in front of her face. Since she was always in the corner of the chimney, they started calling her "Little Cendrouzette."
Then, as time went by, the older ones, we all thought about getting married. So: "We have to introduce them to society. Who would come looking for them down there?" We absolutely have to introduce them to the world. And who are we going to do? We have to give balls where we'll invite some people."
But since they weren't very attractive, no one invited them to dance.
So they said:
"We have to go to some fairs (the beautiful youth fairs they used to have), there they might get noticed, they might even get proposed to."
And that's what we did. They traveled to three or four places to be seen: no young men noticed them, no gents came to ask for their hand in marriage.
They said:
"That's when we introduced them, but no one looked at them. We have to give a ball, and then we'll invite the richest people in the area. Everyone will come." They'll be forced to notice them, to see how they're loved. If we marry one first, we'll make an entrance for the other.
I see nothing but rich people. So, the father was very pleased:
"I know a lot of big, tall girls. I'd like to invite them. I'll invite the fathers and the mothers because in high society, that's how it's done."
So, the man went off to make his invitations.
Almost everywhere, they were well received: the whole family was invited, you understand, the fathers and the mothers. And then, the morning the ball was to be held, Cendrouzette had been helped by her sisters to get dressed. They had one outfit for lunch, another for the ball, another for going out. They had everything, Cendrouzette had nothing. There was a year between the two eldest; Cendrouzette was three years younger than the eldest. "Yeah, I'd love to stay here, watching them dance. I'd learn how to do it!" [accompanied by a gesture: the storyteller puts her head in her hands, leans against the table, and adopts a whining tone.]
— "Oh, you poor rag," her mother says. You want to stay here to prevent me from having guys who would want to talk to my daughters.
You dare call me your mother. I don't know, you're not the other sister. You're not at all like them. Do you know where he's going to take you? Right now, he wants to keep the witch, to work in your place. She looks like she could catch the kids." You're going to go to the fields to keep your ears open. And then, another one said the same thing:
"I'll stay here anyway." He didn't think his mother could hear. The pig girl was there to make the pig's food. She had a scoop to take from the cauldron, and then the mother said to him:
"Pass me a scoop." She was ready to put on her gloves, to receive. The other one didn't know what was going to do. She took the scoop, grabbed little Cendrouzette, and laid her down belly down. She was hitting, hit as hard as she could like that Tan! tan! tan! [accompanied by a gesture] She broke the handle of the bucket! And she said: "Here's a bunch of dry bread to get through your day, and your distaff, for the filai. And turn over all the fusias you make, sure to be scared." And there she went, good people! She was crying because her buttocks were all on fire from the blows she had received. There she went with her ears and her back, and her bunch of dry bread, and her distaff. There she went. As soon as she arrived on the path, left the house, she saw a beggar. She didn't believe who the fairy was because the fairy didn't always present herself equally, she had always seen her as a beautiful lady. A. left sobbing: she hadn't recovered, you think her butt was hurting. The godmother said:
"Hey! Are you the one going to the fields today?"
A. didn't answer, good people! because she was so choked from the blows that she didn't answer. Then the fairy said:
"Well, where are you going? To the fields? Well, stop it for a while. I was going to talk."
A. said:
"Are you going to the valley's field?" And then the other one replied: Yes. So, to herself, she didn't think she was the fairy. She had seen her in her beautiful outfit, that she was radiant, put her hand on her hair, said to her, "You're in trouble," and then she left. And then, when she was back in the fields, she said:
"Isn't that all right? Who's doing yelling like that?"
And then she told her story. The fairy knew in advance:
"He said two or three times that he wanted to stay at the ball, then Mom didn't want to, beat me anyway, and he's suffering. And then, what did he say, at this hour, he's not happy. That's what's making me yell." And then the fairy said:
"You'll be the one to dance the best!"
"How do you expect him to go to the ball? I don't have any clothes!"
And the fairy said:
"Hey, you see, in the field next door, what the fairy says: he has a beautiful pumpkin. Go get me that beautiful pumpkin." » And then, she said the same: "You'll bring it to me there."
When she came, the fairy transformed the pumpkin into a little carriage. She called it a little "flying chest." It didn't need horses, you understand, that was the fairy's power. She said:
"But also, who will spin my distaff?" Then, that carriage came back all by itself, it's funny to see you think! Filled with beautiful outfits inside, dresses of all kinds. That's a power the fairy had. She said the same:
"You're going to dress yourself in those old outfits. There are others there, but don't keep them. They'll be for another time."
But, she said:
"Who will spin my distaff while he's not here?" And then he said to look a little further into the bottom of the flying chest:
"You'll find a little stick, you'll see, you'll do like me when you're in trouble and when you have work to do, you'll tap it three little times with your little stick [gesture] and then, as the fairy said, put down your spindle and put your distaff on the ground, like this."
Then he gave three little taps with his wand like this, and brrrrr! All the spindles were found full of netting.
Then he said: "Keep the stick, because every time your mother sends you to bake, you'll hit the grandmother and the bread will be all ready to put in the oven - and then when you're at the toilet. Here, you'll put your laundry on the wash-house, then you'll tap three times with your stick, and all your laundry will be ready to hang up." »
And, in that way of acting that almost no longer worked, she was taking on a very pretty face. And she was transforming into a beautiful girl. So her parents started saying to each other:
"How come she looks so pretty? She's going to be a beautiful girl."
And her sisters started saying to each other:
"She's going to get married before we meet!"
The worse she got, the more contempt she felt about it. And, every day, the fairy went to see her; she went to the fields more often to talk more freely. And, in the meantime, she had become a big girl like the others, hadn't she, and so we were always jealous of them because of that. The sisters, they had been invited in turn to visit some neighbors. And then, she knew she'd pooped in the toilet: she just had to take it. So when morning came to go on a visit, everything was ready, both father and mother, and the two daughters were ready—and then Cendrouzette, she did the same thing as usual: "It would have been nice to go to the dance too." She stayed in her little corner, in the fireplace, by the ashes. And then, she did the same thing as last time.
"I'd be fine, everything."
"What are you thinking down there, in that little corner? Do you want another tournay like the other day?" And then, right, the bucket was broken, you understand, the other had a big pot to fish out the pig's cauldron. So she said: "Pass me that pot." A'ct'h(e) ure, there was no more bucket, you know very well that it was broken from before. So, he did the same thing again: Then he drummed his buttocks. Al broke the pot again. Cendrouzette went back to the fields to keep his ears. And then, little flying chest, the rest was stuck in a mess of thorns. And then he stayed stuck. He said to his godmother: "I'm too old for him to be caught."
"No, no, there's no one else to save him but Tâ and Mâ." And then, when she was returned, she found the fairy again. She said the same thing that Al had been beaten:
"Well, you'll go anyway," the fairy said. "You'll climb into your flying chest." You'll say:
"Volvol'vol'mon little flying chest until you approach the gate of the castle where the ball is."
When you arrive at the gate of the castle, you'll see a big tree whose branches hang to the ground like this [gesture], you'll slide under it. There you'll put your little flying chest under the big chest. And you'll come out in a beautiful pram. You won't say a word, you'll say "rin." Just note that you have to be back from the castle by nightfall. Then the pram will arrive at the castle gate. And she had to get inside it all the way to the castle, then climb back into her little flying chest. The pram would disappear under the castle and find the flying chest again. All she had to do was say:
"Fly, fly, fly, my little flying chest, to the field of my ears."
She obeyed the fairy perfectly. When she arrived in her little pram, everyone was watching the procession. They were completely astonished, and all her parents didn't recognize her. She danced and danced. And had a great time. So the others weren't having fun in such good taste because she was always in demand. But time passed: it was the ser. She had to go. The boldest one, while dancing, said:
"Allow me, Miss, that I'll ask where you live."
— Her mother was sitting not far away. She saw that her mother was there, that she could hear.
"What's she going to say?... You don't know?" If you don't know, I'll tell you. It's called "Casse-goblet Castle and Casse-pot."
"Oh, I've heard of that. Would you allow me to accompany you for a little while?"
He thanked her, saying that she would always return before the birth. And then when she was about to leave, she made a lovely impression [sic, curtsies?]: she was very sorry to have to leave them so early, but she had to get back before nightfall. She thought everyone would laugh to see her come out. Then at the same time the pram arrived with three drivers up there on the seat, some pretty maids to hold the tail of her dress, others to help her get in. And then everyone watched as she left. Since she had danced so much, no one had taken a liking to the ball. Everyone was about to leave—and her sisters, the youngest.
And there she was. She went to the carriage. And all of a sudden, everything disappeared: the landau, the horses, the drivers, the maids. She had arrived just as the fairy had said. She climbed into the little flying chest again. She said:
"Fly, fly, fly, my little flying chest, right to the field of my ears."
Then she took her distaff, her clothes, and her antics, and there she was, to arrive before her sisters. But the shepherdess and all the maids were suspicious, seeing that there was something urging her on. Then the king's son noticed this young lady. Made her dance. He told his father about it. "You want to marry me, but for sure, that girl would please me the most of all the girls I've ever met."
And he saw her in all his dreams: he had dreams about her all the time.
So the king gave a ball to invite all the girls in the area. The king's son said the same thing: how do you expect him to be invited? I don't know the castle of Break-God and Break-Pot. And then the king said:
"We're going to put it up everywhere." Everyone was invited to please the king's son. And just think, many of them didn't come (he had to go to the trouble of returning the invitation).
And when the day came, well! Cendrouzette, she still wanted to go to the ball. But she went off to the fields; She didn't insist, she wanted to go anyway. A great joy that the fairy had promised her. She went to the fields without being asked. And there, there was no fixed time for the ball. We went there in the morning if we wanted. We had food and drink, and we spent the night afterward if we wanted.
There were footmen to receive the guests, others to "tender" the horses to the stable, guests, serve food and water the horses.
And then Cendrouzette said:
"I don't want to go this morning. I'm leaving around ten thirty or eleven o'clock for lunch." So the fairy said the same: "Now I'm going to give you one more recommendation that you must execute it point by point."
So he said the same thing:
"You see, you're going to take this little toilet." We couldn't even resist it, it was so luxurious, it was so brilliant, and at the time, just think! Then he said:
"You're going to get into your flying trunk. You'll say:
"Fly, fly, fly, my little flying trunk To the king's gate."
Then you'll find something else, an abandoned cabin, where no one lives, then you'll slip inside. You'll say:
"Fly, fly, fly, my little flying trunk To that cabin 'which is located near the castle gate."
You'll leave the flying trunk in the cabin: you'll leave in a large carriage, the likes of which you've never seen in your life. And you'll find maids to serve you. I'll have six horses, three coachmen on the seat, three other horses in front of it, with a coachman on each horse. Then it will go exactly where you're going. When you get out of the carriage, you'll say to the stablehands: Thank you very much. I have everything I need. The men who are with me know my horses only among themselves who do what's next."
Then the king, seeing such a beautiful procession approaching, sent some maids to help the young lady get out.
She thanked him again: that she had everything she needed.
She only had her maids who would serve her. They helped her get out, and she said she didn't need anyone. And the landau turned around. They really thought she'd return to the house of Break-Down and Break-Pot! [gesture].
The king's son went to speak to his father:
"She's the one I need."
"That's what I've noticed for myself too, the most suitable match in society." The king, and his friend, wouldn't let her dance with others: All the time she danced with one and the other.
They asked her who she was. She spoke again of her castle of Break-Down and Break-Pot. She thought: "That's an original thing to say. He must say the same: The future will teach you."
And, you understand, she danced until evening. And: "It's time I left: here comes the girl." Something bad will happen to me if I don't leave before the end."
And she stopped in the middle of the gavotte. And 
then in her haste she dropped one of her slippers (in the old days they wore slippers for dancing and shoes for walking), but something that shone like anything. It was like glass, it shone everywhere! She had a beautiful outfit, Cendrouzette, and beautiful shoes, a ribboned hairdo. The fairy had taken three of Cendrouzette's hairs, and three of hers together so that it wouldn't come off her, which clearly noticed everything she was saying. When she lost her slipper, the vault came. Everyone came out to look at her. The whole procession was all the same, the horses, the coachmen, the maids. And she was undressed while still in her little abandoned cabin, where no one went. AI left in the little flying chest:
Fly, fly, fly, my little flying chest
As far as I can hear
Returned home again To arrive before her parents.
And who does she hear there? She had hidden in a little cave to listen to her father, her mother, and her sisters: "No one has taken a liking to this ball: the king And these guys are two innocents."
So the sisters weren't happy, they were saying to each other:
"All the other girls are like us, no one has taken a liking to it."
When the ball guests left, the king's son said to his father:
"This is the one I need, this is the one I want."
"You're right," said the king, "we must go with the slipper. We must find the one who will fit it." The one who will fit it will certainly be the person the other one lost.

One slipper will bring the other one back to life."
So he sent all his servants searching, searching. Everywhere they went, they found the other slipper. And after that, right? You had to go to your father and mother's. The sisters were tiny young ladies who never worked, who only changed their clothes two or three times a day. When they came home, they said:
"We're looking for a young lady wearing a slipper like that one. Come on, ladies, try it!"
It wouldn't work. There was no way: one was too big, the other was gaping. They were about to leave, and then they turned their heads, and saw Cendrouzette in the corner, sitting in the corner of the fireplace. She said nothing but knew perfectly well what it was—because her sisters:
"Oh! What a crazy idea! She has feet like elephants!" And then, well, anyway:
"Oh! We've come to see all the young ladies' feet. We want to put shoes on this one."
And at the same moment they turned their heads, the fairy transformed it into a ball gown. And then, of course, at the same time as she wanted to put the shoe in, from her little pocket she took out the "personage" of that girl and put shoes on them both. Her sisters were confused, her father and her mother were confused. The king came for her, and his boy. And they got married afterward. They didn't care that she had been named Cendouzette, and that she had been in ashes the whole time.
And her mother asked her forgiveness for the troubles she had caused. The king asked, "Whatever she wanted to do, did she want to punish her parents?" She said, "No, but they mustn't start hurting anyone again."
And that's it.
Said by Madame Ernest Cosset, in La Goujardiere, a hamlet in the commune of Boupre (Vendée), on April 3, 1945.
Ariane de Félice Survey, Poitou (Museum of Popular Arts and Traditions - Ms 59.2).

Content:
Une mère avait deux filles dont l’une était belle et l’autre laide. La mère préférait la Laide. Elle faisait tout pour empêcher la Belle de se marier ; elle menait la Laide à tous les bals, laissait la Belle à la maison, et elle devait laver le linge, récurer la case, faire cuire le manger, faire tout le travail, tandis que la Laide ne faisait jamais rien.
Un jour, la mère dit à la Belle :« Voici un paquet d’aiguilles et d’épingles mélangées; il faut les démêler et les ranger pendant que nous serons à la messe », et elle partit avec la Laide à la grand’messe. Il y avait naturellement aussi le ménage à faire.
Quand sa mère fut partie, la jeune fille alla prendre de l'eau à la fontaine. Là, elle rencontra une vieille femme qui lui dit:«Mon enfant, pourquoi pleurez-vous ?» Elle repondit:« Ma mère m’a donné beaucoup de travail à faire et je n’en finirai jamais de déméler les épingles et les aiguilles. Et si, à son retour, je n’ai pas fini, elle me battra».
Alors, la vieille lui donna une petite baguette et lui dit : « Tu n'auras qu’à dire : par cette petite baguette, faites que j'aie ce que je désire ! ».
La Belle prit la baguette et retourna à la maison toute joyeuse. Elle regarda la baguette et dit: « Faites que la maison soit bien rangée et que les épingles et les aiguilles séparent!». Tout fut fait selon son désir.
Quand sa mère revint de la messe, elle fut étonnée de voir que tous les travaux étaient finis.
Le dimanche suivant, en partant pour la messe, elle donna à faire plus de travail encore que la première fois Cette fois la Belle fit ses travaux en un tournemain, grâce à la baguette et, quand tout fut rangé, épousseté, bien en place, elle demanda à sa baguette de beaux vêtements pour s'habiller et un joli carrosse pour la conduire, elle aussi, à la messe.
Quand elle arriva à l’église, tout le monde la regarda. On la prenait pour une princesse, tant elle était jolie.
Mais elle partit un peu avant la fin de la messe, et quand sa mère rentra, la Belle, comme toujours, portait sa robe de travail. La mère lui dit: «Si tu avais été à l’église, tu aurais vu une princesse ». La fille ne répondit rien.
Le dimanche suivant, elle eut encore plus de travail, mais la baguette fit tout en un clin d'œil. Et sa mère n’était pas arrivée que, déjà, le carrosse s’arrêta devant l’église. Elle était encore plus belle que le premier dimanche, et tout le monde l’admira. Elle repartit un peu avant la fin de la messe.
Mais, en descendant les marches de l’église, un de ses souliers tomba. Comme elle était pressée d’être rentrée avant sa mère elle ne le ramassa pas.
On trouva le soulier, et on l’apporta au Roi qui déclara que la jeune fille à qui appartenait ce soulier serait la femme de son fils.
Le Roi fit donc chercher, dans tout le pays, la femme qui pourrait chausser ce soulier.
Les messagers du Roi avaient déjà visité toutes les maisons, et fait essayer la soulier à toutes les jeunes filles du pays. Aucune n’avait pu le chausser.
Il ne restait plus que la maison de la mère des deux filles à visiter. Quand les messagers du Roi vinrent, ils lui demandèrent où étaient ses deux filles. Elle ne montra que la Laide, disant que l’autre était absente. La Laide essaya la chaussure, nais elle ne put y entrer, et les envoyés du Roi allaient partir quand ils entendirent le perroquet dire : « La belle est sous la baille! !»
La mère voulut faire taire le perroquet. En vain! Elle voulut le chasser ; mais il s’obstinait à répéter : «La Belle est sous la baïlle !». Finalement les envoyés du Roi avisérent un baril retourné et, en effet, la Belle était dessous. Ils lui essayèrent le soulier, qui la chaussa sans effort.
La mère, voyant cela, en devint comme folle de colère, mais cela ne lui servit à rien.
Quelques jours après, fut célébré le mariage de la Belle avec le fils du Roi, et la mère, ainsi que la Laide, durent les servir comme leurs domestiques.
Mr: Schont, Quelques contes créoles, Basse-Terre,
Imp. Catholique, 1935, p. 55-58.
English:
A mother had two daughters, one of whom was beautiful and the other ugly. The mother preferred the Ugly One. She did everything to prevent Beauty from getting married; she took the Ugly One to all the balls, left Beauty at home, and she had to wash the clothes, scrub the hut, cook the food, and do all the work, while the Ugly One never did anything.
One day, the mother said to Beauty, "Here is a bundle of mixed needles and pins; we must untangle them and put them away while we are at mass," and she left with the Ugly One to High Mass. There was, of course, also housework to do.
When her mother had left, the young girl went to get some water from the fountain. There, she met an old woman who said to her, "My child, why are you crying?" She replied, "My mother has given me a lot of work to do, and I will never finish untangling the pins and needles. And if, when she returns, I haven't finished, she will beat me."
Then the old woman gave her a small wand and said, "All you have to do is say: With this little wand, make me have what I desire!"
Beauty took the wand and returned home full of joy. She looked at the wand and said, "Make the house tidy and keep the pins and needles separate!" Everything was done as she wished.
When her mother returned from Mass, she was surprised to see that all the work was finished. The following Sunday, as she left for Mass, she gave even more work to do than the first time. This time, Beauty did her chores in a jiffy, thanks to the wand. When everything was tidied, dusted, and in its proper place, she asked her wand for beautiful clothes to wear and a pretty carriage to take her to Mass.
When she arrived at the church, everyone stared at her. They thought she was a princess, she was so pretty.
But she left a little before the end of Mass, and when her mother returned, Beauty, as always, was wearing her work dress. Her mother said to her, "If you had been to church, you would have seen a princess." The girl said nothing.
The following Sunday, she had even more work to do, but the wand did everything in the blink of an eye. And her mother hadn't even arrived when the carriage stopped in front of the church. She was even more beautiful than on the first Sunday, and everyone admired her. She left a little before the end of Mass.
But, as she was going down the church steps, one of her shoes fell off. As she was in a hurry to be home before her mother, she didn't pick it up.
The shoe was found and brought to the King, who declared that the girl to whom it belonged would be his son's wife.
The King therefore had a search throughout the country for the woman who could fit the shoe.
The King's messengers had already visited every house and had every young girl in the country try on the shoe. Not one had been able to fit it.
The only house left to visit was the house of the two girls' mother. When the King's messengers came, they asked her where her two daughters were. She pointed only to the Ugly One, saying the other was away. The Ugly One tried on the shoe, but she couldn't get into it, and the King's envoys were about to leave when they heard the parrot say, "Beauty is under the barrel!"
The mother tried to silence the parrot. In vain! She tried to chase it away, but it persisted in repeating, "Beauty is under the barrel!" Finally, the King's envoys spotted an overturned barrel, and indeed, Beauty was underneath it. They tried on the shoe, and it fit her effortlessly.
The mother, seeing this, became furious, but it was of no use.
A few days later, Beauty's marriage to the King's son was celebrated, and the mother, as well as the Ugly One, had to serve them as their servants.
Mr. Schont, Quelques contes créoles, Basse-Terre, Catholic Press, 1935, pp. 55-58.

Content:
Il y avait une fois un veuf qui se remaria avec une veuve. La veuve avait deux filles arrogantes et laides, le veuf en avait une gentille et bonne. La marâtre sans cœur en faisait le souffre-douleur de la maison. Elle lui avait fait une robe avec des chiffons et des guenilles : sa place au foyer était sur la cendre; c’est pourquoi on l’appelait Marie Brasoc, saleté, en se moquant d’elle. L'imbécile de père un jour prit une anguille : « Il faut la porter à Monsieur le curé, dit-il aux enfants... » On envoya Marie Brasoc: « Au moins, lui dit son père, n'échappe pas la petite anguille ! » La fille la tenait serrée dans un chiffon; mais quand elles furent près de l’eau l’anguille dit à Marie Brasoc : « Petite fillette, laisse-moi boire, j'ai tant de soif! — Non, petite anguille, tu t’échapperais, disait l'enfant, et mon père me battrait. — Marie Brasoc, laisse-moi boire, je te réponds que tu ne ten repentiras pas! »
Avec son bon cœur la fillette pour laisser boire l’anguille, la présenta à l’eau, l’échappa, et l’anguille si agile fut aussitôt au milieu de la mer. Et alors l’enfant de pleurer, d'appeler l’anguille. Elle s’accroupit là morfondue.
Quand l’anguille la vit ainsi affligée, pleurant : « Marie
Brasoc, lui dit-elle, ne te chagrine pas; si l’on te fait de la peine, tu viendras ici, tu me diras: “Petite anguille du milieu de la mer, viens m’assister !” Et alors, je viendrai.
- Merci, petite anguille, dit l'enfant. » À l’arrivée elle fut battue.
Il n'était jamais question de la laiser sortir. Un jour qu'elle avait demandé d'aller à la messe avec les autres, pour la punir d’être si indiscrète, la marâte la condamna à ramasser sur la litière étendue un sac de mil y était répandu.
La malheureuse pendant la messe s'en alla appeler petite anguille : « Petite anguille du milieu de la mer, viens m'assister » lui cria-t-elle. Et petite anguille d'arriver, de mettre le mil en pile d'un coup de queue. La marâtre revint de la messe comme le diable qui vient de faire Pâques ; le mil était au sac.
Le dimanche après elle alla imaginer la malice de faire ramasser à l'enfant une bouteille d’huile sur les carreaux
L'autre appela de nouveau petite anguille : « Petite anguille du milieu de la mer, viens m’assister ». Et petite anguille de revenir, et d’un coup de queue de ramasser l’huile.
« Merci petite anguille, lui disait la petite fille. - Tu le vois, enfant, lui disait petite anguille, rendre service porte intérêts. »
Alors un roi invita les jeunes filles de tous les riches à une assemblée. La marâtre n'y voulut pas Marie Brasoc.
La fête faisait regret à la fillette ; elle s’en alla appeler l’anguille. « Pauvrette, lui dit l’anguille, tu iras et tu y auras succés plus que toutes. » Et d’un coup de queue la fillette se trouva parée d’une robe de lune, ce qu'il y a de plus beau.
Elle arriva à l'assemblé sans être connue ; mais tous ne regardèrent qu'elle de tout le bal. Elle quitta un peu avant minuit, pour arriver plus tôt que ses parents à la maison, « Ah! Marie Brasoc, lui dirent les autres à l'arrivée, quelle belle personne nous avons vue ! - Pas plus que moi, fit Marie Brasoc tout bas entre les dents. » Les autres l'entendirent, alors il y eut des cris contre la pauvre enfant, qu'on appela effrontée, prétentieuse, bavarde.
Le fils du roi fasciné par la jeune fille si belle avec sa robe clair de lune chercha, fit chercher; il ne la trouva jamais.
Il fit encore des invitations et Marie Brasoc revint auprès de petite anguille : « Petite anguille du milieu de la mer, viens m'assister. » Et petite anguille d’arriver, et d’un coup de queue elle la revêtit d’une robe de soleil. Quand la jeune fille entra dans l'assemblée, à l'éclair qui rayonna autour d'elle, avec sa robe qui étincelait à chaque pas de la si belle enfant, toutes les autres s’écartèrent d’elle contre les murailles pour laisser la plus belle seule au milieu de la salle, comme au matin s’éclipsent les étoiles au point du jour pour laisser le soleil donner la lumière au milieu du ciel.
Le prince demeura toujours auprès d'elle; il ne la quittait pas des yeux. Heureuse elle se promenait, parlait avec le prince; mais pour tant que tout lui fût sympathique dans l’assemblée, quand on arriva aux environs de minuit, elle partit vite ; et elle perdit une pantoufle que le prince ramassa. Cette pantoufle de verre était pour un pied de petite fille. Pour trouver son pied, le prince fit publier que la fille qui chausserait la pantoufle serait sa compagne. Tous les pieds se trouvèrent trop grands et massifs, surtout ceux des filles de la marâtre qui avaient des pieds comme des planches et des mains de fermière. Marie Brasoc ne se présenta pas parce que la marâtre le lui défendit. Le prince l'envoya chercher, et la pantoufle fut comme de mesure.
Alors le prince reconnut Marie Brasoc et l'épousa.
Ils étaient heureux quand une guerre fit partir le prince à l’armée au moment où la princesse eut un bel enfant.
Mais la marâtre changea les lettres où la princesse annonçait son bonheur, et elle écrivit au prince qu’au lieu d'un enfant il avait un monstre. Cette coquine fit périr l'enfant dans l’eau, mais l’anguille le recueillit et le sauva.
Le prince rentré parla de faire périr la princesse ; et comme il allait donner des ordres pour cela, l'anguille lui porta le petit ange beau comme sa mère. Alors on continuait la perfidie de la marâtre. Ce que fit le prince, il demanda pardon à la princesse ; la corde préparée pour elle servit à pendre la méchante.
Abbé Léopold Dardy, Anthologie de l'Albret, Agen, 1891, t. II, p. 34-43.
English:
Once upon a time, there was a widower who remarried a widow. The widow had two arrogant and ugly daughters, the widower had one kind and good one. The heartless stepmother made her the scapegoat of the house. She had made her a dress with rags and rags: her place in the hearth was on the ashes; that is why she was called Marie Brasoc, filth, in mockery of her. The imbecile father one day took an eel: "You must take it to the priest," he said to the children... " Marie Brasoc was sent: "At least," her father said to her, "don't let the little eel escape!" The girl held her tightly in a rag; but when they were near the water the eel said to Marie Brasoc: "Little girl, let me drink, I am so thirsty!" "No, little eel, you would escape," said the child, "and my father would beat me." —Marie Brasoc, let me drink, I assure you that you will not regret it!

With her kind heart, the little girl, in order to let the eel drink, presented it to the water, dropped it, and the agile eel was immediately in the middle of the sea. And then the child cried, calling the eel. It crouched there, grieving.
When the eel saw her so distressed, crying: "Marie Brasoc," she said to her, "do not be upset; if anyone hurts you, you will come here, you will say to me: 'Little eel from the middle of the sea, come and help me!' And then, I will come."

"Thank you, little eel," said the child." Upon arrival, she was beaten.
There was never any question of letting her out. One day, when she asked to go to Mass with the others, as punishment for being so indiscreet, the stepmother sentenced her to pick up a sack of millet from the litter spread out on the floor.
The poor girl went off during Mass to call Little Eel: "Little eel from the middle of the sea, come and help me!" she shouted. And Little Eel arrived and piled the millet in a pile with a flick of his tail. The stepmother returned from Mass like the devil who has just celebrated Easter; the millet was in the sack.
The following Sunday, she went and thought up the mischief of making the child pick up a bottle of oil from the tiles.
The other called Little Eel again: "Little eel from the middle of the sea, come and help me." And Little Eel returned and with a flick of his tail picked up the oil.
"Thank you, Little Eel," the little girl said to her. "You see, child," the little eel told her, "doing a favor pays off."
Then a king invited the young daughters of all the rich men to a gathering. The stepmother didn't want Marie Brasoc there.
The little girl missed the party; she went off to call the eel. "Poor thing," the eel told her, "you'll go and you'll have been more successful than all of them." And with a flick of her tail, the little girl found herself adorned in a moon-like dress, the most beautiful thing there is.
She arrived at the gathering unrecognized; but everyone looked at her only during the entire ball. She left a little before midnight, arriving home earlier than her parents. "Ah! Marie Brasoc," the others said to her upon arrival, "what a beautiful person we saw!" "No more than I," Marie Brasoc said quietly through her teeth. » The others heard her, and then there were shouts against the poor child, who was called impudent, pretentious, and talkative.
The king's son, fascinated by the young girl so beautiful in her moonlight dress, searched and had others search; he never found her.
He made more invitations, and Marie Brasoc returned to Little Eel: "Little Eel from the middle of the sea, come and help me." And Little Eel arrived, and with a flick of her tail, she dressed her in a sundress. When the young girl entered the assembly, at the flash of lightning that shone around her, with her dress sparkling with each step of the beautiful child, all the others moved away from her against the walls to leave the most beautiful one alone in the middle of the room, as the stars disappear at daybreak in the morning to let the sun shine in the middle of the sky.
The prince remained with her always; He never took his eyes off her. She happily walked around, talking with the prince; but although everyone in the assembly was sympathetic to her, when they arrived around midnight, she left quickly; and she lost a slipper, which the prince picked up. This glass slipper was for a little girl's foot. To find her foot, the prince had it published that the girl who fitted the slipper would be his companion. All the feet were found to be too big and bulky, especially those of the stepmother's daughters, who had feet like planks and the hands of a farmer. Marie Brasoc did not come because the stepmother forbade her. The prince sent for her, and the slipper was a perfect fit.
Then the prince recognized Marie Brasoc and married her.
They were happy when a war forced the prince into the army just as the princess was having a beautiful child.
But the stepmother changed the letters in which the princess announced her happy, and she wrote to the prince that instead of a child, he had a monster. This rogue caused the child to perish in the water, but the eel picked him up and saved him.
The prince returned and spoke of causing the princess to perish; and as he was about to give orders for this, the eel brought him the little angel, as beautiful as his mother. Then the stepmother's perfidy continued. The prince did this: he begged the princess for forgiveness; the rope prepared for her was used to hang the wicked woman.
Abbé Léopold Dardy, Anthologie de l'Albret, Agen, 1891, vol. II, pp. 34-43.

Content:
Il était une fois une flemme qui avait trois filles. aînée s’appelait Un-Œil, parce qu elle n avait qu'un seul oeil au milieu du front; la fille puînée s’appelait Double-Oeil, parce qu’elle avait deux yeux comme tout le monde, et la cadette s'appelait Triple-Œil parce qu’elle avait trois yeux, et chez elle aussi, le troisième œil se trouvait au milieu du front. Mais parce que Double-Œil avait la même apparence que les autres gens, ses sœurs et sa mère ne pouvaient la souffrir. « Toi, avec tes deux yeux, tu ne vaux pas mieux que le peuple ordinaire, tu n’es pas des nôtres! », lui disaient-elles. Elles la poussaient d’un coin dans un autre, lui jetaient de méchants habits, lui donnaient pour toute nourriture des restes de leurs repas, et ne manquaient pas une occasion de la maltraiter.
Un jour, Double-Œil dut sortir au champ pour garder leur chèvre. Elle avait cependant encore très faim car ses sœurs lui avaient donné très peu à manger. Elle s’assit donc sur un muret et fondit en larmes, et elle pleurait tant que deux ruisseaux se mirent à couler de ses yeux. Et quand, tout en se lamentant, elle leva les yeux, elle vit une femme debout près d’elle qui lui demanda :
— Pourquoi pleures-tu, Double-Œil ?
— Ne devrais-je pas pleurer ? répondit Double-Oeil. Parce que j'ai deux yeux comme tout le monde, mes sœurs et ma mêre ne peuvent me souffrir. Elles me poussent d’un coin dans un autre, me jettent de vieux habits et me donnent
leurs restes pour toute nourriture. Et aujourd’hui, elles m'en ont donné si peu que j'ai encore très faim.
- Sèche tes larmes, Double-Œil, répondit la femme sage, Je vais te dire quelque chose qui te permettra de ne plus avoir à souffrir de la faim. Tu n'auras qu’à dire à ta chèvre :
« Méé, ma biquetle,
Petite table, sois prête »
et une petite table joliment dressée apparaîtra devant toi, couverte des meilleurs mets qui soient, si bien que tu pourras manger autant que tu voudras. Et quand tu seras rassasiée et que tu n'auras plus besoin de la petite table, tu n’auras qu’à dire:
« Ma biquette, méê,
Petite table, disparais »
et elle disparaîtra. »
Sur ces mots, la femme sage partit. Double-Œil, quant à
elle, se disait : «11 faut absolument que j'essaie tout de suite pour voir si elle a dit vrai: j'ai bien trop faim ! » Elle dit donc:
« Méé, ma biquette,
Petite table, sois prête »,
À peine avait-elle prononcé ces paroles qu’une petite table apparut, couverte d’une jolie nappe blanche, et sur laquelle se trouvait une assiette avec un couteau, une fourchette et une cuiller d'argent. Tout autour, il y avait les meilleurs mets qui soient, fumants et encore tout chauds, comme s’ils étaient sortis tout droit de la cuisine. Double-Œil récita alors la prière la plus courte qu’elle connût: «Seigneur Dieu, sois notre hôte maintenant et toujours, Amen». Puis elle se servit et mangea de bon appétit. Et lorsqu'elle fut rassasiée, elle dit, comme le lui avait enseigné la femme sage :
« Ma biquette, méé,
Petite table, disparais »
La petite table disparut aussitôt avec touvait. « Voilà une belle cuisine !», se dit Double-Oeil, toute contente et de bonne humeur.
Le soir, quand elle rentra chez elle avec sa chèvre, Double-Œil trouva une gamelle de terre avec de le nourriture que ses sœurs lui avaient laissée, mais elle n'y tou- cha pas. Le lendemain matin, elle sortit de nouveau avec sa chèvre et laissa là les quelques morceaux qu'on lui donna. La première et la deuxième fois, ses soeurs ne ça rendirent compte de rien, mais comme la même chose se reproduisait tous les jours, elles s’en aperçurent et se dirent entre elles : «Quelque chose ne tourne pas rond, avec Double-Œil : elle laisse à chaque fois son repas, et pourtant, d'habitude, elle mangeait tout ce qu’on lui donnait sans en laisser une miette. Elle aura trouvé d’autres moyens. » Et pour pouvoir la percer à jour, Un-Œil devait accompagner Double-Œil quand celle-ci mênerait la chèvre à la pâture, et elle devait surveiller ce que celle-ci faisait et s'il n’y avait pas quelqu'un qui lui apportait à boire et à manger.
Aussi, quand Double-Oeil s’apprêta à repartir, Un-Œil s'approcha d’elle et lui dit:«Je vais t’accompagner au champ pour voir si tu gardes la chèvre comme il faut et si tu la mènes bien à un endroit où elle peut manger. » Mais Double-Œil comprit ce qu’elle avait derrière la tête. Elle mena la chèvre dans un champ où l'herbe était très haute et dit à sa soeur : « Viens, Un-Oeil, asseyons-nous, je vais te chanter quelque chose. » Un-Oeil s'assit, mais la route, qu'elle n'avait pas l’habitude de faire, et la chaleur du soleil l'avaient fatiguée. Double-Œil chantait sans cesse :
« Un-Oeil veilles-tu ?
Un-Oeil, dors-tu ?»
Un-Œil ferma alors son unique œil et s’endormit. Quand Double-Œil vit que sa sœur dormait profondément et qu'elle ne pouvait pas la trahir, elle dit :
« Méê, MA biquelle,
Aa fable, sois prête »
puis elle s'installa à sa petite table, mangea et but jusqu'à ce qu'elle fût rassasiée, puis elle dit de nouveau:
« Ma biguette, méê,
Petite table, disparais »
et, en un clin d'œil, tout eut disparu. Double-Œil réveilla alors Un-Œil et lui dit: «Un-Oeil, tu voulais garder la chèvre. mais tu t'es endormie ! Pendant ce temps, elle aurait pu se et s'enfuir Dieu sait où! Viens, rentrons à la maison.» Elles rentrèrent donc chez elles et, une fois de plus, Double-Œil ne toucha pas à sa gamelle. Un-Œil, quant à elle, fut incapable de dire à sa mère pourquoi sa sœur ne mangeait pas et dit, pour s'excuser: «Quand nous étions dehors, je me suis endormie ».
Le lendemain, la mère dit à Triple-Œil :« Cette fois, c’est toi qui accompagneras Double-Œil et qui devras faire attention pour voir si elle se nourrit dehors et si quelqu'un vient lui apporter à boire et à manger, car elle doit le faire en cachette.» Triple-Œil s’approcha donc de Double-Œil et lui dit: «Je vais t'accompagner pour voir si tu gardes bien la chèvre comme il faut et si tu la mènes bien à un endroit où elle peut manger.» Mais Double-Œil comprit ce qu’elle avait derrière la tête. Elle mena la chèvre dans un champ où l'herbe était très haute et dit à sa sœur : «Viens, Triple-Œil, asseyons-nous, je vais te chanter quelque chose.» Triple-Œil s’assit, mais la route et la chaleur du soleil l'avaient fati- guée. Double-Œiïl reprit la même chanson que la fois précédente :
« Triple-Œil, veilles-tu ?»
Mais au lieu de chanter, comme elle aurait dû le faire:
« Triple-Œil, dors-tu ?»
elle chantait, par étourderie :
« Double-Œïl, dors-tu ?»
et elle continuait ainsi:
« Triple-Œil, veilles-tu ?
Double-Œil, dors-tu ?»
Les deux yeux de Triple-Œil se fermèrent alors et s'endormirent, mais le troisième œil ne s'endormit pas, car la formulette ne s’adressait pas à lui. Certes, Thiple-Oeil le ferma, mais seulement par ruse, pour faire comme si cet œil-là dormait aussi. Mais en réalité, elle clignait de cet oeil et voyait tout parfaitement. Et quand Double-Oeil crut que sa sœur dormait à poings profondément, elle dit sa petit formulette :
« Méé, ma biquette,
Petite table, sois prête »
mangea et but jusqu’à ce qu’elle fût rassasiée, puis ordonna à sa petite table de repartir :
« Ma biquette, méeé,
Petite table, disparais»
Or Triple-Œil avait tout vu. Double-Œil revint alors vers elle, la réveilla et lui dit:«Eh bien, Triple-Œil, tu tes endormie ? Tu fais une bonne gardienne! Viens, rentrons à la maison. » Quand elles furent de retour chez elles, Double-Œil ne mangea pas, une fois de plus, et Triple-Œil dit à sa mère: «A présent, je sais pourquoi cette créature orgueilleuse ne mange pas. Quand elle est dehors et qu'elle dit à la chèvre :
« Méé, ma biguette,
Petite table, sois prête »
une petite table apparaît devant elle, chargée des meilleurs mets qui soient, bien meilleurs que ce que nous mangeons ici. Et quand elle est rassasiée, elle dit:
« Ma biquette, méé.
Petite table, disparais »
et tout disparaît de nouveau. J'ai observé tout cela bien attentivement : elle m'a endormi deux yeux avec une petite formulette, mais heureusement, l'œil que j'ai sur le front était resté éveillé.» La mère, jalouse, s'écria alors : « Comment ? Tu veux avoir un sort meilleur que le nôtre ? Eh bien, l'envie t'en passera ! » Elle saisit un couteau de boucher et le planta dans le coeur de la chèvre, qui s'écroula, morte, sur le sol.
À la veu de cela, Double-Oeil sortit bien chagrinée de la maisons, s’assit sur un muret du champ et se mit à verser des larmes amères. Soudain, le femme sage apparut de nouveau près d'elle et lui dit:
- Pourquoi pleures-tu, Double-Oeil ?
- Ne devrais-je pas pleurer ? répondit celle-ci, La chèvre qui me mettait si bien la table quand je disais votre formulette, à été poignardée par ma mère. À présent, je dois à nouveau souffrir de la faim et des soucis.
- Je vais te donner un bon conseil, Double-Œil, répondit la femme sage. Demande à tes sœurs de te donner les intestins de la chèvre que ta mère a abattue. Enterre ceux-ci dans le sol près de la porte de la maison, et ton bonheur sera assuré.
Après avoir prononcé ces mots, la femme sage disparut, et Double-Œil retourna dans la maison et dit à ses sœurs:
- Mes chères sœurs, donnez-moi tout de même quelque chose de ma chèvre. Je ne veux pas de bon morceau, donnez-moi juste les intestins.
- Tu peux les avoir, si cela te suffit, dirent ses sœurs en éclatant de rire.
Double-Œil prit donc les intestins et, le soir, quand tout fut silencieux, elle les enterra près de la porte de la maison, comme le lui avait dit la femme sage.
Le lendemain matin, quand elles furent toutes réveillées et qu’elles sortirent de la maison, un arbre magnifique et merveilleux se dressait là, qui portait des feuilles d'argent et, au milieu des feuilles, des fruits d’or, si bien qu'on
n'avait jamais rien vu de plus beau ni de plus exquis dans le vaste monde. Elles ignoraient cependant comment cet arbre était apparu là pendant la nuit. Seule Double-Oeil comprit qu'il avait poussé à partir des intestins chèvre, car il se trouvait à l'endroit même où elle les avait enterrés.
La mère s’adressa alors à Un-Œil: « Grimpe dans l'arbre, mon enfant, et cueille-nous des fruits, » Un Œil grimpa dans l'arbre, mais comme elle s’apprêtait à saisir une des pommes d’or, la branche lui échappa des mains. Et la même chose se reproduisit à chaque fois, si bien qu'elle eut beau faire tout ce qu'elle pouvait, elle fut incapable de cueillir la moindre pomme. La mère dit alors: « À ton tour, Triple-Œil. Avec tes trois yeux, tu peux mieux voir qu'Un-Œil ce qui se passe autour de toi.» Un-Œil redescendit de l'arbre et Triple-Œil y grimpa. Mais elle ne fut pas plus adroite : elle avait beau regarder autant qu’elle pouvait, les pommes d’or se dérobaient toujours. La mère finit par s'impatienter et grimpa elle-même dans l'arbre, mais elle parvint aussi peu qu'Un-Œil et Triple-Œil à saisir les fruits :à chaque tentative, ses mains se refermaient sur le vide.
Double-Œil dit alors:«Je veux essayer, moi aussi. Peut-être y parviendrai-je, moi.» Ses sœur s’écrièrent, certes: «Que veux-tu donc, toi, avec tes deux yeux ? » Double-Œil grimpa tout de même dans l'arbre et les pommes d’or ne se dérobèrent pas à ses mains:bien au contraire, elles vinrent se placer d’elles-mêmes dans sa main, si bien qu'elle put les cueillir l’une après l’autre, et qu’elle redescendit de l’arbre avec son tablier rempli de pommes. La mère les lui prit, mais au lieu de traiter mieux la pauvre Double-Œil en échange de cela, ses filles et elles ne furent que jalouses, parce qu'elle seule pouvait cueillir les fruits de l'arbre, et elles furent encore plus dures avec elle qu'auparavant.
Un jour, alors qu’elles se trouvaient toutes ensemble près de larbre, un jeune chevalier passa par là. « Vite, Double-Œil, cache-toi là-dessous, Pour que nous n’ayons pas honte de toi!», s’écrièrent ses deux sœurs en renversant en toute hâte au-dessus de la malheureuse jeune fille un tonneau
vide se trouvait à côté de l'arbre. Elles cachèrent aussi sous le tonneau les pommes d'or que Double-Oeil venait de cueillir. Quand le chavelier - qui était bel homme - s'approcha, il s'adressa ainsi aux deux soeurs: « À qui est ce bel abre ? Celle d'entre vous qui m'en donnerait un rameau pourrait me demander en échange tout ce qu'elle désire.» Un-Œil et Triple-Œil répondirent alros que l'arbre était à elles et qu elles voulaient bien lui en donner un rameau. Elles se donnèrent en effet bien du mal toutes les deux, mais elles n'y parvinrent pas, car les branches et les fruits se retiraient chaque fois qu elles en approchaient les mains. Le chevalier dit alors : «C’est bien étrange que cet arbre soit à vous et que vous n'ayez cependant pas le pouvoir d’en cueillir quoi que ce soit. » Elles maintinrent cependant que l'arbre était leur propriété. Mais pendant qu’elles parlaient ainsi, Double-Œil, qui se trouvait sous le tonneau, fit rouler quelques pommes d’or jusqu'aux pieds du chevalier, car elle était en colère que ses sœurs ne dissent pas la vérité. À la vue des pommes, le chevalier s’étonna et demanda d’où elles venaient. Un-Œil et Triple-Œïl répondirent alors qu’elles avaient encore une sœur, mais que celle-ci ne pouvait se montrer parce qu’elle n’avait que deux yeux, comme le commun des mortels. Le chevalier exigea cependant de la voir et appela :« Double-Œil, sors!» Double-Œil sortit donc, toute confiante, de dessous le tonneau, et le chevalier fut émerveillé par sa beauté et lui parla ainsi:
— Toi, Double-Œil, tu peux certainement me briser un rameau de cet arbre.
— Oui, répondit-elle. J'espère bien en être capable, car cet arbre est à moi.
Elle y grimpa et brisa sans aucune difficulté un rameau portant des feuilles d’argent et des fruits d’or, qu’elle tendit au chevalier. Celui-ci lui répondit alors:
— Double-Œil, que dois-je te donner en retour ?
— Ah, répondit la jeune fille, je souffre de faim et de soif, de chagrin et de misère du lever jusqu’au coucher du
soleil: si seulement vous pouviez m'en délivrer en m'emmenant avec vous, je serais heureuse !
Le chevalier prit alors Double-Oeil dans ses bras, l'installa sur son cheval et l'emmena dans le château royal dem son père. Là-bas, il lui donna de beaux habits, de quoim boire et manger autant qu'elle le désirait, et comme il l'aimait tant, il fit bénir son union avec elle et leur mariagem fut célébré avec grande joie.
Mais c’est au moment où le beau chevalier emmena ainsi Double-Œïil que ses deux sœurs lui envièrent vraiment son bonheur. «Qu’à cela ne tienne, il nous reste l'arbre merveilleux, se dirent-elles. Même si nous ne pouvons en cueillir les fruits, tout le monde s'arrêtera devant et viendra nous voir pour nous en faire compliment : qui sait si la fortune ne nous sourira pas, à nous aussi ! » Mais le lendemain matin, l’arbre avait disparu et leur espoir avec. Et lorsque Double-Œil regarda par la fenêtre de sa petite chambre, elle eut la grande joie de voir que l'arbre se trouvait devant et qu’il l'avait donc suivie.
Double-Œil vécut heureuse pendant longtemps. Un jour, deux pauvres femmes vinrent la trouver au château et lui demandèrent l’aumône. Elle regarda alors attentivement leurs visages et reconnut ses sœurs Un-Œil et Triple-Œil, qui avaient sombré dans la misère au point de devoir aller sur les routes et mendier pour gagner leur pain. Double-Œil, quant à elle, leur souhaita la bienvenue, fut bonne envers elles et en prit soin, si bien que ses deux Sœurs regrettèrent du fond du cœur le mal qu'elles lui avaient fait dans leur Jeunesse.
Jacob et Wilhelm Grimm, Les Contes de l‘enfance et du foyer, Paris, José Corti (à paraître en 2009).
English:
Once upon a time, there was a lazy girl who had three daughters. The eldest was called One-Eye, because she had only one eye in the middle of her forehead; the younger daughter was called Two-Eye, because she had two eyes like everyone else, and the youngest was called Three-Eye because she had three eyes, and her third eye was in the middle of her forehead too. But because Two-Eye looked like everyone else, her sisters and mother couldn't stand her. "You, with your two eyes, are no better than the common people, you're not one of us!" they would tell her. They pushed her from one corner to another, threw nasty clothes at her, gave her nothing but leftovers from their meals, and never missed an opportunity to mistreat her. One day, Two-Eye had to go out into the field to look after their goat. However, she was still very hungry because her sisters had given her very little to eat. So she sat down on a low wall and burst into tears, crying so much that two streams began to flow from her eyes. And when, while lamenting, she looked up, she saw a woman standing near her who asked her:
"Why are you crying, Two-Eye?"
"Shouldn't I cry?" replied Two-Eye. "Because I have two eyes like everyone else, my sisters and my mother cannot stand me. They push me from one corner to another, throw me old clothes, and give me their leftovers for all I have to eat. And today, they have given me so little that I am still very hungry."
"Dry your tears, Two-Eye," replied the wise woman. "I will tell you something that will allow you to no longer have to suffer from hunger." You only have to say to your goat:
"Méé, my little goat,
Little table, be ready"
and a small, beautifully set table will appear before you, covered with the finest food, so that you can eat as much as you want. And when you are full and no longer need the little table, you only have to say:
"My little goat, méê,
Little table, disappear"
and it will disappear."
With these words, the wise woman left. Two-Eye, for her part, was saying to herself: "I absolutely must try it right away to see if she spoke the truth: I'm so hungry!" » So she said:
"Méé, my little goat,
Little table, be ready."
No sooner had she said these words than a small table appeared, covered with a pretty white tablecloth, and on it stood a plate with a silver knife, fork, and spoon. All around it were the finest dishes, steaming hot and still piping hot, as if they had come straight from the kitchen. Two-Eye then recited the shortest prayer she knew: "Lord God, be our guest now and always, Amen." Then she helped herself and ate with a good appetite. And when she was satisfied, she said, as the wise woman had taught her:
"My little goat, méé,
Little table, disappear."
The little table disappeared immediately with everything. "What a beautiful kitchen!" said Two-Eye to herself, all happy and in a good mood. That evening, when she returned home with her goat, Two-Eye found an earthen bowl with food that her sisters had left for her, but she didn't touch it. The next morning, she went out again with her goat and left there the few morsels that were given to her. The first and second times, her sisters didn't notice anything, but since the same thing happened every day, they noticed it and said to each other: "Something's wrong with Two-Eye: she leaves her meal every time, and yet, usually, she ate everything that was given to her without leaving a crumb. She will have found other ways." » And to be able to see through her, One-Eye had to accompany Two-Eye when she led the goat to the pasture, and she had to watch what the goat was doing and whether someone was bringing her food and water.
So, when Two-Eye was about to leave, One-Eye approached her and said, "I'm going to go with you to the field to see if you're looking after the goat properly and taking her to a place where she can eat." But Two-Eye understood what she had in mind. She led the goat to a field where the grass was very long and said to her sister, "Come, One-Eye, let's sit down, I'm going to sing you something." One-Eye sat down, but the journey, which she wasn't used to, and the heat of the sun had tired her. Two-Eye sang incessantly:
"One-Eye, are you awake?
One-Eye, are you asleep?"
One-Eye then closed her one eye and fell asleep. When Two-Eye saw that her sister was sleeping soundly and could not betray her, she said:
"Méê, MY little dear,
Aa fable, be ready!"
Then she sat down at her little table, ate and drank until she was satisfied, then she said again:
"My little dear, méê,
Little table, disappear"
and, in the blink of an eye, everything was gone. Two-Eye then woke One-Eye and said, "One-Eye, you wanted to look after the goat. But you fell asleep! In the meantime, she could have run away to God knows where! Come on, let's go home." So they went home, and once again, Two-Eye didn't touch her bowl. One-Eye, for her part, was unable to tell her mother why her sister wasn't eating and said, by way of apology, "When we were outside, I fell asleep."
The next day, the mother said to Three-Eye, "This time, you will be the one to accompany Two-Eye and you will have to watch to see if she feeds outside and if anyone comes to bring her food and water, because she has to do it in secret." So Three-Eye approached Two-Eye and said, "I'm going with you to see if you're looking after the goat properly and taking it to a place where it can eat." But Two-Eye understood what she was thinking. She led the goat to a field where the grass was very long and said to her sister, "Come, Three-Eye, let's sit down, I'm going to sing you something." Three-Eye sat down, but the road and the heat of the sun had tired her. Two-Eye sang the same song as before: "Three-Eye, are you awake?" But instead of singing, as she should have done, "Three-Eye, are you sleeping?", she sang, carelessly, "Three-Eye, are you sleeping?" And she continued thus:
"Three-Eye, are you awake?
Two-Eye, are you asleep?"
Three-Eye's two eyes then closed and fell asleep, but the third eye did not fall asleep, for the little phrase was not addressed to it. True, Three-Eye closed it, but only as a trick, to make it appear as if that eye were asleep too. But in reality, it winked with that eye and saw everything perfectly. And when Two-Eye thought that her sister was fast asleep, she said her little phrase:
"Mee, my little goat,
Little table, be ready."
She ate and drank until she was satisfied, then ordered her little table to leave:
"My little goat, mee,
Little table, disappear."
Now Three-Eye had seen everything. Two-Eye then came back to her, woke her up, and said, "Well, Three-Eye, are you asleep? You're making a good babysitter! Come on, let's go home." When they got back home, Two-Eye didn't eat again, and Three-Eye said to his mother, "Now I know why that proud creature doesn't eat. When she's outside and she says to the goat, "Méé, my little goat, Little table, be ready," a little table appears before her, laden with the finest food, much better than what we eat here. And when she's full, she says, "My little goat, méé. Little table, disappear," and everything disappears again. I watched all this very carefully: she put two of my eyes to sleep with a little formula, but fortunately, the eye on my forehead remained awake." The jealous mother then cried out, "What? You want to have a better fate than ours? Well, envy will pass you by!" She grabbed a butcher's knife and plunged it into the goat's heart, which collapsed dead on the ground.
Seeing this, Two-Eye left the house in great sorrow, sat down on a low wall in the field, and began to shed bitter tears. Suddenly, the wise woman appeared again beside her and said, "Why are you crying, Two-Eye?"
"Shouldn't I cry?" she replied. "The goat who set the table so well for me when I said your little saying was stabbed by my mother. Now I must suffer hunger and worry again."
"I'll give you some good advice, Two-Eye," replied the wise woman. Ask your sisters to give you the intestines of the goat your mother slaughtered. Bury them in the ground near the door of the house, and your happiness will be assured.
After saying these words, the wise woman disappeared, and Two-Eye returned to the house and said to his sisters:
"My dear sisters, give me something of my goat anyway. I don't want a good piece, just give me the intestines."
"You can have them, if that's enough for you," said his sisters, bursting into laughter.
So Two-Eye took the intestines and, that evening, when all was quiet, she buried them near the door of the house, as the wise woman had told her. The next morning, when they were all awake and leaving the house, a magnificent and marvelous tree stood there, bearing silver leaves and, among the leaves, golden fruit, such that nothing more beautiful or exquisite had ever been seen in the wide world. They did not know, however, how this tree had appeared there during the night. Only Two-Eye understood that it had grown from the goat's intestines, for it was located on the very spot where she had buried them.
The mother addressed Then to One-Eye: "Climb the tree, my child, and pick us some fruit." One-Eye climbed the tree, but as she was about to seize one of the golden apples, the branch slipped from her hands. And the same thing happened every time, so that no matter how hard she tried, she was unable to pick a single apple. Then the mother said: "Now it's your turn, Three-Eye. With your three eyes, you can see better than One-Eye what is going on around you." One-Eye came down the tree again and Three-Eye climbed up. But she was no more skillful: no matter how hard she looked, the golden apples always slipped away. The mother finally grew impatient and climbed the tree herself, but she was as unsuccessful as One-Eye and Three-Eye in grasping the fruit: each time she tried, her hands closed on nothing.
Two-Eye then said, "I want to try, too. Perhaps I will succeed." His sisters cried out, "What do you want, with your two eyes?" Two-Eye climbed the tree anyway, and the golden apples did not slip from her grasp; on the contrary, they placed themselves in her hand, so that she was able to pick them one after the other, and she came back down from the tree with her apron full of apples. The mother took them from her, but instead of treating poor Two-Eye better in return, they and her daughters were only jealous, because she alone could pick the fruit from the tree, and they were even harsher with her than before.
One day, while they were all together near the tree, a young knight passed by. "Quick, Two-Eye, hide under there, so that we won't be ashamed of you!" cried his two sisters, hastily tipping an empty barrel that was lying beside the tree over the unfortunate girl. They also hid the golden apples that Two-Eye had just picked under the barrel. When the knight—who was a handsome man—approached, he addressed the two sisters thus: "Whose is this beautiful tree?" Any one of you who would give me a branch could ask for anything she wanted in return." One-Eye and Three-Eye then replied that the tree was theirs and that they were willing to give him a branch. They both tried very hard, but they were unable to do so, for the branches and fruit withdrew every time they put their hands near it. The knight then said: "It is very strange that this tree is yours and yet you have no power to pick anything from it." They maintained, however, that the tree was theirs. But while they were talking thus, Two-Eye, who was under the barrel, rolled some golden apples to the knight's feet, for she was angry that her sisters were not telling the truth. When the knight saw the apples, he was astonished and asked where they came from. One-Eye and Three-Eye then replied that they still had a sister, but that she could not show herself because she had only two eyes, like ordinary mortals. The knight, however, demanded to see her and called out, "Two-Eye, come out!" Two-Eye then confidently emerged from under the barrel, and the knight, amazed by her beauty, spoke to her thus:
"You, Two-Eye, can certainly break a branch for me from this tree."
"Yes," she replied. "I hope I can, for this tree is mine."
She climbed up and without any difficulty broke a branch bearing silver leaves and golden fruit, which she held out to the knight. He then replied, "Two-Eye, what must I give you in return?" "Ah," replied the young girl, "I suffer from hunger and thirst, sorrow and misery from sunrise to sunset: if only you could deliver me from them by taking me with you, I would be happy!" The knight then took Two-Eye in his arms, placed her on his horse, and carried her to her father's royal castle. There, he gave her beautiful clothes, as much food and drink as she desired, and since he loved her so much, he had his union with her blessed, and their marriage was celebrated with great joy. But it was when the handsome knight thus took Two-Eye away that his two sisters truly envied him his happiness. "Never mind, we still have the wonderful tree," they said to each other. Even if we can't pick the fruit, everyone will stop in front of it and come and compliment us: who knows, fortune might smile on us too!" But the next morning, the tree had disappeared, and their hope with it. And when Two-Eye looked out of the window of her little room, she was very happy to see that the tree had been in front of it and had therefore followed her. Two-Eye lived happily for a long time. One day, two poor women came to find her at the castle and asked her for alms. She then looked closely at their faces and recognized her sisters One-Eye and Three-Eye, who had fallen into poverty to the point of having to go out on the roads and beg for their bread. Two-Eye, for her part, welcomed them, was kind to them, and took care of them, so much so that her two sisters regretted from the bottom of their hearts the harm they had done her in their youth.
Jacob and Wilhelm Grimm, Tales of Childhood and Home, Paris, José Corti (forthcoming in 2009).
